post:
I had 2 FIV+ cats: a mother and one of her 2 kittens. 
The kitten died at 3 1/2 yo. He got infected  most likely during nursing - I saw one of her nipple bleeding, because the first test at 4 weeks was negative.   
He was healthy until his immune system broke down and he died within a couple of weeks.   
His mother who was FIV+ but never showed any symptoms died of breast cancer at 5 yo, the same week.   
The youngest the cat is infected, the shortest is his life expectancy.   
In order to bring a cat over you need a certificate of health. If the cat is healthy, being FIV+ will not be mentioned. Check with your vet to be sure. 
You should be cautious with vaccinations though and only do what is necessary.    
Some people say that one should not mix FIV+ and FIV- cats. 
I know many rescuers who end up keeping FIV+ cats, without transmissions - as far as I know.   
The virus is not easily transmitted. Like in humans, you need a blood to blood or sexual contact. 
Of course, you can not totally exclude the risk, but from my point of view, it is really minim.   
Now FeLV is another story. The FeLV virus can be transmitted through saliva while grooming and to some extend through urine and feces. Infected cats should be separated from non FelV cats.   
There are very useful and knowledgeable yahoo groups for people with FIV+ cats. I recommend you subscribe there.

Hi Rob1, no, the two assigned pet seats were both aisle seats. Both were on the left side of the plane with only one seat next to them (on the left near the window). The two seats were spaced out about 20 rows apart. When the woman next to me switched sweats with my husband, we had no one sitting next to us (he was the aisle and I was the window) so that worked out well since the carriers extended beyond the space and required us to step around and over them when we got up.

I can't receive stuff during the  week, hence the Saturday delivery question. Zooplus.ch delivers to Switzerland as well, they use DPD, while zooplus.com delivers to Switzerland using DHL.      I called zooplus. They don't deliver on Saturday and you can't select  a specific day according to them.  But according to the dpd website (German version, I've linked to the English one) you can schedule delivery days (I'm guessing  only Mon-Fri) and ask to place the parcels in the stairwell.    
So it's basically "hope and wait and see if they deliver to the place they're supposed to", I guess...?

meloncollie makes a good point about the heat.    
Hopefully by having night flights you will avoid the hottest part of the day anyway, but as you are flying with your dogs, insist on keeping them with you until the last possible moment.  
The airline will often want to take them through to the cargo area as early as possible, but depending on how this is set up it can be quite hot and noisy. Usually if you ask (and make it clear you won't go wandering off) you can stay with your dogs until quite a short time before they are loaded.   
You should always call the airline a day before to confirm anyway, as most aircraft only have one hold appropriate for dogs, and they will bump your dog if they need to transport a body.

Much of the newer Swiss legislation is modeled on the laws in Germany (our whole approach to dog control changed after a tragic incident, much as German regs did somewhat earlier) so if you are familiar with the German system you should have no trouble navigating your way around Switzerland's various dog laws.   
One other thing I should point out, as a fellow owner of a canine crew.   
Renting with more than one dog can be difficult. Not impossible, many of us have done it, but it might mean putting permission to keep multiple dogs as a priority and compromising on location, type of dwelling, etc. Here is where your relocation agent really needs to earn his/her keep. A good 'dog friendly' agent can be the key to success.

From the Tier Im Recht website:       
The Berner Verwaltungsgericht has ruled that the introduction of a leash law along the Limpach canal in Baetterkinden BE is a disproportionate measure, and thus untenable.    
The leash law covered an area that was approximately one-quarter of the Gemeinde land.    
The court argued that because the affected area was open, giving dog owners enough time to bring their dogs under control, a general leash law covering such a large portion of available land was an excessive restriction.   
(One provision of the TSchV is that as far as possible, according to individual needs and level of training and control, dogs should have opportunities for off lead exercise.)   
Gemeinde Baetterkinden still has the option of appealing this ruling  to the Bundesgericht.   
---   
It will be interesting to see if the case goes farther, or if  this decision leads to challenges to similar laws in other communities.   
---   
I would encourage all dog owners (and anyone interested in animal welfare issues) to browse the TIR website now and again. Especially as the laws that affect us can change...

Rates are all over the ballpark, from ca. CHF 20 per hour to CHF 100 per hour.  Group walking is usually at the lower end, walking your dog alone sometimes towards the higher.    
Some dogwalkers will charge mileage on top of that.   
Other things you need to know about :   
Anyone doing commercial (paid) dog care must have completed certain education courses. It is your responsibility to ascertain that your dog walker has the necessary certificates. (For care of up to 5 dogs, the SKN courses - the same course all owners must take* - are sufficient.) You can read more here:       
Make sure you understand insurance liability coverage. Talk to your insurer to understand what falls under your coverage* and/or the walker's. Ask the walker for copies of his/her policy.   
Make sure you have a written contract, covering all expectations and contingencies.    
Get references, and check them out.    
---   
* Since you mention that you are new to Switzerland, a couple of points that you might not have come across yet:   
You are required to take out liability insurance (Privathaftpflicht) of at least 1 mio.   
You are required to take courses yourself. There are two requirements, federal SKN Theory and Practical courses, and the ZH cantonal List 1 courses. (A lab is a List 1 breed.)  Whether you are required to do the more extensive ZH List 1 courses will depend on when your dog was born, before or after 31 Dec 2010.

Bringing this back up, because after discussion with my vet I decided to have Hooligan vaccinated against Lepto this year, using the Lepto 6 vaccine.   
As per my earlier post Hooligan has epilepsy which puts her in the 'compromised' category - so we had to stop vaccinating her some years ago.    
But that decision shouldn't be static. Each year we review the incidence of the various diseases and weigh the consequences of disease against Hooligan's own 'risk profile' and current health.    
Hooligan is still a very active dog who lives and hikes in areas where there have been Lepto cases reported (this year is expected to be particularly bad), our garden is full of mice (rodent urine is a vector) - and she has been seizure-free for a good long time now (knock wood!).  All in all, this year I felt that the benefit of having her vacc'd against Lepto far outweighs the risk. Lepto is a horrible disease, sadly often fatal.   
So just wanted to say to all whose dogs are 'compromised' as Hooligan is - it's a good idea to have regular discussions with your vet, in light of current lepto incidence in your particular area and in light of your dog's individual health factors.   
By the way,  Hooligan  has shown no signs of adverse reaction.    
---   
Young Heffalump gets vaccinated regularly as a matter of course. With the ancient Belltie we do a similar review as to benefits/risks for his individual situation.

post:
hi guys 
so i have been busy with importing my cat (fully grown, pedigree) from south africa to here. 
he is arriving in July, and i thought to share the procedure that I needed to do in order to comply with swiss laws.   
bear in mind that the cat is flying solo (not with a passenger) 
FSVO permit took the longest, but its a very simple process when you know what to do...       For the accompanied entry into Switzerland from a rabies risk country, the animal (dog, cat or ferret) requires the following:     Â·          
The microchip must conform to ISO standard 11784 and must be readable with a reader as specified in ISO standard 11785, i.e. a so-called euro chip, which contains only numbers and no asterisks (*). Otherwise, you must make sure you carry a suitable reader with you.      Â·          
A rabies vaccination can only be recognized as valid if the microchip was implanted before the vaccination. The rabies vaccination is not valid if it is carried out before the animal has reached the age of 12 weeks.      Â·          
A blood sample must be taken from the animal no sooner than 30 days after the rabies vaccination (but within the validity period of the vaccination). This sample must undergo analysis for rabies antibodies. This analysis must be carried out in a laboratory approved by the EU. A list of approved laboratories can be found at  http://ec.europa.eu/food/animal/live...pproval_en.htm  
The blood analysis is followed by a further waiting period of 3 months until entry into Switzerland is possible, provided the result is at least 0.5 IU/mL.     Â·          Must be issued by the official veterinarian responsible or the authorities responsible in the country of origin. The model veterinary certificate and declaration of ownership can be found via the following link:  http://www.blv.admin.ch/themen/04670...x.html?lang=en      Â·          To enter Switzerland via a Swiss airport, a permit issued by the FSVO is required. To obtain a permit, you must send the following documents to the FSVO before your departure: a copy of the laboratory report on the blood analysis, microchip certificate with date of implantation, certificate of rabies vaccinations and the application form (obtainable at  http://www.blv.admin.ch/themen/04670...x.html?lang=en ). The permit costs CHF40. This fee is collected by customs upon entry.     We draw your attention to the fact that, if the animal does not fly with the owner in the passenger cabin, but is carried in the hold, it is absolutely essential to make sure the animal is checked in as ÂAVI in HoldÂ or ÂExcess baggageÂ. This makes it clear for all parties involved (airline, border veterinarians and customs) that the animal is accompanied by the owner, which simplifies entry.

post:
My 2.5 year old bitch, Lucy, was recently spayed (February). She had her ovaries removed and was forbidden from running around off the lead for 10 days. She also had to wear a nifty body stocking to prevent her from worrying at the incision. Unfortunately, unlike the body stocking that my other dog Schotty had to wear after his castration, there were no suitably placed apertures in Lucy's outfit - which meant partly undressing her every time she needed to "do her duty".   
Be warned, though, the night of the surgery (generally they are released home the day of surgery) your dog will be in discomfort and may not have any appetite (Lucy whimpered for a number of hours   and refused everything except some boiled chicken). But Lucy soon bounced back.   
Your vet will (should) prescribe adequate analgesia after surgery and I would suggest giving her the analgesics for a day or two after surgery as, unfortunately, dogs can be in discomfort or pain and not show it. I felt that this course of action was best for Lucy (better safe than sorry).   
Good luck with your little lady.
Maggie knows best.

Greenmount, there are battery farms and scams in every country. The numbers - let alone the sights - will make you ill, then make you cry, then make you very, very angry. No country is immune, no country can sit firmly on it's high horse.   
Wealthy Switzerland is a target for foreign puppy mill operators. There are ready buyers with money in their pockets. Illegal imports are a continual problem, and yes, some of those battery farmers do come from eastern Europe. And they also come from southern Europe. And western Europe. And the UK. In fact, the only reason that you don't see many illegal puppy farm imports from the rest of the world ending up here is that the cost of shipping eats too far into the profit.    
It should be noted, though, that Swiss hands are far from clean. Show me a foreign battery farmer, and I'll show you a Swiss counterpart brokering the sale and taking a chunk of the profit.   
BTW, the only reason you don't see more puppy mills in Switzerland is that the cost of land is so high. You see plenty of BYBs and irresponsible breeding, though.    
As above, no country can sit for very long it's high horse.   
(An eye opener, for instance: google Amish + puppy mill.)   
We've seen it here on EF. How many threads have there been with posters trying to circumvent importation regs? Were all those naive do-gooders, or perhaps some battery farmers in disguise?    
Slammer brings up a very good point about battery farmers disguising themselves as rescues. As the public becomes more educated about responsible purchasing, scammers and battery farmers get more and more creative - and what better way than to tug at a dog lover's heartstrings with a hard luck story.   
---   
It should be said that just as no country is free of the dark side, excellent breeders and rescuers can also be found in all countries.    
Whether one is a breeder or rescuer, buyer or adopter, or simply a dog lover - we all have to join together to fight the 'dark side'.  
---   
Sorry to fly off on a tangent, Galatea. I'm so very happy for you and Chili. She was certainly worth the wait.   
Wishing you both all the best.

Thanks for your thread meloncollie, you might want to add the orange part because it could keep people from letting their dogs off leash more than if they think it's just a civil/etc. matter if they let their dogs off leash.

We spent the days hiking in the black forest and traveling to small villages and towns.  Then off to Munich and once again he was very welcome.  Public transport, restaurants and coffee shops had no problem.   
Europe seems to be a very dog friendly place.

It also reminds me of the one time I was out for a walk and this grenade of a tiny dog came shooting at me. I calmly but firmly called out to the owner to get his dog under control but no, the "oh he won't do anything" tripe was spouted. Tripe in this case, because that dog had nothing better to do than to run up my legs. Owner walked up to me and said "oh, he does that." Thanks indeed  
Not funny as I wasn't in the mood for a dog to do that, because I expect dog owners to have their pets under control when out with them and to at least apologize if they can't even do that.  
So... had the owner either gotten his pet under control or at least said "Sorry, what can I do to have your pants cleaned" or, for crying out loud, "May I offer you a tissue?", I might have been less annoyed, but that's precisely the way to annoy people with your dogs.    
On the other hand, if someone walks up to me with their dog on a leash or at their feet and the dog curiously sniffs my shoes, I ask them if I can pet the dog and   they agree, I do so, asking what the dog's breed/mix/age is and complimenting the owner on their dog's behavior.   
It goes both ways - sometimes people forget that. Thanks for this, Meloncollie.

The most useless drawer in my kitchen has now become useful.   
I am talking about the drawer fitted with the insert for holding bottles. I never used it and was thinking I could put it to use storing dog food.    
We keep the bulky bags (12 - 15kg) downstairs in plastic bins and use smaller tubs (rice keepers from Japan) to transfer the food for daily use. The rice keepers were too big for the bottle drawer and were taking up valuable space in another cupboard.    
I looked everywhere and finally found the perfect solution. From Rotho. They have a new line of pet food storage containers.   
As we needed 3 bins I bought the 4.5 litre containers.      
I could not find these containers in any store so I ordered them online. They were delivered with an invoice.   
I sawed off the inside wires of the basket for the bottles so the containers fit inside the frame.   
I adjusted the height of the little drawer above and in there keep all the dog meds which are given with the food. The dog food scale is not in the photo but it sits between the containers.

post: This dog obviously touched many, many hearts.

If the sitter is staying in your house then more time is devoted to your dog. More time will of course cost more.   
When a sitter takes a dog into his/her house the dog slots in with the sitter's family and routine. The sitter is doing his/her normal housework, running errands, caring for his/her own family and pets in addition to yours. In this situation fewer hours a day are devoted exclusively to your dog.    
When the sitter moves into your home obviously the sitter does not do any of the above - the sitter's time is exclusively devoted to your dog.   
The CHF 200 per day average is generally figured on an assumed 8 hours spent actually working with your dog at CHF 25 per hour - the same wage you would pay a babysitter or other household worker. But you are getting a bargain - the sitter is there to care for your dog throughout the full day just as you would. Yes, he/she is sleeping overnight, you would have negotiated how much personal time the sitter would have away from the house during that time, and a good deal of the time at your home is spent doing one's own thing around the house - but 200 per day is actually a very good deal.   
(I know of one sitter who charges CHF 600 per day - that is, 25 per hour for a 24 hour day.)   
But either at your home or the sitter's, while one is not 'working' that is, interacting with your dog the full time, nonetheless the sitter takes on what is in effect 24/7 responsibility, just as the owner would. If a crisis occurs in the middle of the night, one needs a sitter who is both willing and able to respond. That responsibility is actually what you are paying for.   
My sitter and I have been through two of the awful 'what if' situations. One anticipated and thus discussed and decision-making planned for, the other completely out of the blue. Every sitter and owner need to anticipate these terrible possibilities - and what you pay your sitter reflects the willingness and ability to take on this responsibility.     
It should be stressed, though - if you are paying the sitter then under the TSchV the sitter needs to have done at a minimum both the SKN courses - the same courses that any owner has to do. A sitter takes on owner responsibilities, so it makes sense that the same legalities apply. I know that many people consider themselves as sitting 'casually' rather than professionally but still want to be paid - one needs to understand that it is payment that triggers the education requirements.   
It is only the case of sitting as a favor, not for money, where the education requirements do not apply.   
I've said this before but it bears repeating:   
If you find an otherwise promising sitter who has not yet done the SKN courses, why not sponser that person for the course, have him/her do it with your dog while sitting for you? Win-win all around.

I think the best way I can explain what I meant by my original statement that   is to use my own son and dog as an example. When a stranger comes to my house for the first time, my son may or may not like the person but he will be polite, say hello and shake hands. With my dog, I don't know how he's going to react. He will either love the guy or hate him. Some people he jumps all over like he's known them forever while others might get barked at or sniffed suspiciously.   
Sure my dog is predictable in some situations, like when I put his food out, I know he's going to eat it.   But she does not exhibit human-like behavior and we can't expect her to. She's a dog. A full part of our family, like a kid to us but still a dog in behavior.

The 'Crate' thread reminded me, so an FYI to Ruffwear fans:   
Ruffwear has introduced two new harness styles, the Front Range harness for everyday use (much lighter than the Webmaster, a good choice when the walk doesn't involve climbing a mountain) and the Load Up, to be used as a car restraint attached to a seat belt (not for walking!) in situations where a travel crate is not possible.       
Because I sometimes have to transport dogs unexpectedly I keep a set of the Load Up harnesses in the car - these have been a godsend.   
All the Muttley Crew wear Ruffwear harnesses of one type or another - in fact, Hooligan's original Webmaster is going on 9 years old now, still in pristine condition. Given that she's a rough-and-tumble kind o' gal, that's saying something. Love Ruffwear products.   
The new styles might not be in stock in most Swiss stores - but Meiko (and possibly other retailers) can order one for you.

post:
Something folks might not know:   
Private persons may list an animal in need of a new home on the Tierdatenbank, it's not exclusively for use by rescue organizations.   
There are conditions, though - for private persons, the animal must be born in Switzerland, have a valid vac and be chipped. This is to prevent dubious folks trafficking animals into Switzerland from using the system.   
A private person cannot use the online Meldung, it has to be written. The form is here:     
The Tierdatenbank is the best place to reach serious animal lovers in Switzerland.     
---   
Years ago the Free Ads were 'the' way to reach the public; unfortunately they have become so infested with dodgy and unscrupulous ads that many serious animal lovers avoid them. Thus there are better tools available to reach the kind of people one wants when in need of rehoming.

post:
The first is the Coop site. Both require a paid subscription to get a sitter's details.    
(Be aware that it is the responsibility of the dog owner to determine that a carer is compliant with the education requirements under the TSchV.)     
Another site that isn't specifically for pet care but has provided useful contacts for many folks is Rent-A-Rentner, a platform tor retired folks who wish to work a bit:         
ETA:   
And of course you could always post an ad on the EF market place. But the same caveat as to dog care requirements applies - be sure that the person you hire is compliant.

If your dog is registered with ANIS, you will receive a confirmation letter from them with your account and pin numbers. (My recent mutt was registered on 3 January, I just received the confirmation letter today, FWIW.)   
If you don't have this letter, call ANIS (  ) give them the chip number, and ask the status of your dog's registration. They are very helpful folks and will advise you what to do next.   
It would be odd that the transport company did the ANIS registration - first time registration is supposed to be done by a vet. But who knows, we've seen all sorts...   
If in doubt, if you have further problems, see your vet, he/she will take care of the bureaucracy for you. (Cost of ANIS registration is 20-40, usually rolled into an initial consultation visit - total usually under 100.) You'll want to get to know a vet anyway, an introductory visit is always recommended.   
Don't stress about the 10 day thing -  just follow up on the registration both, ANIS and at the Gemeinde/Polizei. And make sure you understand which training classes (federal, cantonal) you are required to do.   
And enjoy your Swiss adventure  - always more fun shared with a four footed friend!     
ETA:   
If you don't yet have a passport, your vet will give you one. There is a new format from 1 Jan 2015, do make sure you get the new version.

post:
Part of what makes a reputable breeder is the extensive health and genetic testing done on the parent dogs to determine if each is fit to breed and then if the pair is a good match - this will significantly add to the cost of breeding.  From the little I know of the SKG world, in the two breeds I see most often Swiss breed clubs do seem - at least on paper - to take these issues more seriously, with more oversight, than, say, what I have seen in the rescue fall-out from breeders in the US.   
(Bearing in mind that this is not my world - I generally only come into contact with breeders via rescue work. But from that perspective, I respect many of the breeders I have met in Switzerland and Germany.)   
Add in all the rest of what a good breeder does - necessary accomodation (you can guess how much a property with sufficient land costs in Switzerland), a solid socialization program, health testing and care of puppies, etc., - and you will of course see higher prices.    
There is a lot more to rearing healthy puppies of sound temperament than just vaccinating. Look at the retriever.ch site to read up on the various genetic health issues of the breed. A good breeder plans a pairing with genetic health in mind - and the tests involved are expensive.   
----       
The reputable breeders I know don't actually make much money from breeding - most cover their costs. Good breeders generally do it out of love for the dogs.   
It's the battery farmers, who do none of the necessary health testing, who do no socialization, who toss any two dogs together with no thought for genetics, who breed a dog every season until it drops dead, whose dogs live in misery in small cages their entire lives, whose pups are often ill with parvo, with respiratory infections, with inherited conditions - these are the folks cashing in.   
These folks need to be stopped. And the only way to stop them is to educate people to buy only from a reputable breeder.  Stop supporting the barstewards who are ruining our dogs.   
---     
Bottom line, though - the purchase price or adoption fee is but a drop in the bucket. Dog ownership is expensive - especially in Switzerland.

Animal welfare - of pets, wildlife, and livestock, is regulated under the TSchV and TSchG. These includes not only minimum accomodation standards for pets but also care and handling requirements.   
You can start by perusing the BLV's pet owner website, Mein Heimtier:     
And also the Wegweiser linked above.   
Have a read through Mein Heimtier - and then taking the Swiss perspective (and requirements) into account think about which animal would make a good pet for you.   
Good luck!

post:
Here is a link to a website that allows you to find a veterinarian anywhere in Switzerland.        
Of course, it is always good to know if someone else has used that vet and what their experiences were.    
I have found that veterinary practices here can vary quite a bit, depending on how many doctors there are, and whether the practice is located in a village, town or city. What does seem to be standard in our experience is that most do not have a lab on site for analysis and sending blood or urine samples out for testing is quite expensive. Not only that, but waiting for results can be really frustrating. There is one lab called Diavet that is used exclusively by vets. Then there is another lab called Medica which is not just for animals but humans and I find the results with this lab are much faster.    
We actually use the services of two different veterinarians. The one we used before we moved I still use exclusively for injections as they give us a discount for having 3 dogs  . But the local vet is just 5 minutes away from our home which is a big advantage. She also had a Basset as her patient for years until he recently passed on. Bassets are not very common here and they have some problems unique to their breed so it is good to have a vet who has some experience with one. I am considering asking about the price of injections as it could be that she will not charge us for an "examination" as the other vet does when I take them for injections. It is not as though the dogs are examined at all - the vet just asks me if they are sick or not .   
Hope all worked out well for you and your cat.

Orion,    
There are not that many breeders in Switzerland, and therefore not many puppies. Which is a good thing, for the welfare of the animals.   
You see, good breeders do not plan a litter until they have enough interest expressed from potential buyers in order to ensure that there are homes ready for their puppies. Most breeders will have waiting lists, some a year or more in advance.   
If one wants a puppy of a certain breed, one needs to first establish a relationship with the breeders.  Generally, you need to contact each breeder, introduce yourself, explain who you are, what kind of home you can offer their pup, etc. If you meet the breeder's criteria you would then meet him/her and the dogs. If the 'interview' is successful - that is, if you have convinced the breeder that you can offer a good forever home to one of his/her pups, you would then be invited to join the waiting list for the next (or a subsequent) litter.    
The process of developing a relationship with a breeder is in the best interest of the pups - which is what all good owners want.   
It is not often that a breeder has a pup to offer a last minute buyer, but sometimes it happens - for instance when a buyer already on the waiting list drops out.   
---   
The reason that we stress the 'proper' way to find one's puppy is that the breeders out there who advertise pups ready immediately are often battery farms/puppy mills. Often these dogs are bred in abusive conditions, no thought to genetic health or suitability, the pups sick, poorly socialized, mentally damaged - and if found in Switzerland often illegally imported. Sadly, small fluffy dogs - including the Maltese - are the breeds most often subjected to this horrific trade. Battery farming of puppies is vile - please do not support these criminals and animal abusers.    
Fortunately, the new revision to the EU passport scheme , in force as of 1 Jan 2015, has stricter measures put into place to help combat these barstewards.   
---   
So - plan for as long a search as necessary to develop a relationship with a good breeder. A dog will be with you 15+ years - waiting some months or a year is nothing in the long run.   
To start your search, look for the breed club of the SKG  - in Switzerland that is the Zwerghundclub:     
For more discussion on the process of finding a puppy from a Swiss breeder, see these threads:           
---   
And just because rescue is my thing - as a possible alternative, and if you are in a position to offer a rescue dog the right kind of home, from time to time take a gander at the Tierdatenbank, the database of homeless animals here in Switzerland:     
While there are currently no Maltesers in need of a home, I have seen some listed on this database, a few recently. Yes, purebred dogs do indeed land in shelters or in search of new homes. It might be worthwhile to also keep an eye on the database as you continue your search.    
---   
And of course  - because the ins and outs of the TSchV is also my thing - if you are a first time dog owner in Switzerland, have you done the SKN Theory course, or if not a first time owner but new to Switzerland have you contacted the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt for a ruling on whether you must take it or not?    
If you fall into the category of those required by federal law to take the course, good breeders will want to see your SKN certificate before inviting you onto the waiting list. If you are required to take it but haven't yet, this might be why your search is stalled. In which case, you'd be well advised to make the course a priority.   
---   
Anyway, all the best to you and your future four-footed friend.
Poor old thing! Does she have to be crated? Hope you find someone soon. Must be stressful for you all! X

This part of my profile relates to my employability in Switzerland, I am totally unemployable in Switzerland because I don't speak German and I am non eu. I am not unemployable in the UK, I was a police officer until 10 days ago, a job I loved and was good at and resigned from to accompany my family on a life changing experience to Switzerland.    
This site I'm sure was started to help and encourage, not to make people feel like crap for making a massive life change to become an expat, spend a bit more time being nice to people instead of assuming the worst.   
You've made me feel like crap for wanting to make my time inswitzerland as fulfilling as possible while I'm over there. Finding a breeder takes months, I know because I did it for the last year in the UK.  
Go back to when you were first an expat and ask yourself if the way you answered my question on this post was the most appropriate for a newcomer.    
Thanks again for making me feel like absolute rubbish on what is a massive emotional and life changing personal situation.

Whatever the Swiss dog rules are they don't seem apply to all.    
Last summer my friend went for a walk near her house (she was 5 months pregnant), she was attacked by a large dog while the two owners stayed 50 meters away watching it. The dog jumped on her, ripped through her jackets and pants with his teeth and bit into her wrist while she was trying to protect her face.    
Finally the man yelled in Swiss German blaming her that she was the one that clearly provoked the dog by looking into his eyes. She was very shaken and wanted nothing to do with them at that very moment so she rushed home without taking their details.    
As she lived in a small town, it turned out that they lived a few houses down from her. Police was notified and the owner was called by the police, which he lied to saying that he had nothing to do with it.    
However the same day the owner went down to the Gemeinde and registered the two dogs, as we later found out he only had one dog registered and the other two officially never existed even thou he lived with them for two years in that apartment.    
Finally it came down to a confrontation a week later in a parking lot, she recognized him and approached him, he admitted that it was him but she couldn't prove it, at that very moment another friend of hers walked behind him and heard the entire conversation. He realized that there now was a witness and started screaming at her, threatening her.  His exact words were; you f...ed me and I will f... you back.   
At the end of a long police interview, she was told that unfortunately they couldn't do anything unless the dog attacks again.     
The police was presented with photos of the ripped clothes and body bruises and they believed here, but supposedly there is a two strikes rule in this country.   
As yes the laws here clearly state that dogs should not be without a leash but not everyone follows them.

post: I would also add that if you go googling for the SKN course you may find people advertising the ability to do the theory part online in English.  Please note that these courses are not recognised by the Swiss Vet Office and you would have to take it again.  So look for an English speaking instructor who can do both the theory and practical course with you in person.  The only online course which is approved is the one by Wolf Zemp which is in German.  Of course if you speak German then you can do the theory part via his website.

Thanks for that. I'll give them a go. Seraquin isn't either so I guess I can order that from UK too. Just Milbemax to find then - which is prescription only - but 2 out of 3 isn't bad.

Last thing anyone wants is you panicking and being afraid of NOW doing what is right. But I'm afraid your previous thread seems to indicate your dog arrived around March- but even if September- as many posters confirmed on that previous thread- you had to, by Law, register your dog within 10 days of arrival with your Gemeinde/Commune, pay the fee for the whole year, register with Anibis- and perhaps do the SKN course.   
There is huge concern at the moment with dogs not being properly imported- due to the possibility of being infected with all sort, and also due to the possibility of them coming from dreadful puppyfarms, with defects, illness and weakness and behavioural problems, lack of socialisation and much too young- due to the way they are kept in the first few weeks of life, to mothers that are forced to produce litter after litter in the most appalling circumstances. Poorly socialised dogs are often scared, and will tend to bite when 'threatened' by noisy and boisterous children- and then abandonned in a shelter!   
A long article about this in the current 'Terre et Nature' magazine- with an estimation of of 100s of illegal dogs being bought just this year in Romandie alone- mainly chihuhahas and other small breeds- many who die within days or weeks of being bought. The importing gangs have no conscience- and often use relatives or friends living here as intermediaries- very happy to make 'easy' money.   
Vets are being asked to keep a very sharp eye on this- and to report any owner they suspect from illegal import. The article finishes by saying that, even if the buyer buy in good faith- they can still be fined for not doing the necessary checks- picking upa dog from a car-park or at the border- without visiting the breeder and seeing at least the mother with the puppies- to pay a cheaper price. They can still be fined 1000s of francs for importing without due care.   
Of course, this does not apply to you- but as I just read the article today, I thought it was a good idea to share.   
So, don't panic- it is too late now. But- get your dog properly checked, vaccinated and recorded in passport, and anibis +Gemeinde registered. The last thing any vets wants to do is get an owner- and therefore a dog (it can be quarantined or even euthanazed in case of doubt) - but they will do if they are concerned. Keep a VERY close eye on the vaccination date, as if you go over 1 year, it may cause real problems. We were 2 days late for our dog's booster, and the vet changed the date on the passport, but only because a/ he knew the dog well and b/ he knew us well as we have used him for many years with other pets.

Swiss animal protection law already forbids 'Qualzucht', abusive breeding practices, but the current definitions are vague. The BLV has now revised the legislation adding definitions and specifically forbidding certain practices. The revision is set to enter into force on 1 Jan 2015.   
The provisional text:     
And an article by TIR:     
I am especially thrilled to see that  the proposal forbids breeding animals where due to the pairing it cannot be ruled out that the offspring would suffer loss of one of the senses, such as deafness or blindness, or that due to anatomy the animal would have difficulty in giving birth.   
This addresses double merle breeding (collies, shelties, aussies,  etc.) as well as other breeds  such as danes and dalmations, where known problematic genetic combinations can result in deafness or blindness. It also addresses breeding animals whose heads are so large that cesarean sections rather than natural births have become the norm (some of the bulldogs). The revision also addresses many health issues and extreme conformation problems.   
Additionally, the proposal explicitly forbids breeding toy dogs whose expected weight is less than 1500g - the so-called tea-cup trend.   
It also forbids breeding cats with shortened forelegs, the so-called kangaroo-cats. The legislation applies to all breeding, not just cats and dogs.   
Tables 1 and 2 following the text list specific 'Qualzucht' issues.       
TIR is pleased to see these proposals, but one objection they make is that the proposal sets up a control system that would rely on private persons. TIR is concerned that would allow for vested interest groups to water down the enforcement and would like to see control fall under the aegis of the BLV or the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt.     
But this is a huge step in the right direction.   
.

We have had our share of lumps and bumps. In the early days when I found one it was alarming.    
Veterinarians have different ways of treating lumps. Some aspirate them, or try, examine them carefully and then decide to send them to a lab. Anaesthetic has never been used for this. It seems that a pet can develop multiple lumps which are all the same type.    
The ones we have removed were when the dogs were younger, and a general anaesthetic was used. It is also possible to use a topical anaesthetic if the dog can be kept still for the procedure.   
As the dogs age only the lumps which interfere with mobility have been removed.    
I second the idea of getting a second opinion particularly if your dog has has major surgery and you want to avoid invasive treatment if possible.

Heksita, if the puppy is one of the 'kleinwÃ¼chsige' breeds, then you only need to follow the federal SKN rules, which for you will be the SKN practical course as you are not a first time dog owners.   
If your dog's breed falls into the List 1 (large and massive - 45cm or 15 kg adult size) category, then you need to take the additional ZÃ¼rich courses, which do indeed include a puppy course, a juvenile course, and an adult course.    
See the breed list here to determine which category the dog will fall into:     
(Mixes, if the puppy is too young to guess at final adult size, usually fall into the largest of the dogs' parents, or go by common sense   )   
More information on the ZH law can be found here:             
Be aware that the ZH Kantonsrat has just this week voted a revision into the ZH law making the ZH course requirement applicable only to the first List 1 dog you own, not to each one. However, this is not yet law, it is expected that the transition period could be 3 years. So for now the current regs stand.   
(I'm glad to hear that you are thinking of getting another dog, and wish you all the best.)

Cath, there are a few vets whose practice model is a house visit. Googling 'Tierarzt Hausbesuch' comes up with these, for instance:         
If you are not mobile, perhaps something like this might be a solution? I would guess, however, that these practices function as others do, that is, normal visiting hours. Whether one can call on them in a middle-of-the-night emergency is something that one would need to discuss after becoming a patient of the practice.   
Also, some vets in traditional set-ups also offer house visits to their established patients if one lives within a certain radius of the practice. (There might be an extra charge for the service, and whether it can be done out of hours/on an emergency basis needs to be discussed with the vet.)   
It should be born in mind, though, there may be a limit to what can be done in a house visit. For many emergencies, one often needs the equipment available only at a practice or hospital.       
But something to look into if you do not have your own transportation.

I agree with lmerkel - do try to find someone who can stay in your home and care for your dog.    
My dogs each still carry some of the baggage of their past lives so I truly understand your predicament. To give my guys the environment they need I need to keep their lives as free of stress as possible, which makes finding care difficult here. Given their characters and medical issues, none of the kennels I have investigated in Switzerland can provide the level of care needed. So I have a sitter who moves into our home to care for my dogs while I am gone.   
My sitter no longer takes on new clients - but perhaps you can find someone here on EF who would be willing to care for your dog. Yes, the average fee a live-in sitter charges is high, but well worth it when you have a dog with 'special needs'. (Be aware of the SKN requirements.)   
Given that 1 Nov is tomorrow, and a holiday in Switzerland to boot - do you really have to go? Is there any way to delay your trip until you have found appropriate care? Or, is there any way to take your dog with you?   
If not, put an ad in the market place section, giving full details (including what breed/mix/size your dog is, whether she is spayed or not, if your dog can live with other dogs, cats, children) and the price you are willing to pay (as this will generate more interest). Perhaps someone will respond. Alternatively, look at the usual pet sitter sites   or   . Or perhaps even  , the platform for retired folks who want a bit of work here and there.   
These are only short term solutions - long term, as lmerkel has said, working on your dog's adjustment issues will be key. Towards that end, if you tell us a bit about how you manage your dog day to day, what kind of training you have done in the past and ongoing, describe her issues in a bit more detail, perhaps we can help with some suggestions. However, that likely should be another thread, as cluttering up this one won't help you find a sitter quickly.     
----   
FYI, there is one Tierheim I would trust to care for my dogs. It's not in Switzerland, but in Germany, 83233 Bernau. I think it would be about 3 hours from Schaffhausen, maybe less. But again, it's a bit late for tomorrow - nonetheless you might want to keep them in mind for the future, visit (without your dog) to see if it might be a good fit, if so then schedule a trial stay. They have a good reputation in the rescue community.           
Hope you find a solution for tomorrow...     
Also, you might want to ask a mod to change your title, as 'dog assistance Schaffhausen' really doesn't say what you need or emphasize the urgency. Something like 'URGENT - dog sitter needed 1 Nov Schaffhausen' might garner more views.

My family here also have outdoor cats, two of them.   
They got a really big wooden box (grandson made it) lined it with thick insulation sheets, put it on a low shelf in the bicycle shed, hung a thick old carpet piece over the entrance (to stop wind blowing in) and put their padded ordinary cat beds inside.  The cats love it.   
Although now and again they change to sleeping curled up in some old water barrels under the eaves outdoors that have straw inside (depending on the weather) - they can peep over the tops to keep control over the territory.

Heksita, have you tried the Tierrettungsdienst and/or Tierheim PfÃ¶tli?     
It's true that there is less need for volunteers in Switzerland than in other countries. This is perhaps due to smaller shelters, perhaps also the trend towards using professional staff rather than volunteers. Additionally some of the animal care diploma courses require a student to do a Prakticum at a Tierheim so often students get the first pick at volunteer opportunities.   
(A bit frustrating when you are passionate about animal welfare, have the time, and would like to do a bit of good to find that the only thing welcome is your money.)   
But there are still shelters needing dog walking, and a few needing help in other areas - just keep asking around, perhaps at shelters in other cantons as well. Or consider volunteering in France or Germany - which is what I do.   
Another thing to consider is offering to help your local senior services group. Often elderly dog owners could use a helping hand - walking the dog on bad weather days, delivering heavy dog food packages, driving an elderly owner and dog to the vet, offering to care for a dog if the owner has to suddenly go into hospital. These can make all the difference in helping an elderly person to keep his/her canine companion. Most Gemeinde have some sort of senior services; while few would have any sort of official pet volunteer coordination you could write and offer your help on an ad hoc basis. Nothing ventured, nothing gained.   
Good luck!

You are doing the right thing carrying a slip lead, treats to lure him... Can you call on friends to help? The more people on the lookout prepared to help the better.   
Theoretically there cannot be a stray in Switzerland as all dogs should be chipped... But the reality is there may still be a few unchipped dogs, or dogs who are chipped but the owner has not updated the contact details. Nonetheless, once you catch the dog first priority should be to have him scanned.    
Any vet will scan the dog, this should be free of charge for the finder of a lost animal. If it is after hours and there isn't a 24/7 emergency clinic in the area just call any vet practice, most will have an after-hours cover group.    
Around my area police do not have holding kennels, but larger stations should have a scanner,. This is usually my second port of call, I prefer to enlist the help of a vet rather than the police as vets tend to be more sympathetic.    
Once scanned, the vet will file a report with ANIS... And if the police do the scanning, I'd recommend calling yourself as well, just to make sure the report got done. (Often stray animals are not a priority for the police) ANIS will contact the owner.   
Now to the legalities, once you have caught the dog:   
A finder is required to file a report to the cantonal Meldstelle, for all found animals. There are two online reporting sites that will fulfil this obligation:       .   
look under 'gefundene Tiere' (can't link on the iPad, sorry)   
Or call the cantonal Meldstelle directly.   
Just an FYI, the waiting period before a found animal can be rehomed is 60 days, starting from the date the finder report is filed.   
If you wish to keep a found dog at your home during the waiting period you need permission from the cantonal Meldstelle. But be aware that if a finder chooses to keep the dog during this period the expenses in such a case are born by the finder. (If an owner is found you can ask the owner to refund your expenses, but the owner is not obliged to do so.)   
If you can't keep a found animal with you, find out from the cantonal Meldstelle who the official cantonal Tierheim is, this is the shelter obliged to take the animal. Other Tierheim might charge you for the animal's care, as they are not obliged to take in strays. (But some are willing to help nonetheless.)   
Here's hoping this dog can be caught, and helped back to his owner... Or helped, full stop, if it turns out that the owner doesn't deserve him.   
Good for you for caring and trying to help.

post:
We've been here for a year now. We had to wait 2 months to bring our baby over due to the fact that we lived in what is classified as a "high rabies risk" country. It was never in my mind even an option to leave her in South Africa, she is my baby, she has been since the moment I looked after her for a week before adopting her.   
I agree with Meloncollie, a dog is a responsibility for 15+ years. Getting a dog is a decision people take far too lightly (and that, combined with backyard breeders, are the main reasons why there are millions of dogs in shelters around the world). But you made the decision and commitment to get this puppy (granted, without the prior knowledge of a possible move to CH), and now you need to do what you can with the decision you've made.   
Switzerland is an absolutely amazing country for dogs. Honestly, I think this is heaven on earth for them. Most restaurants and hotels have no issues with dogs, they even bring Peanut a bowl of water when we're at a restaurant with her. Your options for dog care are plentiful, as are dog walkers and so forth. I am incredibly happy that we jumped through all the hoops to have her here. Yes, there is legislation, and yes, it is obviously more challenging to have a dog here than to not have one here. But the advantages far outweigh the negatives in my opinion.   
Having said all of this, it sounds to me like you have made up your mind and you are looking for people to support the decision you made. From your responses I get the feeling that this puppy will be a burden to you. And in that case, I feel that a loving home in the States would be a better option for him.   
But please, if you cannot find him a home, and the last option is a shelter in the US, please bring him with you. I cannot even bring myself to imagine the trauma he would go through if he had to return to the shelter.

We have two cats, one a 4 month old kitten that we adopted from a shelter a month ago in Bern. We live on the 3rd floor in the city, right next to tram tracks so our cats are strictly indoor. Our balcony is completely netted in - a balcony is not cat proof unless there is no earthly way that the cat can get out! Many cats have fallen from balconies, and I suspect that any shelter in CH will require your balcony to be secured with net if you're on the 4th floor.   
The shelter we adopted from didn't visit our apartment, in stead they requested our address to check where we live, on what floor and what we could offer the kitten. We discussed the fact that our balcony was "cat-proof", they wanted pictures of it etc. To them it was important that 1.) they would be 2 kitties and 2.) there was a safe way for the cat to be outside (cat proof balcony or normal access to outdoors). It should be possible for you to find a shelter that is willing to let you take a couple as indoor only, but I don't think you'll get around the cat net.   
Good luck and thanks for adopting shelter cats!!! There are so many cats in need of good homes.

meloncollie and other posters are right, the problem of stray cats is a huge one in Switzerland. When I helped the stray cat (described earlier in the thread) I was calling around organizations to figure out how to possible get help with the vet bill and find a home for him. Only then did I gain insight into how enormous this problem is. Simply put, it pisses me off that intelligent animals like cats are left to their own devices like this. I spoke to a very nice woman at a larger organization that focuses on TNR (trap, neuter, release) and she said that most people in CH downright refuse to believe this is an actual problem. The popular view here seems to be that cats have a right to roam freely (if you neuter and vaccinate I'm ok with outdoor cats), have kittens at least once and if they are strays or ferals, hey, that's just in their nature!    
It's a paradox that cats are such valued companions, yet they're second class pets compared to dogs. Having had both, there is no difference in the bond and responsibility that goes into having a cat vs a dog. Cats should have more legal "rights" to protect them, like mandatory chipping for starters. But I could go on like thisÂ   Anyways, OP, adult shelter cats make for wonderful, grateful pets.

I have had my horse for over 20 years, and now she is 32 years old.  Last summer 2013 my husband and I brought her to Switzerland after months of serious thought, planning, organization, and regular vet checks to see if there would be any health issues besides her age that we would need to take into consideration.  Now here in the pasture just outside of our apartment she is very happy, healthy and getting lots of attention. Seeing her happy here made all the work and personal sacrifice to cover the expense worth it.   
The process was greatly simplified by our shipping company, Equiflight, run by Katie Forest, who personally walked us through the entire process, step-by-step. I highly recommend her.  She is great to work with and was very patient to explain everything and answer our never-ending questions. Our horse was quarantined at her facility, and I felt so much better knowing that she was not just some agent, but that she was personally overseeing the care, quarantine, transportation, etc. of my horse.  Yes it was expensive, but not as much as I had imagined it would be.  It just depends on how important it is to you.   
I would be glad to explain the process in detail if it would be helpful to someone in a similar situation, but with regulations constantly changing, it may be even more helpful to contact Katie Forest directly.  I wish you and your equine friend the best!

I will share with you what our vet said to us recently (our dogs are 13, 11 and 9). Referring mainly to the eldest dog, she said that "at this age, each day is a gift."   
Not much more I can add here as MC, our resident expert, has said it all, in her usual eloquent fashion. Except that our dogs eat grass when their stomachs are upset, this seems to cause them to puke and they feel better afterwards. But it is just grass, not dirt. Occasionally one dog will dig in the dirt if there is something very interesting under it. (once she found a bone buried in the garden.)   
Our eldest dog is almost 14, and she is taking Karsivan. She had back surgery a few years ago, and her problem now is the one of back legs is weak, so she is a bit wobbly. But she is not in pain. Karsivan is supposed to improve the circulation and improve the quality of life. (I have been wondering if humans can take it.  )   
Our youngest dog, who is almost 10, has severe arthritis in one of her back legs. The vet has prescribed Cosequin capsules but this dog has such a sensitive stomach that we are not sure if this is the right treatment. Arthri dog might then be an option.    
I think you have to trust you vet and your own instincts. Last week I met someone who has a dog going on 19!

Here is a summary of the Solothurn cantonal dog law, from the Tier Im Recht website:     
For all dogs:   .    
There is a general on-lead requirement in the forest in May and June, and in other places so signed.   
For the BLS breeds (Bullterrier, Staffordshire Bull Terrier, American Staffordshire Terrier, American Pit Bull Terrier, Rottweiler, Dobermann, Dogo Argentino, Fila Brasileiro and all dogs crossed with these):        
Dogs of the listed breeds must always be on lead in public.    
---   
The actual text of the law is linked at the top of the TIR page.   
---   
There may be additional Gemeinde requirements, ask at Einwohnerkontrolle for specifics.

I, too, find the 'oodle' craze very disturbing, as by far the majority of these dogs are unregulated breeding by folks with no understanding of what they are doing - and many are battery farmed, byb'd, the dogs are simply used as commodities. All to fuel a demand from naive buyers who think they are getting a 'designer dog' when they are simply paying silly money for a mutt.   
(See my link above to Wally Conron's statement of regret at coining the 'oodle' name.)    
Nothing wrong with a mutt, as I have said many times. I love mutts, I love all dogs of any and every flavor. But why line the pockets of unethical producers who breed for all the wrong reasons?   
And remember - one cannot guarantee the genetic characteristics in crosses, especially early crosses. So if one wants a curly coated, non-shedding dog... why not get a poodle? If one wants a fluffy dog, why not get one of the many poodle crosses sitting in shelters, waiting for their forever home?   
And again, to repeat for those seeking 'oodles' because of allergies:   
If you have severe allergies, you must test the individual dog you are considering buying/adopting, full stop. No breed or crossing can   a dog that will not trigger your individual allergies. You will need samples of adult hair, saliva, dander. Get the test done with your doctor.    
---   
I have a foster dog here, a poodle. It's funny to watch people's reaction to him.   
Strangers oooh and ah over him, asking "Is he is a XYZ-oodle, isn't he gorgeous, what a lovely dog, what a delightful character, I want one just like him, where can I get one?    
When I say "He's a poodle" the next comment is usually "Oh,   a poodle? What a shame."   
Nowt so queer as folk.    
.

Not a license per se, but you are correct Lucy. Unlike what most of us are used to in our home countries, commercial (that is, paid) dog care is a regulated activity in Switzerland.    
A dog walker will need at a minimum to have done the SKN theory and practical courses. These are the same courses that all dog owners are required to do.   
(Have you recently acquired your dog, or recently moved to Switzerland, Croberts? If so, you need to do the course (or courses - this is the short version) yourself. Search for the term 'SKN' there are many threads explaining this requirement.)   
It only make sense that someone who is being paid to look after a dog be held to the same training standards as an owner.   
The requirement for the SKN courses applies to anyone caring for 5 or fewer dogs at a time. If one is caring for more than that, one needs more in-depth courses, the FBA or the Tierpfleger diploma, depending on what is offered. If caring for more than 5 dogs, the carer must be registered with the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt.   
---   
The above does not apply if the carer is not being paid. Friends may still do friends a favor.    
---   
It is the responsibility of the owner to ascertain that the dog carer is duly qualifed. Fines have been given out if a complaint is made and it is discovered that the carer is not in compliance.   
--- 
One should also ensure that a dog carer is duly insured against liability. Generally someone working in your home (which would include walking the dog) is covered under your Privathaftpflicht (in ZH and about half the cantons Privathaftpflicht/Liability insurance is mandatory for dog owners, the cover sum varies by canton), but one should check with one's insurance provider for the specifics of the policy. A carer who runs his/her own business, though, likely is not covered under your policy and would have to have his own liability insurance.     
Hope you find the person you need, Croberts.

I have now adopted two dogs since living in Switzerland and it has been a very rewarding experience.  It is not always easy though, so I can't recommend highly enough all the required courses plus investing in further courses to become acclimated with all things doggy and the responsibilities that owning a dog in Switzerland entails.  These will build you up to be a wonderful dog owner and accepted by other fellow dog friends and owners.  We adopted from two different shelters and it was no problem, as we did take the ownership seriously.  We now have two wonderful furry companions and have met some very nice Swiss people through our ventures.  It is every day "work" but very rewarding ! Start reading up now and find out where you can best do the courses near where you live.

Understood - when it's a case of he said/she said, sadly, there seems to all too often be a reluctance to investigate on the part of some authorities.   
I wonder:   
If he is providing dog care in his home, under the TSchV he should have the appropriate credentials - which would be either the SKN courses if he is caring for fewer than 5 dogs (not including his own dogs) at a time, or the FBA or Tierpfleger diplomas if caring for more.   
I do know of one case of a local lady who had been offering holiday care in her home for decades but had never taken the SKN or any other course. Then one day she received a complaint from neighbors over barking. When the police came to speak to her about the complaint, in the course of the conversation it came out that she was running a Hundehort without the proper credentials. She was told that she must stop her holiday care business until she had completed the appropriate course.   
But this was in SZ, so who knows if the same would happen elsewhere...   
If he has a diploma as a groomer, though, that might be sufficient to cover the Ausbildung requirement - I'm not up on how the various animal related education courses fit together. Again, TIR could advise.    
If he is not declaring the income that is an issue for the tax office - but I have no idea if they would take an interest, or not.    
Again, good luck following through.

I don't know if good and cheap go well together in this respect. The technique is rather easy to perform yourself, if you want as cheap as can be. All you need, as an outlay is a stripping knife. You can find them on google and they are not expensive. You can do it between your finger and thumb but with a bigger dog your hand will soon get sore. All you need to do is use the knife to "cut" but as something to hold the hair against as you pull it out in the direction the coat grows.    
Start at the neck and work down the back towards the tail, following the shape of the dog pull out the longer, bristle top coat, leaving the softer undercoat. It comes out rather easily. You just need to decide how you want the legs, chest and skirt. You can use scissors to blend this into the stripped part.    
Have a go! It can be funâ¦ 
Gal xx

My bushes have made similarly remarkable recoveries. Box is amazing robust and able to come back.   
The moths apparently all fly at more or less the same time, or at least within a very narrow window. They mate and then lay eggs on fresh box trees and then die within a few hours. They can smell box trees from miles away. So the spread of the moth or even its survival depends very much on what happens on these two or three nights. Heavy rain can prevent them from flying. Atmospheric conditions can prevent the odour of the box reaching them. If the flight of the moths coincides with increased bat activity, they also get decimated (bats love the box moths). So lots of factors can transpire to either decimate or help the next generation of caterpillars.
Glad to hear this came to a happy ending.

I am sure you must be relieved to hear this.    
Dog ownership in Switzerland is not how I imagined it would be when we moved back here from Asia with our dogs. It's not the dogs, but rather their owners. The farmer over the road from me just doesn't see the need to keep his dog away from the sidewalk and everyone who is walking by with dogs. Last week his dog ran across the road when he saw me with our dogs.   
Then there are others who walk dogs off leash yet their dogs do not stick by their side but instead approach us. Of course the owner will say, he does nothing.    
Basically my rule is to avoid all dogs I don't know. We are lucky as our dogs have each other as companions and play together. We have a very large fenced garden. I appreciate that dogs need to socialize and play with other dogs but my advice is to be very selective.    
I have seen posts here where dog owners are looking for other dog owners to arrange play dates, walks, etc. Maybe worth looking into?

You really cannot use the excuse that you do not wish your cat to be in pain as a reason for not neutering.    
If you prevent your cat from mating, the high levels of hormones raging will be driving him insane- emotional pain far worse than physical.  Also, this prolonged increase in hormonal levels and the stress that produces will eventually cause physical problems far worse than being sore for a day or two. Prolapses, cancers and other nasties will be awaiting in his older age. It's simply a no brainer not to have him done.   
Gal xx

Pixie, are you going to be in Switzerland for the expected lifetime of a hamster? If so, then by all means get another. But if not - or even if there is a small chance that you will leave within that timeframe - it would be best to wait until you know where your future is headed.   
If you know that you will be here for the duration, then why not adopt a homeless hamster?   
You'll find a list of homeless animals on the Switzerland-wide database here:       
For Tierart (type of animal), choose 'KleinsÃ¤uger' for a list of all the small mammals.    
A ZÃ¼rich area specialist rescue focusing on the small furries is the Nagerstation:     
These are good folks to speak to, especially for advice on issues relating to care of the species in Switzerland.

Threads like these, posts like this, really hit home for me. I've bemoaned my trials with my dog and my mother enough that some who have been around a while know my feelings and my story.   
I came with the expectation that it was temporary and I'd go back to my dog, with the ability to bring her with me when it was permanent. I left her with my mother who didn't see her as a family member the same way I did, so when she had something come up, she left her with my brother and his wife who REALLY don't see dogs as anything close to how I see my Harri. So, it is with a hard heart these years that I've resigned myself to the fact of Harri not being here with me.   
I've also resigned myself (unwillingly, and mostly, but not completely without hope) to the very probable fact that I won't have a dog while I'm here. I can not have faith that any dog I get here will be able to go with me if / when we move and with the other things that have happened here, I just can not go through leaving another beloved behind.     
Meanwhile, by now, having had the fortune to come to this thread after dalingling has had the chance to explain about her dogs, I can see it is obvious that she made the choice to leave her existing dogs back in the US for their own good, rather than for her convenience.      
Dalingling, there are many pet shelters within communities, as well as (I believe) "rescue" places who look after specific breeds of dog. Also, near the borders, it seems (sorry if is unfair to say) "particularly" the French and Italian borders, there are dogs in desperate need of adoption as those countries seem to have different (less favorable for the animal) animal rights and protection laws in place. You may find your forever friend within Switzerland, or maybe just across the border  .   
So, good luck in finding a new member of your family who will fit with you and you them.

post: So glad to see that your pussy cat's arrived safe and sound after their long trip! We moved from Melbourne 14 months ago, and brought our cat with us too. We used Jetpets who were fantastic. And like your two, she sprung out of the cage and was so lovely and happy! Not what we were expecting at all!     I'm not sure of your long term plans, but just a heads up for you if you are returning to Australia with your cats. It will take about 5-6 months preparation before you ship them back! So ensure you get started as soon as you know you will return, or alternatively just make sure you keep their rabies shots done annually (In Switzerland they only need to do every 3 years).      We have to return back to Australia unexpectedly, and now our cat will require 150 days in Quarantine in Australia! The key is that you have to have the blood test for the Rabies antibody done and then your pet has to wait 3 months before they can travel, so they still have a minimum of 30 days in Quarantine... Good old Australia quarantine! Anyhow, we were aware of the Quarantine requirements, but we were not expecting to have to return suddenly, so we just like to let people know if they are not aware!

post:
Travelling is freight is not as scary as it seems!   
My dog, a tiny puppy at the time, arrived in CH with us travelling as freight in a cargo plane.    
Animals go in a safe - pressurised and heated - part of the plane, and the handling conditions are very detailed and obey severe rules toward the wellfare of the animal. They can't stay on tarmac in heat/cold for instance, etc.   
There would be zero difference for your hamster to be in a cargo plane or in the hold/cabin of your own plane.

You are allowed to move to Valais with a dog on the list but  the owner and dog have to take a (very straightforward) personality test. I moved from Vaud and had no problems - the cantonal vet trusts another vet to make the decision. Considering I met someone last week with a Cane Corso  Italian mastiff (not on the Valais list but is on the Geneva one!) they are seemingly not as restrictive ....   
Annabelle[/QUOTE]   
The two cases that were mentioned in the 20 minutes article -one a Doberman and the other a Mastiff were NOT examined by the Cantonal Vet. But the owners were given the "get out" letter based on the breed being on the exclusion list. According to the article, there have been only 9 exceptions to the law. I am not sure where your dog fits in.   
According to the Vallis Cantonal Vet (translated from the article) "According to the legislation in effect, it is not possible to definitively import a breed of dog that is on the list for exclusion". Seems pretty clear to me.

One of the things with Harri's (Harriet) remains was that I'd always wanted her here with me. A lot of things happened that made it impossible, despite the fact that I'd done everything I could to prepare her to come with me when I moved here. Once I was here, she never was in the same place as me the few times I made it back to the US - until December a year (and some) ago, when it was too late for her to come, due to age and health.   
Harri and I both had been living with my mother (who has poor health) for a few years before I came, so leaving her there, in a place that was her home, was not a horrible thing for her - she knew my mother and they loved each other. If I knew my mother would always be in her current house, I'd have been happy for my mother to bury her in the yard, which was what she'd wished. Alas, she hates the house, would leave it if she could. I did not want Harri's remains to remain in the yard, to be dug up by whomever may buy the house next.   
So. I'd thought to have Harri's ashes with me, until a time I can decide the "perfect" place to release her - hopefully with my mother at my side, so we can do it together.     
I wish you the best with your daughter's dog. Hopefully things work better (without arguments and stress over details of end of life care) and easier for you and your family and the dog as time goes on.

Thanks guys for your replies.   
Merrylegs - of course she is, they all are in the eyes of their owners. They are the best breed if you ask me.   
TiMow - Fribourg could have been possible, but it sounds like you have enough on your hands now.

Well, I was about to direct you to shopping across the border when I checked current prices... and was surprised to find a bargain in Switzerland.   
Just pulling one example out of the hat, Orijen, one of the premium high meat content grain-free foods, is CHF 105 for a 13kg bag from Editrust in Switzerland. From Zooplus.de, a german supplier, Orijen costs 89 Euros for the same sized bag. That's slightly less expensive in Hochpreisinsel Schweiz - well knock me down with a feather!   
I guess I'll have to double check my assumptions more often.    
I feed Magnusson, Lily's Kitchen, occasionally Orijen to one of mine, and Terra Canis wet food. (The last is indeed quite a bit less expensive in Germany - likely because it is a German product, whereas the Orijen is shipped from Canada to both countries.) I figure on spending around CHF 100-120 per 13-15 kilo bags, obviously more per kilo if I buy in smaller quantities. The most expensive I've come across is Ziwipeak which is CHF 114 per 5 kilos ( ) but because it's an air-dried meat product 5 kilos goes a very long way - it works out to be not much more than normal premium prices.    
So - you should have your choice of premium food in the CHF 7-9 per kg range.   
As to where to buy it - the two big chains are Fressnapf and Qualipet, but neither stock the better known premium brands, although both carry own brands. (Not sure about grain free, though...)    
Meiko ( ) carries Magnusson as well as some other brands, Editrust ( ) carries Orijen, Arcana, and similar, Goldenway ( ) -  I think all deliver Switzerland-wide. I'm not familiar with retailers in the Romandie, hopefully someone from that side of the country will post soon. There are other independent retailers carrying specific premium brands - write the manufacture to find a distributor in Switzerland, or post here for suggestions. You can also order from Zooplus' french site ( ) for delivery into Switzerland.

post: Oh wow, not the rabbits, but those other links to the Dog Whisperer - amazing stuff.  I just sat entranced watching how that guy re-trained agressive dogs.

Hi I just flew with my dog to the States in Nov (for a long holiday) and back to Zurich in Jan.  She was also in-cabin with me and honestly, no one knew I had her with me the entire time!  <<Bother to the US and back to Switzerland.  I had to keep offering the fact that I had a dog in my bag...  and hey, here dont you want to check my paperwork!   
Checking in at the airport.. I showed her EU Pet Passport and a health certification I got from her vet within 10 days of the flight.  They weighed her and the bag to make sure we were under the limit.  And, confirmed payment for her.   
Walked through security and screening - no one cares about her papers.   
Walked onto the plane - no one ever asks about her papers again.  I have boarded a plane three times w her and never once did anyone ask.  But they might not have noticed her in the carrier either.   
Going through customs in Washington Dulles - no one asks about her papers.  In fact, I carried her in my arms as customs officials ask how my trip was etc.   
It was a similar experience on the way back from USA > Switzerland.  I just had to go to USDA to get extra certification on her health certificate which again no one bothered to ask me for.  I offered the documentation that was so painful to get.  (A three hour drive to the closest APHIS office in Richmond VA and another three hours back home... days before my flight!)   
Hope this helps.  Feel free to let me know if you have any other questions.   
PS - A great tip is to let a (friendly) flight attendent know you have the pup w you.  I did this on the way home, and the attendent gave me a whole row to myself since there was room!  He and some of the other lady attendents kept asking if the pup was ok.  He even told me if it werent for some of the snotty attendents (hehe his words!) and probably air safetly regulations - he would let me hold her out of the bag.  They helped me to the biggest bathrooms on the plane for me to bring pup in w her potty pads to do her business and stretch.  We had a great experience!   
Best of luck w yours!!

Heads up for dog owners in Spreitenbach AG:   
Four dogs have died in the Spreitenbach area. There is a suspicion of poisoning, but it must be stressed that poison has not yet been established as the cause of death:       
Remembering the Honng case of a few years ago, where early suspicions of malicious poisoning turned out to be toxicity due to fertilizer made from grape production, it would be wise not to panic.    
But it would also be prudent to take steps to protect your dog if you walk in the area. Do not allow your dogs to eat anything on the ground, and as always,   At the first sign of symptoms (shaking, drooling, muscle weakness, respiratory distress, collapse) call your vet immediately.
