post:
IMO, the HHB  would be the easiest for a 'normal' pet dog to pass.      
It has a few elements similar to a WT, such as the 'Begegnungen mit auffÃ¤llig gekleideten Menschen' and 'Begegnung mit einem anderen Hund' that can be tricky for reactive or fearful dogs, though. Such exercises are more a test of the dog than the owner, which I see as a failing. It's the owner's skill in managing his dog in a given situation, as well as understanding of his responsibility, that needs to be assessed.   
BH1 is the next easiest, and IMO more fun for dogs who think like mine, but requires much more specific training than the HHB. BH is a sport - some of the exercises go well beyond 'normal' dog ownership. Here's a decent explanation:     
Obedience (GehorsamkeitsprÃ¼fung) skills are not that difficult to acquire, but to do these things to the standard required is.  The judging is so very technical (for instance, if the dog's nose breaks in front of the handler's knee during a heel points are lost...) that it's difficult for 'everyday pets' to pass - and not too many owners are motivated by this type of handling. IMO, there are other certifications that are more relevant to everyday pet life.   
Most of the other PrÃ¼fungen are specialized skills requiring significant training.   
---   
I still maintain that the best way to ensure public safety and promote responsible ownership is to require ongoing attendance at a Hundeschule - Familienhund classes, for instance - throughout a dog's life, rather than a one-shot PrÃ¼fung. Continual training keeps me on my toes, keeps me aware of my responsibilities, and makes me a better owner. And it's fun for my dogs.   
Are these tests relevant? Hmmm...    
Hooligan, who is very well trained, would have trouble even with the HHB if the stooge dog used was a GSD. (A GSD attacked and very badly injured her, leaving her reactive to the breed. We have worked on this for years, but some fear remains.) But understanding her reactivity, I am a responsible owner. Hooligan is on lead in public, and I do not allow her to get into situations where she might become fear reactive.    
Hooligan passed her HHB with flying colors, by the way, despite her reactivity. We got lucky on the test day and drew a stooge dog of another breed. But nonetheless, having the HHB certificate does not mean that the steps I need to take as a responsible owner in everyday life can be relaxed.

I read a study somewhere that the labs where associated to the most biting accidents, compared to other races.    
The study emphasised that it was not because labs are more aggressive than other dogs, but simply because they are the most populare breed. So the sheer number of them explains why there's more bites reported.

And just a note for those who are looking for a grain-free high-protein food but can't feed Orijen (my Hooligan can't have it due to the rosemary) Purizon from Zooplus is a pretty good alternative.   
Terra Canis is a good wet-food alternative as well - bio, fully disclosed sources, ethical production, grain free, from a small producer in Germany.   
Neither of these, however, fulfill the primary motivation for raw feeding. But since the discussion has strayed to non-raw, I just thought I'd throw this info out there.

post:
I believe that form is only for importing animals who do not meet import conditions.    
Is there any reason why your dog would not meet the standard import conditions? (Such as unable to be vac'd due to medical reasons, etc.)   
If your dog already has a pet passport with a valid rabies vac (and the waiting period has been observed if vac'd for the first time) you should be good to go.    
That your dog originally came from Canada is irrelevant. If he was legally imported into Germany and has lived with you in Germany he is 'German'.   
But as always, go directly to the source - call or write the BVet with questions. They will respond to mail in English.   
---     
LivingInSwiss, I am surprised that the person you spoke to at the BVet was so unhelpful. Hopefully you just got hold of a clueless telephone operator. I would suggest always writing to them - not only will the mail be forwarded to the responsible person who has the answers, but it's always good to have a paper trail.

Yes, incidents are on the rise. A sad sign of the times.   
I would recommend that all dog owners regularly train the 'leave' command - and better yet, regularly train your dogs never to eat food from the ground, never to accept food from another person. (Offering adulterated treats is also a favorite poisoning tactic.)    
Not an easy thing to do, especially when you have Hoover Hounds like mine. But worth working on.   
We often do 'ignore the sausage on the ground' exercises at our Hundeschule, in order to teach the dogs just that.     
Put the dog in the heel position or on short lead if necessary, walk by a plate with kibble on it - keep your dog's attention on you, offer an even better treat when he ignores what is on the ground. Repeat a million times, varying your speed, direction, left/right side heel, etc. Next try hiding the kibble in unexpected places as you walk by.  Once your dog can reliably ignore kibble on the ground do the same with a higher value treat, repeat. Continue in the same vein until what is on the ground is super high value (like a sausage).   
Do this on your own along your favorite walking trails and in your garden. The more you reinforce the fact that things on the ground must be left alone and that food only comes from you, the safer your dog will be.   
There is a special place in hell for those who harm animals...

Looking on one website at the ads in German for those looking for properties to rent, it is clear that many desperately searching for housing are pet owners. Some have many more pets than I can imagine any landlord wanting to accept. Some have very limited budgets.    
Looking for pet-friendly housing is about making compromises.  
As long as you are prepared to do that, you will find a property.    
Pet owners who are landlords understand that two dogs might be better than one. Two dogs are not alone, they have each other. One dog, if left home alone, can be very lonely and bored. This can lead to other problems, like excessive barking.   
As your move is a long way off, if you are considering getting the second dog, I would do so now. The reason I suggest this is that it may be more difficult to amend the supplementary agreement to your lease for keeping pets from one dog to two. If an owner does not allow pets, 1 dog is one too many. If a dog is okay, two should not be a problem. More than two starts to get complicated.

Several articles of the TSchV (and related legislation) have been revised - these changes are set to go into effect on 1 Jan 2014.   
The text of the revised law is here:     
The changes are explained here:   
Click on 'Revision Tierschutzverordnung: Die wichtigsten Ãnderungen fÃ¼r Heimtierhaltende'   
To give a very rough translation of bits that affect most of us in the summary linked above: (And those whose German is better than mine, please correct me where I have made mistakes.)       
Keeping dogs in kennels (Art. 70 Abs. 2 / Art. 72) 
Dogs do not have to be kenneled in pairs anymore.  As long as there is appropriate visual, auditory and olfactory contact with other dogs they may be kenneled in adjoining enclosures.       
Ban on all collars that inflict pain (Art. 73 abs. 2)   
Because new types of collars have been developed to circumvent the ban on prong collars, this loophole has been closed. All collars or 'guiding aids' which cause pain are forbidden, and the use of choke collars without a stop is explicitly forbidden.   
Private Schutzhund training (Art. 74)   
Previously Schutzhund training was allowed only for the army, police, border guards and dogs competing in organized sport. The law did not address the training of dogs used by private security services, now private Schutzhund training is included.    
Training hunting dogs with live animals (Art. 75)   
Previously the use of live animals was only allowed in training 'ground hunting' (my note: 'Baujagd', I think this means scent hunters - anyone more familiar with the sport please correct me), in livestock guardian training, and in herding dogs. Now it will be allowed in training wild boar hunting and in retrieving. Direct contact between the dog and animal used in training is forbidden - the only exception will be when it is essential to the training or testing of the dog. The wild animal must be allowed to retreat to cover. Training grounds where live wild animals are used are subject to approval of the cantonal authorities.   
Prohibition of devises that prevent noise or the expression of pain (Art. 76)   
Devises designed to prevent an animal from making noise or expressing pain are forbidden, with the exception of those attached to a collar that emit a blast of air or water. No other such devises, such as those emitting an scented essence, may be used.   
--- 
My note: Electric shock collars, citronella or lemon collars, acoustic collars are still banned for the general public. The use by licensed professionals remains regulated by the canton. 
---       
Animal shelters or animal care services such as dog sitters, dog walkers or people who take in animals while owners are on holiday, need a cantonal license as soon as they care for more than 5 animals. The carer's own animals are not counted in that number. Breeders and rescue organization selling/rehoming a large number of animals per year require a permit from the canton. (The exact numbers are stipulated in 101.c.1-7)   One will need the appropriate training course or diploma to be granted a permit as an animal carer. Pet owners are reminded to ask for the cantonal permit when you give your animal into the care of someone else.   
--- 
My note: For shelters or other commercial providers of animal care who care  for max 5 animals, it is enough that the responsible person possesses 'the requisite training'. This is quite a change from current regs (for instance, I'm assuming 'verlangte Ausbildung'  means the SKN for dog carers) and I would urge those of you offering/using pet care to clarify this with the BVet.  
---   
There is also a revision to the articles governing keeping horses, but since that is a specialist topic I'll leave those interested to read for themselves.   
Again - these changes are not set to go into effect until 1 Jan 2014.     
Animal welfare legislation (at the federal level) and animal control legislation (at the cantonal level) are both subject to change. Pet owners and pet carers should keep this in mind.

post: I will ask him also to clarify if it is in middle of room or next to a wall .?

Hi, 
Right, guinea pigs and rabbits should not be paired together (although they are at animal shops). First, some diseases that don't give symptoms in rabbits can be transmitted to g. pigs, which will be sick. It's rare events, but unnecessary risk. Second, g. pigs and rabbits don't understand each other and won't benefit from the company, compared to that of a "species friend".   
There's NOT a shortage of g. pigs in switzerland! I know many people how work with rescuing g. pigs and other animals, they are lucky to find somone who'll take care of baby g. pigs (babies are more attractive than the adults). Thay have a really hard time to find someone who'll take in older animals. The sad reality is that many older animals are put down, even though they are healthy, because there's no space for them anywhere. Animals are handed in to the vet to be put down because "the children got tired of them". Live, older animals are, not unfrequently, found left outside in the cold/in garbage rooms/outside the shelter house etc. The problem is rather to find responsable people to take care of the animals for their whole lives (which can be up to 10 years).    
The animals in most abundance is adult, castrated males, as there can be only be one male (and several females) in a herd. A castrate is actually an excellent company for a single female, often it works better than 2 females together.    
I suggested craci.org before, also SPA centers in switzerland sometimes get g. pigs, it's worth to give them a call. Unfortunately, I don't know of other organizations in german-part of switzerland. Also, sometimes people "donate" single animals on pages like tutti.ch, I don't like this business but it's better for the animals to pair them up.... Where do you live? 
I've adopted one older (4 y) male before here in switzerland, and now I have 3 newly adopted - 1 older and 2 younger.   
Have you also tried asking to "borrow" a castrated male as company for a few years? Some adoption places allow this, you can give the male back if you don't want to keep it when the female passes away. With males, this often works ok, as males often are more adaptable than females.   
Good luck

post: He's lovely!!

First, looking at the lawâ¦   
From the ZÃ¼rchertierschutz:     
"Auch ist es nicht erlaubt, Hunde tagelang im Auto warten zu lassen (z. B. wÃ¤hrend der Arbeitszeit). Bei lÃ¤ngerer Aufenthaltszeit des Hundes im Auto gilt dieses nÃ¤mlich als Boxe, deren PlatzverhÃ¤ltnisse aber nicht den gesetzlich vorgeschriebenen Mindestabmessung entsprechen."    
Roughly:   
Leaving a dog all day long in a car (for instance, during work hours) is not allowed.  Leaving a dog in a car is deemed to be the same as leaving him in a crate/box, where the space does not meet the minimum legal size.   
Here is the law that ZÃ¼richtierschutz is referring to: Note that the federal animal welfare law does not directly ban leaving a dog in a car, but rather sets out requirements for the minimum space a dog must have in any kind of kennel. ZÃ¼rich Tierschutz interprets the law on kenneling to apply given the length of time the dog is left in the car.       
See Art. 72. Boden, Unterkunft (p. 24) and  Anhang1, Tabelle 10, Haushunde (p.92.)   
---   
OK - So what should be done?   
First, do you believe the dog to be in immediate mortal danger? Anytime there is a reasonable suspicion of immediate mortal danger one shoud act immediately - which means calling the police in the first instance, or Tierschutz. But first one should take responsible steps to ascertain whether 'immediate mortal danger' applies or not.    
A car in a garage is usually not as dangerous as a car left outside, but garages can still get too cold or too hot, resulting in danger of heat stroke or freezing, ventilation can be a problem even in safe temperatures. Leaving a dog in a car where the temperatures are too hot or cold and pose an immediate risk to the animal can be an act of 'Tierqualerei', which (depending on the details of the case, of course) can be punishable under the animal welfare law.    
However - if the dog is not in immediate mortal danger, it is best to take a more measured approach. Speak to the dog owner first, explain your concerns.     
If the dog is indeed safe and seems happy in the car, do not go to the authorities before talking to the owner.  Remember, the goal is to help the dog and owner find a solution. Unless an animal is in immediate mortal danger, one usually has a better chance of making a positive change if one approaches concerns as a friend ready to help rather than with condemnation.  For the sake of the animal, again barring immediate mortal danger, it is usually more effective to work with the dog owner than against him.   
Find out exactly how the car is set up.    
(I know people who have gone to great lengths to design their cars boot space specially for their dogs, with safe ventilation and heating/cooling, sleeping and play areas, some cars are roomy enough, etc. Not every car is 'just a box'. But the issue of compliance with 455.1 still remains. If the car complies with 455.1, if temperature/ventilation is deemed to be safe, then under the law there is likely no grounds for action.)     
Find out the reason the dog owner is doing this. For instance, it's not uncommon that landlords forbid tenants from leaving a dog unattended in a flat. The owner might not be allowed to leave the dog at home.    
Once you know the why, once you have ascertained that leaving the dog in the car does not comply with 455.1, then offer to help find a dog care solution that addresses that reason, such as a Hort or other day care provider or a dog sitter who would stay in the flat. Do you know  of a good day care provider? Do you know of someone who could care for the dog in the owner's flat if a Hort is not appropriate for this dog? If you don't, could you help your friend find someone?      
Focus on helping to find a solution. What you don't want to do is to invoke the law leaving the owner with no alternative, possibly forcing him to give up the dog. That won't help the dog, which is what this is all about. Yes, 'Gesetz ist Gesetz', but the day to day reality of animal welfare work is all about protecting the animal first and foremost - which often means working quietly to help the owner rather than blazing in brandishing the law.   
---   
Whenever one has concerns about a animal related situation, once can always ask the relevant Tierschutz organization for advice, or ask Tier Im Recht. Best to proceed from fact - and these are the folks who know the laws, who can best advise re: practical solutions.   
---   
Good for you for caring - and I hope a solution can be found. Paws crossed, thumbs pressed.

So, an update -    
We called Dr. Serban, and he referred us to a vet clinic in Ecublens ( ), very close to where we live, in fact.   
As expected, and as the first vet told us, there wasn't anything that could be done for our really sick rat, and we had to have her pts last week. We are so sad to lose her. She was a funny little monkey who never stopped running around, exploring and getting into troubles when she was out of her cage. Our place is so quiet without her!   
After a medication change, our other rat is doing better. We will give her a bit more time to be sure her health is okay, and then work on finding her a new companion (or companions).   
Upon some reflection, I don't want to give any future readers the impression that the first vet clinic was not good (as you may figure out where we went!). Maybe it is just a case of a different approach and we wanted to ask more questions or try something else. Plus, the responses we've gotten from other people about this clinic have all been favorable!    
The new clinic, however, was quite good, and as they are much closer to us, we will probably continue going there.    
Thank you to all the responses and suggestions that were posted here; I appreciate them very much!

post:
Yes, a certain amount of moping after a move is normal.  As long as they are still eating and drinking, don't worry about it. They'll settle in in a few days.     
Did the coop come with the chickens?  If not, keep them shut in it and don't let them out for at least three days - they need to learn where "home" is so that they find their way back to it when they do go out.   
How old are they - I'm assuming full grown?  Hens, roosters or some of each?   
They need water.  A plastic bucket is OK, try to get one that's about chicken-head-height.  Won't hurt them if they have to stretch a little to get a drink, and the taller and heavier it is the less likely they are to knock it over or scratch food and straw into it.  The water should be changed every day.  In winter you'll need to go down first thing in the morning and break the ice off it, top it up with hot water.  I also used to feed them a hot breakfast on winter mornings (just their regular food with a bit of hot water poured over it, like a sort of chicken porridge - they go nuts for it.)   
Food - I second the recommendation to get some more pellety stuff if you can.  Don't know what's available here though.  They also need some grit (e.g. ground oyster shells) or small stones like you'd put in an aquarium.  You can just scatter a couple handfuls of this around their yard, they'll find it and pick it up as they need it.   
They will eat all sorts of kitchen scraps - well, almost all sorts. Mine hated bananas.  They'd take an experimental peck and immediately start wiping their beaks on the side of my shoe(!) trying to get rid of the nasty stuff.  But potato peelings, onion tops and tails, anything like that... also meat scraps.  And they will   stale bread.  Feed it to them by hand and you've got a friend for life.   
If you have hens they need a place to lay their eggs.  A good nesting box should be big enough for the hen to turn around in but not much larger.  It should be up off the floor (maybe a foot off the floor) and open in front, closed on top, back and sides.  Put some straw or wood chips in it, which they can then arrange to their satisfaction.  One nesting box is enough for four or five hens.  They'll probably find it and start using it on their own, but if you do keep finding eggs in odd places, pick them up and put them in the nesting box.  This time of year, an extra day or two won't hurt them (eggs will keep at room temperature for several weeks) and the hens will start laying there once they see other eggs there.   
Oh, and they need to be shut in at night - summer   winter - to keep them safe from foxes, neighborhood cats, etc.  They'll go in by themselves around dusk, you just need to count heads and shut the door.  If one or two are hanging around outside you can gently chivvy them in.   
I'm so jealous.    Have fun!

Many people who have Chinese or Japanese as their first language can't properly differentiate between R and L, it's very common, which might explain the mistake.    
You say you have a small apartment - just to let you know that animal law stipulates that you need to have at least a 2.5 room apartment for a cat, with an extra room for every extra cat. You should also have a litterbox for every cat and it is not recommended to have a solitary cat that is not allowed outside if you are not at home for at least six hours every day. Being at home asleep doesn't count. I don't know who checks this but just thought I'd let you know, especially if you are considering a move.
Would you own up to causing this damage? We will never know!

I wasn't sure whether to post in either of the pet sitter threads, given I don't have pets of my own here, so...   
Hi, I'm a 23 year old Australian, recently moved to inner city Geneva.  Unfortunately my animals have had to stay behind with my family, and I'm  having withdrawals! I have owned animals all my life, and worked for  three years in an animal shelter in Australia. I like all animals, but  I'm particularly fond of cats and rabbits. I had a chat the other day in Morges with a lady who has a Labrador puppy.    
Yes, you keep the dog for a year. I do not think that there is a lot of "training" during the year other that socialization etc. The dog wears his blue learner vest during this period. The dog goes everywhere with you.   
At the end of the year, you give up the dog who then goes to "school" for the blind (in the case I was talking with). The fail rate is 50%. The drop-outs can then go back to the family, if they would like to keep them (or can keep them) or they will be placed in another family.   
Sounds like a great idea if you can organize it. Good luck.

Mischka,   
Have you already taken the SKN theory class?   
People who have previously owned dogs in other countries but have not owned a dog in Switzerland need to contact the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt for a ruling on whether you are required to take the SKN Theory course, or not. This is decided on an individual basis, depending on your proof of previous ownership.   
But even if you are excused from the Theory course, I would strongly recommend that you take it before you go any further. The questions you are asking on this thread suggest that you are not familiar with Swiss norms and Swiss laws. Through the course you will learn quite a bit about what is expected of a dog owner in Switzerland, and in Wallis.   
And of course you are required to take the SKN practical course within 12 months of acquiring a dog.          Given that you were not able to bring your boxers with you to Switzerland - it's important that this does not happen again. As you are thinking about adding another dog to your family, please consider: Are you now in a position to guarantee that you will give this new dog a home for his/her entire lifetime, some 15+ years, no matter what else might happen in yours?

My dogs mother tongues are/were English, Chinese, Spanish, French, Italian, High German, and Whatever-in-heck-they-speak-in-Valais.    
I use hand signals.    
Seriously, all my dogs were adopted as adults and regardless of their 'mother tongues' I teach them all commands in English, as that is my default language and likely to come out first in an emergency. I then taught the dogs the basic commands in the language of the country we were living in. And as above, hand signals.   
Learning the commands in the local language is really for the benefit of passers-by, a bit of theater so that folks who are uneasy with dogs can see that mine are under control. But it's also useful, as your dog sitter or vets might use the German.   
So commands I use regularly:   
Fuss - general heel, specifically heel at left side 
Hand - heel at right 
Rechts/Links - left, right 
Bleib - stay 
Warte - wait 
Sitz - sit 
Platz - down 
Drehen - turn 
Rund um - to go around 
Ruhig - quiet 
Kom! come 
zu mir - to me 
Front - front, oddly my trainer uses this in English 
Voran - sendaway 
Apport! - Fetch 
PfÃ¶tli - give paw. I do not use the gib Fuss that your site suggests, as it is too close to the heel command. 
Steh - stand. (I only use the English 'stand', as the German 'steh' sounds too much like the English 'stay', confusing to the dog) 
Stop! - stop 
Peng!  - Bang, play dead - as in roll over belly up. (A trick that can be very useful on the exam table) 
Lass - leave 
Pfui! - the general Swiss-German 'stop that!' used in emergencies. A gentle 'Ah' is preferable for everyday correction. 
Genug - that's enough. 
Frei! - free, as in the exercise is over.   
Oh, and the JÃ¶Ã¶Ã¶Ã¶Ã¶Ã¶... fiiiiiiiiiiiiiiine HÃ¼ndli! which you will (hopefully) hear from pasers-by as your dogs are sitting pretty.    
For complicated commands I use the English. So for sit pretty I'd say just that.   
I actually use hand signals far more than verbal commands, as dogs are more attune to body language/visual than the verbal. And I had a deaf dog.   All the other dogs picked up on his 'canine sign language' very quickly - and hand signals are universal, not dependent on local language skills.   
But at the end of the day, none of this matters. Anything we humans say is a foreign language to our dogs, the words have no inherent meaning to them. We simply teach our dogs to associate a set of sounds with a desired action. I know a trainer who uses vegetables and fruits. 'Broccoli!' means heel, 'Tomato!' means sit, etc.

OK , without wanting to sound rude, that's incorrect. 
When we were in Japan we visited a bird sanctuary in the winter. It was cold and there was snow and the cockatoos and parrots were quite happy to be outside.   
Also, altitude has nothing to do with it either. There are some very high locations where these birds are indigenous and that is not an issue.   
The main reason that birds are not sold here is the recently introduced animal protection laws which regulates how these birds should be kept. The space requirements and the fact that these birds must be kept in pairs are just two elements that have made keeping birds unpopular. Many birds were given up as a result and the market for new birds has dwindled considerably.

post:
I studied the subject quite a bit, as my daughter (yes, my baby daughter, not my dog) got leishmaniasis in Portugal 2 years ago. Luckily it was the cutaneous form, and she now has a scar on the shoulder and nothing more. Internal form is mortal, so I consider myself lucky.    
As you probably know, a specific kind of mosquito is necessary to transmit the parasit: between animals, or from an animal to a human being.    
According to my vet, once an animal has leishmaniasis, it's systematically lethal. It can't be cured. Death will take a long time, perhaps even years, but there's no remedy. You can prolonge life, but nothing more.    
PLEASE people: if you go to an infected area, that is ALL south of Europe and further down, vaccinate your pets and protect yourself against mosquitoes.

Timely thread...   
The rescue with which I volunteer will take over rehoming, that's all set up. But as mine cannot go into kennels (medical issues), there needs to be someone to step in in the short term should I suddenly kick the bucket.    
The lovely lady who used to sit for me will take my dogs in the short term. But she is retired now - in 5 years or so, she might not be able to do this. So I'm searching now for a Plan B, someone else local who would also agree to step in as short term foster should the need arise.   
But I'll also stress the need to provide for one's pet financially - adopting an older pet can mean taking on a significant financial burden; I would hate to have that stand in the way of my dogs finding the right home should something happen to me.  I've set up funds so that whoever takes on my dogs - both short and long term - will not need to worry on that score.    
Working in rescue I see the fallout all too often. When Mum becomes incapacitated or dies, the family cannot or will not take on Mum's beloved dog - and the future of many elderly pets  is bleak when plans are not made in advance.   
Thanks for bringing up this issue, Odile.     
FYI - If one has adopted a pet from a rescue where there is a clause in the adoption contract that the pet cannot be passed on to a third party without their consent, be sure to discuss your plans with the rescue. Most rescues are thrilled to know that the animal's future is secure, but there are legalities involved. If the rescue retains ownership of the animal this discussion is critical.     
ETA: If your estate is governed by Swiss law, be aware of the legalities around animals and inheritance.  From Tier Im Recht:

BTW, the Alzheimer's care home where my father is makes great use of the Pets As Therapy program. These are not assistance dogs as in the video, but rather PAT dogs who are trained to do Alzheimers/dementia visits. The dogs are calm and gentle, unfazed by the periodic outbursts typical with Alzheimer's. In turn the dogs' presence seems to have quite a calming effect.   
I am so very greatful to the many volunteers and their wonderful dogs who give of their time - the dogs bring a ray of light into the patient's day.       
(What really warms my heart is that several of these PAT dogs were rescued from the pound under a 'Seniors for seniors' program. Older dogs who might otherwise be overlooked find a great new home, bringing joy to older people. Big win all around.)
Dog years - Often explained to kids to help them understand the process of life and death, and to make sure they don't get scared into thinking they're going to cop it in a couple of years time.

All dog owners who have taken on a dog in Switzerland after 1 Sept 2008 must do the practical course. Those already resident in Switzerland as of that date whose dogs were acquired before 1 Sept 2008 don't have to do the course - but if one arrived with one's dog in Switzerland after that date one needs to do the course(s).   
So... Rambokitten will need to take the SKN   course within 12 months of arriving.  The   course is for first time dog owners - but if one moves here from abroad one needs to contact the cantonal VeterinarÃ¤mt to determine if one's proof of previous dog ownership is acceptable, or not.   
(I have American acquaintances who are been excused from the theory course, and who have been required to take it. It's up to the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt to decided on individual cases. When in doubt, always ask your cantonal VeterinarÃ¤mt or the BVet.)   
But whether one is required to do the theory course or not - newcomers to Switzerland should do it nonetheless. Expectations of dog owners in Switzerland are   different than in other countries - knowing 'the Swiss way' will make your life much easier as you settle in here. The theory course is only 2 sessions, the practical 5. Cost is ca. 150 each.  A worthwhile investment, a good introduction to Swiss culture - and a great way to make new friends.

post:
According to the Susy Utzinger Foundation for Animal Protection no one can just go out and start killing cats at random. Here is an excerpt from their publication in English about killing animals as it is currently.    
[QUOTE]-> Legal situation regarding the killing of unwanted young animals   
In Switzerland, killing young animals without the appropriate expertise is forbidden. Killing an animal without professional training is a criminal act since it is classified as cruelty to animals and can therefore be reported.  
Cruelty to animals (Art. 26 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act in Switzerland)  
In Switzerland, it is forbidden to kill animals cruelly or out of malice. Doing so is classified as cruelty to animals according to article 26 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals act and is punished by imprisonment of up to three years, or by a fine, which can amount to several thousand Swiss francs. 
â 
What does Âkilling an animal cruelly or out of maliceÂ mean?  
Killing an animal out of malice means killing without having any sensible reason, for example out of mischievousness, thoughtlessness, callousness or on a whim.  
Killing an animal cruelly means that death is agonizing for the animal, and/or means killing it unprofessionally and without following the regulations of the animal statutory order. Generally speaking, an animal is killed cruelly if it was not adequately anaesthetized before its death so that it had to suffer or endure pain and fear. 
Regulations of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act 
Article 177 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act lays down the rule that vertebrates can only be killed by people who have the necessary knowledge and competence. According to article 185 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act, animals must be anaesthetized professionally prior to their death, thus ensuring that they die immediately and painlessly.  
Examples of killing cruelly:    
Â Drowning animals, such as rabbits, cats, chickens (death is very slow and extremely    agonizing)  
Â Intentionally running into or over animals 
Â Laying out poisoned bait 
Â Shooting without appropriate expertise 
Â Letting animals freeze to death 
Â Letting animals starve to death 
Summary   
The killing of animals must fulfil the requirements of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act. The killing of animals can only be carried out under certain circumstances and with the appropriate expertise. In particular, the killing method has to ensure that the animal loses consciousness immediately and that death sets in quickly without the animal regaining consciousness. There are special regulations concerning how animals are to be restrained when they are killed. The killing must not cause stress, fear or a defensive reaction.    
According to article 26 of the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Act, killing animals without these demands being fulfilled is classified as cruelty to animals and is punishable by imprisonment or a fine. This applies to livestock as well as to cats, dogs and rabbits. As a rule, only vets have the necessary expertise for killing an animal. 
What to do if you learn about the killing of young animals?    
- Address and inform the person about the new legal situation and the Animal Protection Act. 
- Offer various solutions to the problem (practical and financial support for the neutering of mother animals, support for finding respectable and animal-friendly placing for the young animals). 
- Organise cooperation with and support from an animal welfare organization.   
- If the person concerned does not listen to reason and if the animal welfare organization is unsuccessful, press criminal charges against the person for cruelty to animals.     
/QUOTE]   
I've attached a pdf of their full brochure in English. It's very informative and if you have a problem with an over population of ferrel cats in your area they can help.

A heads-up for dog owners:   
A recent article in K-Tipp and a bulletin from Tier Im Recht have highlighted the danger of fertilizers containing Rizinusschrott (Castor). Such fertilizers are apparently commonly used, especially in bio-farms. The pellets are apparently attractive to dog - and toxic. Recently a Labrador died after eating the pellets.          
Fortunately the Bundesamt fÃ¼r Landwirtschaft has reacted and ricin, the toxic substance in Rizinus (castor), will be banned in fertilizers from 2014.       
But that's a year away folks - as always, train your dog not to eat from the ground, and keep your eye on what your dog is doing at all times. Especially when walking near or in fields.

This is good news. In my experience, some vets try to prepare you for the worst unnecessarily. Last year one of our dogs had a sore on her tail that would not heal and the vet spoke to us about how it might be cancer and simply removing the affected area was too difficult given that there is little skin on the tail and they might have to amputate part of her tail.  At the visit they took a sample from the sore and sent it to the lab. The results came back that it was an infection, and she needed a dose of antibiotics. The sore cleared up. It was in fact a type of cyst which became infected.   
I appreciate that the doctor wants to prepare an owner but doing so prematurely just causes worry.    
The lab tests are not inexpensive but it really makes sense to me not to guess before lab results are available.

Word of warning about EuropÃ¤ische and their WauMiau insurance. They've just wheadled out of covering our dog's medical bill.   
We got our dog insured with them. They were not the cheapest company. (In fact, they were expensive and we went for the pricier package, assuming it would give us better coverage).   
Our dog recently had to have an emergency medical procedure, during the course of which the vet ascertained that her uterus would have to be removed.    
EuopÃ¤ische refused to cover the full cost of the procedure. They claimed claiming that the procedure was a spaying, adding that this are not covered by them.   
Whilst the small-print does say they don't cover castrations/spaying and pregnancy costs, this was not a spaying as such. It was a medical procedure which also necessitated having her uterus removed. Our vet backed us up on the interpretation of this.    
However, EuropÃ¤ische insisted on playing semantics and have refused to cover the four-figure bill.    
I spoke (in German) with their representative - a rather brusque, charmless lady. She claimed to have talked to our vet about the case, who supposedly agreed with them. Having double-checked with our vet, this was not the case. As as a supposed consolation, EuropÃ¤ische did offer to cover one-fifth of the cost, "as it was an emergency". This suggests to me that they know their argumentation is questionable, and that they're trying to "make it good".   
However, their terms and conditions also say that they will cover the *full* costs of emergency medical procedures, which this was.    
It doesn't look like we'll  be getting our money back from them, but we can put the word out there and warn other pet owners about our experience.    
I'll update this if anything changes.

Climber, is your dog already used to lino or other similar surfaces?   
I ask because some dogs find lino flooring slippery or even a bit scarey, or if your dog likes to self-entertain by tossing and running after toys (or is inclined to the 'Schwache Funf Minuten, otherwise known as the Puppy Zoomies*), running and breaking on smooth flooring can lead to accidents.   
Another solution might be area rugs. You can get inexpensive sisal or similar rugs (Ikea, Hornbach, etc.) that are very easily cleaned if you think your dog might be happier with some extra traction. Or you can get an inexpensive piece cut to measure at CarpetLand or other similar carpet stores.    
Just a thought.   
ETA: And, having learned from (expensive) experience - make sure your insurance really does cover damage by dogs, to flooring and anything else in rental accomodation. Some policies require an additional rider, others will cover dog damage within the scope of the usual policy. Despite covering the floor, you might need it one day...     
* Despite the name, the Puppy Zoomies are not limited to actual age. 8 year old Hooligan still succumbs to the urge to bounce off the walls at super-sonic speeds now and again.

Shildyu, it would help posters to understand if they can offer an appropriate home if you added added some critical information. For instance:   
Male or female? 
Age? 
Neutered or not? 
Is the dog a working sheepdog? If so, must a working home be found, or can he/she live as a pet? 
Can the dog live with children? If so, from what age? 
Can the dog live with other dogs? If so, what gender, personalities, etc? 
Can the dog live with cats or other animals? 
What kind of training has the dog had to date? 
What exercise and activity requirements does the dog have? 
Is the dog safe around livestock? 
What accomodation requriements does the dog have? That is, can the dog live in a flat, does he need a single family home with garden, does he need a quiet country home, does he need a fenced in property, etc? 
Where is the dog now?     
And - it always helps to include a picture with the initial rehoming post.   
Hoping he or she finds the right forever home...

post:
Treverus, the terms Tierheim and Tierpension are sometimes (albeit perhaps incorrectly) used interchangeably here; added to the confusion, some that are primarily holidays kennels also take in homeless pets as needed, and many that are primarily shelters for homeless animals also offer holiday care.   
Indeed it is rather common that shelters for homeless animals rely on their Ferienpension service to help fund their charitable activities. (TSBasel, SPA Fribourg, and Tierheim Burg in SZ come to mind - but many others do so as well.) Some cantons do not have a dedicated refuge for homeless animals and so outsource their care to private kennels.

post: I trained as a groomer last summer in Dublin as part of my big plan to ditch corporate life and open a quality boarding/grooming centre over here. I'm currently mid way through the new Swiss diploma in breeding/grooming/kennel management. All my Irish grooming colleagues agree that dogs act up much more when the owner is present during grooming. As an owner of rescue dogs myself, I would understand an owner's concerns and personally I would be willing to try grooming with the owner present but I do think it would be easier and quicker if the groomer is left alone with the dog. I also think any reasonable groomer should agree to divide the work to be done over a number of visits to get the dog comfortable with him/her and the environment

You don't mean "if", you mean "when" you move with our dog. It sounds like  your children would be devastated if the dog was not part of the move.  
What breed is your dog? Luzern is very dog friendly. I am certain you will find an arrangement for your dog. Veterinarians can often recommend a kennel or a dog sitter. The price can vary depending on the size of the dog. We get a "group" rate as we have 3 dogs but one of the kennels has a "suite" they can all share.

indeed your vet will do everything for you (at a reasonable cost too). Worming for a puppy should be done monthly, don't forget ticks and flea treatment on a regular basis.   
and you've saved a puppy that could be still in a store, we avoid certain pet stores in Italy because they have these animals in them.   
Are you going to crate train? I'd recommend this for your sleep to be good. My puppy is 1 tomorrow and benefitted from it.   
and follow the advice of your vet. Don't rush your first few consultations.

Just a reminder for all who have added a dog to the family after 1 Sept 2008:    
The transitional period for obligatory training classes (the Sachkundenachweis - SKN), required now under the TschV, comes to an end 1 Sept 2010. After that date, the local authorities can ask you to prove that you have taken the course, and might issue a fine if you are not compliant.     
So if you have not yet taken the course(s), best get going!

It's pretty easy to feed raw here. We get our meat from Carmello's at the Slaughter place near the Letzigrund.    
We have a freezer, so we get about 30 kilos at a time. We feet mostly heart meat, chickens and stinky tripe, sometimes sardines. You can also get your organs there, livers, kidney, esophogus... Watch out because he'll try to unload a giant bag of sawed up bones on you for free. Those can be dangerous. Our dog loves the the pork tails.    
I've seen packages of raw meat in Qualipet, but at ridiculous prices and it's probably minced or cooked anyway. When in a pinch, I just get the MBudget chickens from Migros.

We got our female schnauzer spayed at 6 months.  No worries, no problems and the vet was great.  She just couldn't have activities for 10 days.  Stitches out, no problem.  We did it because schnauzers are a highly active breed, and it calms them.  Also, females are more likely to get cancer the longer it goes on not to get spayed.  Don't know about males.   
And I don't think it is popular en suisse, because I could never understand when we met other dogs why the owners asked me if I have a male or female before they could greet each other. I think it is because they don't tend to get their dogs fixed.  We had no problem and it didn't change her personality either.

Hi Mop,   
I'll have to echo meloncollie et al. on the "only get a cat if you can commit yourself to it for its entire lifespan, come what may" line.   
If you can truly stick to that and really want a cat, get a new apartment and get it in writing that cats are permitted   moving in.  
I recommend using the form provided on this page : 
That way, landlord and tenant know what is ok and can fall back on it if problems arise. 
Maybe it would help to suggest using this form to your landlord?    
About his fears about the cat going outside, could you live with an indoor cat?    
If you're not ready to accept some inconveniences (e.g. forms, complicated rental agreements, indoor cats, people annoyed with roaming pets etc.) with regard to your pet, I'm sorry to say, I don't have the impression that you will be committing yourself to your cat 100%.   
Best of luck.

Sorry for replying so late...   
Cantonal and Gemeinde/Commune rules apply to all, residents and visitors alike. One is expected to comply with local rules when visiting.   
The obvious points will be areas where dogs are forbidden, noise regulations, areas where a dog must be kept on lead, etc.    
In the cantons where BSL is in force some cantons require visiting owners of those breeds to apply for a special visitor's permit for their dogs. If one has a listed breed (generally the bull or molosser breeds - the lists differ by canton) one must make sure that one understands local regulations to the letter.

Hi there!   
We attend the   A-Z   & Umgebung which is located at the Wiese(on the road where the Zoll Otterbach is located-Freiburgerstrasse) with our two Dackels. There are a variety of class levels and dogs that attend. Most classes are on Saturdays between 11 am and 2 pm and last 45 min. There are 3-4 trainers that rotate so that you usually get a different trainer every week or 2 weeks, which can be quite fun. They also do a nice mix of agility and obedience training, so it usually isn't boring. This is important as our older dackel gets verbal when he gets too bored sitting around doing nothing when he could be running around and digging holes. 
It is also very inexpensive at 200 CHF per year (if you go religiously there are ~30 classes per year). All classes are in Swiss German, but the trainers have been very good about speaking high German with me (if I am alone) or English if I'm very lost. They also allow my partner (Swiss) and I to train together, which has been beneficial for both of us (though more so for my comprehension of Swiss German).   
The website ( .ch/) seems to currently be down, but I will lay out the basic schedule:   
11:00-Noon: Welpenspielstunde 
noon-13:00: Beginners class (basically 4 months old and up, new people for a few classes, etc...) 
13:00-14:00: Intermediate 
14:00-15:00: Expert   
We currently attend the Expert training with our almost 3 year old dachshund and Intermediate training with our almost 1 year old dachshund. The trainers recommended that we skip the beginner class with the little one due to the class size (they have had over 10 dogs there on average) and our current experience-since we train weekly with our dogs at this club and our breed club. The trainers are all very patient and know all the regulars by name. We have met quite a few people there and I would highly recommend checking it out.If you would decide to check it out, I would recommend going to the Beginners class to start. Make sure to bring your pet's passport so they can check that he/she is up to date with shots and have fun!   
Currently the school is on winter break until the 23rd of Feb. and then there will be normal classes and clicker courses.    
Hope that helps.

Cristina,  one thing that your friend should understand is that dog ownership is viewed very differently in Switzerland to what one might expect coming from other countries. The responsibilities of owners, breeders, trainers, those working in rescue, dog carers, and anyone working directly with dogs are regulated to a greater degree, and animal welfare is taken very seriously.   
How a puppy is raised in the first weeks of life is one of these things. No responsible breeder or trainer would allow unrestricted public access as your friend's question seemed to suggest. Yes puppies need socialization - but that means a proper socialization program. Bad experiences during the puppy phase, which is all t oo possible when random people are allowed access, is the cause of many later behavior problems.   
And, just a note: A Welpenspielgruppe is an owner and puppy training class, and should be a controlled atmosphere. I would seriously question a trainer allowing strangers access to the class.     
If your friend is truly interested in puppies, I would suggest that she take the SKN theory class. No,she won't get to play with puppies, but she will come away understanding why the question was inappropriate.

post: Oasis des VÃ©tÃ©rans is a wonderful organisation, rehoming more senior dogs in a very homely environment.  I went to an open-day there and was most impressed.  Please consider a senior dog (some of them are not so senior, just middle aged!) as quite often available for rehoming due to an elderly or ill former owner.

I'll add to the mix, since my experience is still fresh in my mind. And since Jetset had a great format, I'll follow it for my own:          cat    13 pounds    Swiss.com    Sherpa Original Deluxe Pet Carrier    Arrived at the airport 2 hours before scheduled flight    January 10th    $100 payable at the check in counter (paid via CC)    direct, Newark, NJ - Basel     
- Took him to get him rabies shot at vet within 30 days of departure date. 
- Had vet put in microchip that meets ISO Standards 11784/11785. We did not purchase it ourselves (he had it in stock, as well as the forms required to be filled out by him) 
- Took him back to vet within 10 days of travel to have vet confirm she is fit to fly. (this was stressful, as the holidays/vet closure left me only 7 days from departure) 
- FedEx'd forms we received from visit in Step 3 to the local USDA where they signed and stamped the forms and FedEx'd them back (FedEx used due to the tight timeline   Switzerland requires additional paper beside the USDA forms.  . The omission of this document with the USDA and rabies forms caused yet more stress for me 
- He rode in the plane with us, sitting on the table next to my seat (we flew business class). During take off/landing he had to be moved to the space behind my seat and the bulkhead.      
The cat was very quiet the entire ride and only made a small wet spot inside the kennel. After we landed we took him through customs, declaring him (we didn't know if we had to or not, but felt it was prudent to do so). The guy at the counter glanced at the paperwork, checked for the chip and wished us a nice day. No money changed hands.

post:
Thank you Odile:    
I have read all this multipul times from other threads and on the government website. However, if you read other threads, they had no problems bringing in their pets that were docked as puppies from other countries.  As it states as well, you can bring in a docked animal as "claimed personal property".     
I would happily take a non-docked dog, however because it is done at such a young age breeders in America generally are not ones to want to do this, because they haven't developed enough to see if the dock as show potential or not, which is ultimately what they are breeding for. So in a breeders mind if they leave one not docked it might be the one that they would have kept and shown or also it might be the wrong a more aggressive dog when you want a more mellow temperament vise vera.     
I have found one breeder near our area in the US that does not dock currently, however, after doing some research it has been reported that it questionable whether she does proper health testing with the mating pair.  Not testing for health before breeding is a huge warning sign.     
I still have a little less than a year to figure this all out before we will be bringing a dog into our home.

We flew Lily from Raleigh to Zurich 5 years ago - she was 3. We really had no choice but to use a connecting flight, but we were able to use Continental - they had a specific pet transport program (pet safe) at the time, and she flew Raleigh to Newark, had a chance to get out and walk around in a secure kennel, and then Newark to Zurich. She was fine. I don't know if the airline still has this program - they've been consolidated into another airline.    
It's great if you can do a single non-stop flight, but if you can't and your dog is young, all you can do is arrange for short lay overs and keep an eye on things.    
Lily's 8 now though, and although I don't see much evidence of aging, we might do things differently.

All the information needed regarding commercial import is available on the BVet website. All serious breeders working within the FCI breed clubs already know the regulations.   
Apologies if I have the wrong end of the stick, but you sound as if you are proposing some kind of third party import scheme. If so, beware.   
Please understand that 'Hundehandel' is a very dirty word in Switzerland. Importing dogs into Switzerland with the intent to sell them on is looked on as very dodgy. The people who operate like that are usually battery farmers/puppy mills. NO serious ethical breeder would even consider operating in such a manner.   
Yes, knowledgeable dog owners here in Switzerland often go to breeders in other countries - not surprising given how few breeders there are in Switzerland. A knowledgeable dog owner then imports the dog they have chosen themselves, under the private import regulations.  - and very much frowned upon. People here expect to go directly to the breeder.    
A knowledgeable dog owner gets to know the breeder and dam (and sire when possible) personally, usually well in advance of the birth. A knowledgeable owner investigates the ethics of the breeder, ensures that the breeder's early socialization program is up to snuff, researches lines, checks that the breeder is a duly accredited member of the relevant breed club and that the sire/dam are properly angekÃ¶rt, that all relevant health and temperament tests have been done... in short, knowledgeable dog owners do due diligence.   
And a serious, an ethical breeder does the same (and more!) with all potential buyers. A good breeder checks out the buyer, requires the buyers to visit them and the dogs,often several times as the pup grows, and checks references.   
Knowledgeable Swiss dog owners expect this - and welcome it as a sign of a good breeder.   
As said, the people who ship dogs here to be sold on are generally battery farmers, selling sick, poorly bred dogs often under false pretenses. The BVet regularly runs campaigns against this awful trade, to warn naive buyers.    
All would-be dog owners are required to take the SKN theory course BEFORE acquiring a dog. How to buy a dog, how to assess a breeder, how to spot dodgy folks masquerading as breeders, the evils of 'Hundehandel' are discussed in the course.    
So be aware of the general sentiment and expectations of most Swiss dog owners who are looking for an FCI pedigreed dog.    
And those of us who aren't fussed about pedigrees go to well-respected rescue organizations.

post: ... if anyone is acquiring a cat in the near future and stocking up on necessities, I thought I'd point you towards a couple of cat transport boxes I have available for sale on the Pet Trading board. I know it's often rather quiet on there and with quite a lot of newcomers here, I thought it was worth pointing out on here too in case you've not found that board yet.

I've had cats pretty much my entire life. Your cat is trying to get your attention by using everything except the box when relieving himself. Either he's very sick, or he's really unhappy.   
I personally think you should take the cat to the vet FIRST to rule out any medical issues. Cat his size and even his age often have medical problems such as UTIs, kidney failure, diabetes, etc. Not saying your cat has any of these, but if he does they certainly can explain his behavior.   
Only start working on behavior modification if it turns out all is medically sound. Starting such techniques earlier (discipline, changing his routine, food, litter, etc.) will only create more anxiety for him if he is already sick.    
Hope it all works out and that he is healthy and happy soon. Ragdolls are not normally known for behavior or anxiety issues.

As a  , it is not allowed to bring a pet animal here with the intention of passing it on to someone else. The end owner must import the animal.   
In order to bring an animal here   either via sale or for adoption, one must import under  .   
Yes, I know that people import incorrectly, declare animals as theirs with false intention, even smuggle animals in. But they are acting outside the BVet regulations.      
As I have said many times before: if you wish to help animals, please do it right and stay on the right side of the law.   
Animal welfare work is very much in need of public goodwill. A rescue needs to maintain a sterling reputation here in Switzerland if it is to operate successfully.     
The law is clear. What you chose to do with this information is up to you and your conscience.

Summergirl, in my opinion this is what you must worry about. Your dog is left alone all day, and this is a no-no. One of your neighbours could report you. Just because I own dogs does not mean I want to listen to someone else's dog barking.    
I am not a dog psychologist but I think your dog is lonely. Splitting up the dogs, as you and your ex have done, makes no sense to me. Dogs are not property to be divided. It would have been in the dog's interest to share ownership of the two dogs.    
What does your ex do with the other dog all day? Is he left alone and barking as well?

As you may know canton ZH has BSL in force, banning 8 breeds and any mixed breed dogs whose DNA shows 10% or more of any of the banned breeds.   
Have any of you ZÃ¼rich dog owners been required to have your dog DNA tested in light of the ZH ban?   
I ask because on other forums there have been stories of wildly inaccurate DNA results, as the companies offering these services use somewhat limited databases.    
Just for the laffs, I had mine tested, although not using a Swiss company. I was quite amused to learn that the analysis claims that my sheltie is a... wait for it... schnauzer/BMD/dachshund mix.        
(She is a rescue, but I do have her pedigree and have met her sire and dam. So yes, I can say with certainty that she is, in fact, a sheltie.   )    
Such stories are not uncommon, apparently.   
It's fine when one uses such tests for fun. But given that under the ZH law a dog could be condemned on this data... I worry about the general accuracy of such tests.    
So - have any of you done DNA testing on your dogs, or have you been asked by the VeterinarÃ¤mt to do so? Were the results what you expected, or were there surprises?

The problem starts and ends with irresponsible owners. These restrictions are simply band-aids, doing nothing whatsoever to address the root cause - and a could possibly cause more problems in the end.   
A dog whose behavior warrants it should be kept on lead or muzzled. No argument from me there. However these laws will aversely affect hundreds or thousands of dogs whose behavior is perfect, who have done no wrong, whose owners have continually work on training, who take responsibility for their pet and respect others.   
A concern with a muzzling requirement for all dogs - those whose behavior does not merit it - is that you have cut off an important natural communication point. Dogs communicate with one another (and with us, if we pay attention) via body language. There are a range of facial expressions called 'calming signals' (read Turid Rugaas, please!) that dogs use to navigate encounters with other dogs. A muzzle restricts the dog's ability to 'speak' with his face (set of mouth, set of eyes, etc.) or block the other dog's ability to read his face. The result can be that dog A can't see that dog B is trying to say "hey, it's all good"  - and suddenly conflict errupts.   
(Geneva's general muzzling requirement was struck down by the courts - it will be interesting to see what happens with the Vaud law.)   
Most responsible owner will decide to leash or muzzle their dogs without being told. There are already laws on the books - in every canton -  that could deal with the few irresponsible ones. If those existing laws were actually enforced there would be no need for this new legislation.   
I see this in many Swiss rules and regs - a law is on the books but it is not enforced - and there is no mechanism of enforcement. So half the population ignore it. The problem isn't solved so new, stricter laws are passed. For which there is no enforcement mechanism so half the population ignore it, and the problem continues....   
By the way, I wrote to the VD VeterinarÃ¤mt several weeks ago asking how 'large' is defined in this law, but have received no answer. Could I ask someone whose French is better than mine to do the same?   
As for banning based on breed alone: Bad science. In most cases it's how a dog is raised, trained and treated that counts. The majority of pitbulls are actually bred/raised to be quite friendly to people. Even the poor dogs who have been trained to the fighting ring have to be people friendly, so that they can be handled when their adrenaline is up.  It should be understood that dog-dog aggression does not automatically translate to dog-people aggression, as the behavior is motivated by different instincts.     
Remember - the owner in the Oberglatt incident was a known criminal. The dogs had been illegally imported into Switzerland. They were kept starving (thought to be training for dogfighting) and at the time of the tragedy had been left in the care of someone incompetent to handle them. The owner had already broken several laws, complaints had previously been made.  The tragedy could have been avoided if any of several laws already on the books had been enforced.    
It's an old saying but one that rings true nonetheless: deed, not breed.

I got the answer what has happened to my cat so I am posting it for other cat owners.       He had a reaction to the Feluk vaccine.  As a result of this, his immune system was suppressed.    The cat flu he had as a kitten, the vet says stays dormant, and when his immune system was suppressed, it has emerged again making him  feel bad.   His gums are a little inflamed (she said this is caused by that same flu virus) and why he does not eat and she said he has a little cystis and his bladder is inflamed.   
I had brought him to the other vet numerous times and was told it was nothing. 
I am glad I went for a second opinion and listened to what I thought even when the vet kept telling me nothing is wrong.   
I did not know the cat flu stays dormant in the cats and also did not know all of the side effects that can happen with this vaccine.  She told me he can never have that specific vaccine again.   
He has meds and she believes he will be on the mend soon.

post:
1Snow, this is not true everywhere; a foreigner is required to ask the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt whether his/her proof of previous dog ownership is acceptable, or not - as Jules has done. Some of my colleagues have had their proof accepted, some have been denied.   From the BVet website, the FAQ on the SKN (Click on 'Haufige Fragen' on the right side:       
"Muss ein Hundehalter, der frÃ¼her im Ausland bereits einen Hund gehalten hat und sich nun in der Schweiz erstmals einen Hund anschafft, den theoretischen SKN absolvieren?   
Wer nachweisen kann, dass er schon einmal vor dem 1.09.2008 Hundehalter war, muss nur den prak- tischen Kurs absolvieren. In welcher Form aus dem Ausland zuziehende Personen diesen Nachweis fÃ¼hren kÃ¶nnen, ist nicht geregelt.  (z.B. BestÃ¤tigung der frÃ¼heren Wohn- gemeinde)."     
Roughly translated:   
Must a dog owners, who earlier owned a dog abroad and now in has taken on a dog for the first time in Switzerland, take the SKN theory course?   
If one can show that one owned a dog before 1. Sept 2008, one must only take the practical course. What form of proof is acceptable is not defined. One must contact the cantonal VeterinarÃ¤mt, to determine what they will accept as proof (for instance, confirmation from the previous place of residence.)       
FYI, Two of my colleagues who have been denied came from the UK. The problem seemed to be that there was no official registration or dog license. One of my UK friends was accepted, however, because she had a UK pet passport issued prior to 2008. MY US colleage was accepted - because she has a dog license from her town. These were in three different cantons.   
From what I hear, each cantonal veterinary office might look at it differently.     
But regardless of what one is required to do, it is strongly recommended that every dog owner new to Switzerland take the theory course - because the laws and social responsibilities here in Switzerland are very different from many of our home countries. It's a chance to learn what is expected - before we make mistakes.      
ETA:   
And just to stress: there is no test for either the practical or theory courses. Course attendance is all that is required.

If you need something bigger and are looking for an inexpensive solution, you might try Ikea baby or children's mattresses.   
Baby mattresses are ca 120x60, 5-10cm and children's 160x 70, 8-12cm. When Melon's old bones needed a bit more comforting I put two mattresses together to make a thick bed. I made fleece covers (out of CHF10 fleece throws, on sale at Manor, IIRC), easy to clean. The foam is a nice egg crate foam, has held up well so far over about 8 years and four dogs. If the size isn't quite right, the foam is easy to trim.   
If those are too small, you could also get the full sized foam mattresses, 200x 90 or daybed mattresses 190x 80.     
(But despite having lovely comfy beds in every room in the house, where do the muttley crew sleep? On the sofas and in my bed, of course.   )

I had friends traveling back to the US in July with Lufthansa (ZRH to Frankfurt then on to DC). In Zurich they were allowed to put the cats through the x-ray machine while still in the carrier.  They turned down the level of the x-ray apparently and told them it was safe.  In Frankfurt they had to be rescreened, but this time they had to take the cats out of the carriers, put the carriers through the x-ray and walk through the metal detector with the cats.  They had leashes on the cats, but apparently some old woman thought that this was a nice time to just walk up to my friend and try to pet the cat without asking. Needless to say, the cat flipped out, scratched my friend quite deep, slipped out of the harness and ran off into the Frankfurt airport. Luckily, her husband saw where the cat was going (he too had a cat in his arms), and they were able to find the other cat quickly.  Both cats are now happily living in the states but it was quite a difficult day for everyone. So, if you do go through Frankfurt, be mindful that you might need a second security check.  If that is the case, keep an eye out for idiot travelers that might think cats love all forms of attention even when in unfamiliar places.

You heard right - under the new-ish federal animal welfare law (TSchV), dog owners are indeed required to take courses. These are called the Sachkundenachweis (SKN), and there are two types of mandatory classes:   
First time dog owners - that is, anyone who has not had a dog registered in his/her name in Switzerland* - are required to take a theory course BEFORE acquiring a dog. This course discusses the basics of dog care, dog laws, your responsibilities as a dog owner in Swiss society. It is designed to prepare you for sharing your life with a four-footed friend - and to get you to ask yourself if you are indeed  ready to make this commitment and to stick to it for the next 15 or so years. The theory course is usually done over 2-3 lessions.   
All dog owners, regardless of experience, must take the practical training course within the first 12 months of ownership with each and every dog acquired after 1 Sept 2008. This is a very basic training course, really just brushes the surface. The course is usually done over 5 lessons.   
The price of the courses may vary a bit by trainer - but usually are in the neighborhood of CHF 150.   
Only a trainer certified by one of the BVet recognized organizations may teach the SKN; to find a trainer near you, see the database:       
You can read more about the courses on the BVet website:     
And the subject has been discussed at length here, search for 'SKN'.   
So as you are doing your research, if you are required to do so, take the theory SKN now - it's a good introduction to dog ownership in Switzerland.   
All the best.       
* Folks who have owned a dog - as in the legal owner - in Ausland but not in Switzerland should contact the cantonal VeterinÃ¤ramt with proof of previous ownership for a decision as to whether you need to take the theory course, or not.   
But - even if you are not required, I would strongly recommend doing so - society's expectations of a dog owner are rather different in Switzerland than in other countries, and the SKN sets you on the right road.

My one dog, while out hiking in the US got into a wasp (yellow-jacket) nest. Everyone ran except me who went in to get him. I got stung a couple of dozen times, he got stung equally as much.  Now, even if the slightest bump on his arse happens, he go crazy, yelps, and takes off running, without regard to anything. There could be several reasons why this has happened, I wouldn't want to guess... this is a case for the vet.   
My rule is always: Lumps = vet, if only for peace of mind.   
Hopefully it will be something relatively simple and easily treatable. But if it turns out to be a more complex or lasting problem, don't hesitate to as your vet for a referral to a veterinary dermatologist.    
If an allergic reaction is suspected it will help if you keep track of what your dog eats and comes into contact with - including not only household chemicals but also things on your walks. Have neighbors put down lawn chemicals? Have you walked through a newly fertilized field? Has he been playing in water? And so on... Also track any changes to the size or number of the lumps. The more info you can give the vet the easier it will be to treat him.   
Poor little guy - paws crossed for him.

Hi,   
I know it's a little late, but we use Mitzy's dog sitting services. She can come to your place and pick up the 'kids' and drop them off again. We use her for our little girl and she loves her!

The SPA Fribourg charge 500 for dogs, 150 for unneutered kittens and 190 if neutered and 50 for rabbits.  It's not the sum itself, it's making sure people are really committed to looking after their pets once they take them on.  And having had two rescued cats, albeit at no cost, the love and joy of watching them transform from scared young cats into confident, playful companions is worth any amount of money in my book.  As soon as we get the new house cat friendly, we'll be getting another one or two and I can hardly wait.

Methinks you are an exceptional dog owner, JBZ - and one of the exceptions to the rule.    
I see the fall-out from poorly planned puppy ownership all the time.    
When a 6-12 month old dog is handed in to our rescue, most of the time it is because the owners got a cute puppy without understanding the amount of work that means and were not able/willing to devote the time needed to teach him how to live in the human world.    
Without consistent-on-the-spot training, socialization, and reinforcement that cute puppy can develop some annoying behaviors - and in some cases, serious behavioral disorders.  And when that cute puppy turns into a rambunctious teenager - this is the point where the family dump the dog.   
Rehabilitation of a pup who did not receive adequate socilization during the critical fear periods can be very difficult.    
Based on the intake interviews I've done in such cases, the majority of those owners left the young puppy on his own for long stretches at a time, and did not make adequate provisions for physical and mental stimulation, socialization, training. Surprise, surprise - they now have an ASBO hound on their hands.     
Over the last 20 yearsI've spent too much time and shed too many tears picking up the pieces.      
I firmly believe that one owes it to one's puppy to set him up for success from day one. That means being available - on the spot - whenever necessary in those early days, to help him learn what he needs to know.    
Especially here in Switzerland, where neighborhood intolerance of an imperfect dog often results in abandonment or a one-way trip to the vet.      
---   
That said - I've told the story of Saint Swimbo's unexpected entry into my life before... (Post 15 here:   )   
Yes, it can be done. But it's bl**dy hard work - and owner and pup start out with one strike against them.    
It can work - IF the owner is creative, IF the owner is willing/able to gather the resources necessary to provide for the pup, IF the owner -   -  are willing to make the pup's welfare a number one priority. Some people can do this - but my rescue experience shows that many cannot. And the pup becomes a statistic.   
I've been there, done that - and by merest chance got very lucky. In hindsight -   -  I would never, ever do it again, nor would I ever recommend anyone else doing so.    
A pup deserves the best possible start in life - which in most cases is someone with him during the critical early periods.

Our cat came from this SPA and can vouch for their professionalism, althogh have no experience with their boarding business.  Also, it really is not far at all from Lausanne.   
Elsewhere in Vaud, the Nyon SPA does holiday boarding as well, but not sure about others in the Canton.  Nyon fills up quite fast.   
Please check the pet boarding thread for recommendations.

Toothcentral, have you taken the SKN yet?   
If not, this is a good way to get involved with local dog owners - who will have the scoop about local dog-friendly places.   
I've not found dog parks like we have in the US in Switzerland.    
(O how I miss our local park - acres and acres securely fenced, with two lakes, woods, open fields, dedicated dogsport areas... all safe from complaining dog haters. Those were the days...)   
However there is an alternative: the Lecky Trail JÃ¤gglisch-Horn (near Klosters) is not too far from you in Chur - maybe not an every day thing, but a good outing for you and the pooch.       
These are trails designed primarily for 'conflict-free' hiking with dogs. The idea is that folks using the trails will understand that yep, here be dawgs. Those who dislike dogs and do not wish to share public spaces with them hopefully will avoid these trails.    
However the usual dog-etiquette applies: if someone does request that you re-leash, please do so - and please respect other's rights to use the trails.   
---   
Living in SZ where dogs must be on lead in public, I more or less consider our local Hundeschule as our 'dog park'. By that I mean that much of my dogs' socialization/exercise with other dogs takes place at the HS. We practically live there   so it's a good way to ensure the dogs' social/behavioral needs are met. Area walks are on-lead (as per law), so I use these as bonding and training opportunities.   
You might consider joining a local dog club or dog school if you don't find what you are looking for in an informal setting. Fees usually aren't all that expensive.

Sadly the people who buy these dogs have a clue there is something not right. They just don't want to pay the Swiss/French/German/Italian price for them. A good quality healthy pedigree Chi is expensive. Even a good quality healthy well breed non-pedigree Chi is about twice as much as these dogs were selling for.    
I was just out with some of my Chi owning friends tonight and we were discussing this. There is a woman in the area who has 9 Chis from the Czech Republic! And these are her pets. She imported them all and isn't a breeder.
how long did you do the 'separation'?  I think it's just a matter of time.....
