Hi   
Looking for professional price per day dog sitting for my dog. I remember seeing a thread recently where someone advertised themselves but after searching I can not find it again   
Need a dog sitter for a week from 13th Feb but not kennels with lots of other dogs. Has anyone got any recommendations. As I mentioned on the pet sitting thread I can't return the favour at the moment hence looking for a paid (guilt free) service    
Nicky

Hi 
we need a dog sitter (vacation sitter) for Feb 12 through Feb 20 and for other times in the future. We just moved to Winti and miss our old dog sitter a lot already  ;-) 
Does anybody know a good dog sitter and/or dog sits themselves ? 
We have two little dogs - Bichon Frises.

Climber, fees vary depending on the services needed - but expect around CHF 25-50 per hour for a dog walker who comes round once a day. You may need to pay mileage on top of that.   
Daycare, where you bring the dog to a carer's home or professional care facility, can run from CHF 40-100+ per day. You would need to vet any facility carefully.    
In-home care, where the sitter stays in the client's home, generally starts at CHF 200 per day.   
Do be aware that professional (which in most cases means paid, depending on how the business is set up) dog walkers and dog sitters are required to hold certain qualifications, and be registered with the cantonal veterinary office.   
You are absolutely correct that there are dodgy sites out there. There are people offering dog sitting services who do not have the necessary qualifications/registration/insurance, who are working 'schwarz'. A sitter/walker working illegally puts the client at risk.    
An alternative would be to find a friend with whom you can exchange dog care (as opposed to paying)  - but if this is a regular thing that goes on for more than 3 months that friend might need to do the SKN with your dog as well.   
(Speaking of which, don't forget that you must do the SKN theory course  you get a dog, and then complete the practical course within the first 12 months.) 
---   
Is the dog you are looking at a puppy, or an adult?    
If a puppy, you will need to have someone with him/her all day, a dog walker who pops in for an hour is not enough.  A pup cannot be left for long, this is a crucial socialization and training period. It would be grossly unfair to the pup - and you'd be setting yourself up for problems down the road. It is generally recommended that people who work full time should not get a puppy.    
An adult dog is a better choice for someone who is gone from the house full time - but you still need to choose the dog carefully. Some adult dogs could not handle being left while you work, even with a dog walker - some would be fine. You'd need to understand the individual's character.    
All dogs need companionship, training, and socialization - which requires quite a time-intensive commitment from you. When one works full time one often must devote pretty much all of one's free time to the dog, in order to meet the dog's needs. But that's why we have dogs, isn't it? Because we love being with them.
We've done it loads of times and have never been stopped, but you'll have to ensure you have done all the items in the link above.

I am a 26 year old reliable and trustworthy woman who grew up with animals and would like to look after your darling whilst you are on holiday/working/shopping etc. 
Canton of Zug/Luzern/Schwyz. Just send me a message with your details and I will contact you.   
Kind regards, 
Eli

post:
Alarm bells ringing here, too.   
Never, ever, hand over money before you have visited the breeder/rescue. While some breeders do indeed ask for a deposit, this should only be done once you have met the breeder, passed passed the breeder's homing criteria, once you have determined that the breeder passes your criteria for ethics, responsibility, health of pups, etc. Once you have seen the dam (and sire where possible) and thoroughly vetted the pup's living conditions and socialization program, once you have seen the health certificates - only then should you proceed.   
Unless you have a binding contract in writing, do not exchange money.   
Same goes for any rescue organization.   
Money upfront says BYB or naive breeder at best, scam or battery farmer at worst. Walk away. If the breeder is proposing to ship the dog to you then   away. That is the first sign of a battery farmer.   
---   
That said, I have adopted from a shelter in Italy. The paperwork is easy, you just need to follow the BVet requirements:       
Now - I took a vacation to visit my guy and spent a long time with him - got to know my dog's personality and needs, got to know the shelter staff - and they me - before finalizing the adoption. And this for a broken old collie that no one wanted .   
--    
Do understand that some of the worst of the dog world hide behind the snazziest websites  -    
Please read the thread Summerrain has linked. Then re-read it, and read it again.   
What breed are you looking for? Perhaps someone can point you to an reputable breeder here - or you may even find the companion of your dreams in rescue.     
--   
ETA: Coming from Italy, make sure you understand the risks of Leishmaniose...

post:
There are many good breeders in the UK, in Germany, in the Netherlands, in Sweden, in the US, in Australia, in every country. Nothing wrong with finding your puppy over the border.   
But please - do not buy over such internet sites. These sites are littered with battery farmers and scams.    
If you are not aware of what goes on in the battery farming trade (a more accurate term than puppy farming, puppy mills) please do a little googling. Best to have a strong stomach, though.    Every pup bought from a battery farmer condemns another dog to a life of misery - do not support this vile trade.   
I'll say it again - if a dog from a breeder is what you feel is best for you, go directly to the breed club of an FCI kennel club (the KC in the UK, VDH in Germany, etc.) who will guide you to reputable breeders within their club.   
Again, see the 'How to find a reputable breeder' thread - the same process applies to all good breeders, worldwide. Prices from reputable breeders in the western world are not all that far off those in Switzerland, btw.    
Reputable breeder, reputable rescues - both work hard to ensure the same thing: a loving forever home for their dogs.    
Yes, the process of bringing a dog into your life can be time consuming and costly. But well worth it, when you consider that your dog will be your loyal, loving companion for the next 10-15 years.

post:
Sue I make my own Schleppleine out of climbing rope and a carabiner or clip. You can get a variety of strengths - my guys are 10-16 kg, so I use a fairly lightweight rope. You can find this stuff at climbing stores, but I buy it  at Coop B/H for a tiny fraction of the 'profi' price.   You can also find the materials to make your own at Landi, again at very good prices.   
The Schleppleine you find at the pet store are indeed different weights - you will need something that will hold up to your dog's strength when running as he normally does. To start, probably choose a middle weight, one that feels comfortable to you. Or better yet, ask the staff at the pet store - they should be able to advise you.   
And if you haven't used one before -   attach a long line to a collar, only to a harness. The long line allows a dog to build up a nice head of steam - if you pull taught , or the line gets caught you could injure his throat.   
As for the cost of training classes - all over the ball park.    
To give you an idea, though - I have a yearly 'Familienhund' abo for each of my guys, ca CHF 600 for 40 or so lessons. Other classes like Team Training are something like CHF 20-25-ish per class, and Agility once a week is CHF 250-ish per semester.   
I train in SZ, so unless you are right on the border probably too far for you - but take a look at the Certodog website for trainers by canton:       
There are many other training organizations, though.  You can also look at the BVet database for SKN qualified trainers - most will also offer other training opportinities: (Searchable by PLZ)       
Good luck!

post:
Not only would it be helpful...  it's also the law.    
(Please forgive me for sounding like a broken record, but under the new Tierschutzgesetz anyone acquiring a dog after 1 Sept 2008 must take classes with a trainer certified by a Bvet-recognized training organization. First time owners are required to attend theory classes   acquisition of the dog. Given the confusion surrounding the roll-out of the law, you will have until 2010 to comply, though.)   
See the BVet for a list of training organizations recognized to certify members, click on 'Anerkannte Ausbildner von Hundetrainern' and 'Wer Darf Sachkundenachweise Ausstellen?:       
For instance, a list of Certodog eligible trainers can be found here:       
And a further list of training schools; some of these trainers will be certified to offer the Sachkundenachweis soon:       
The required courses are fairly minimal - 10 hours IIRC.  You will probably be able to complete the requirement via a puppy or Junghund class, but it certainly is a good idea - for you and your dog - to continue beyond that if you find a trainer with whom you like working.   
As for English speaking, I wouldn't worry so much. Just start calling trainers near you - even if a group course is offered only in German some trainers will be willing to do private lessons in English.    
Or use this as an opportunity to practice your German.  Seriously. Thanks to training classes and tolerant fellow dog owners, I speak fluent 'Hund-Deutsch'   - although my High German is imperfect and my Swiss German downright awful.   
If you speak any German at all, you will probably find that you can get by - and there is often someone in the class who speaks enough English to help when you get a bit lost.   
Honestly, being in a class where I didn't quite understand the language actually helped me work more effectively with my dog. After all, the dog is going through the same thing - trying to decipher a babble of sounds and an incomprehensible set of rules, relying on visual clues and universal tones to guess at what is being asked. Having been put in the same shoes, so to speak, I've learned a lot about how to use non-verbal communication more effectively.    
All the best to you and your pup.

post:
We almost lost one of our dogs (Hana)to pyometria. She was a rescue and at 3 1/2 she was not spayed. We had planned to but the vet advised us to let her drop some excess weight first (she was an enormous 27 kg). About a week after we got her she seemed ill and the vet, who had checked her out before we took her home, said she suspected early pyometria. But at 3 1/2 spaying is more complicated, not to mention on an overweight dog. But there was no choice. So we went ahead and she was fine, just had a longer hospital stay (most dogs go home the same day).   
The cost of spaying a dog in Japan is about 350 chf. We had our other two rescued dogs done while they were much younger.    
Hana recovered well but then developed bladder problems and there were months of tests with inconclusive results. Finally we took her to the oldest veterinary hospital in Japan where they found that the silk sutures used when she was spayed were the source of the trouble. This is so rare - then again, Hana is an unusual dog.

Bobby, first can I say how wonderful that you have adopted an elderly dog in need - good for you!  There is something so very, very special about the oldies, they ask so little and have so much love to give. I wish you and Lady all the very best.   
---   
Nutrition can be quite a complicated issue. Good nutrition is especially important with senior dogs as their appetites, ability to digest, energy needs, and emotional relationship with food changes as they age.    
Billhardie and FairyDust have given you very good advice.    
My first thought when any of my mutts, but especially my seniors, starts to get fussy with food is to look for an underlying physical problem. It is generally easier to address physical problems than psychological ones, so I try to rule out physical causes first. Has Lady had a baseline blood chemistry done?  A blood chemistry is non-invasive and can give an idea of organ function so it's a good place to start. I do this as part of a regular senior dog check-up, this is an easy way to catch some issues in a timely fashion.   
(Mine are generally hoovers-on-legs, so turning up their noses at food starts my alarm bells ringing. An example: what I initially took as fussiness in my girl was acute pancreatitis, fussiness in one of the boys turned out to be chronic IBD.)    
It is important that Lady gets a balanced, nutritionally sound diet. That can be accomplished with either a good quality commercial diet, or a vet-approved home made diet - but you want to ensure that Lady gets what she needs to eat, not just what she wants to eat.   
----   
The question is: Is Lady rejecting the foods you offer because she doesn't like the taste of that particular item, because she is intolerant to an ingredient in the food, or because she is holding out for something better (in her mind)?  If the first two, the key is finding a nutritionally sound diet that Lady can and will eat. If the latter, then some behavior work is needed.   
Some random thoughts:   
In determining if a particular food suits Lady, look first to her general energy levels - is she alert and age-appropriate energetic, or lethargic? Also condition: how does her fur look - glossy, or dry? And watch her stools.  Firm, good color, normal amount? (Ah, the wonders of dog ownership - one quickly becomes something of a scatologist.) If her condition, energy and stools are not so good, she likely cannot tolerate one or more of the ingredients - which is why she may be rejecting the food.    
Allergies or intolerance to foods are not uncommon; you might start with something Lady has not had before, perhaps a fish and potato based diet, and see how that goes. Some dogs needs a grain-free diet, some need different levels of protein. We feed Magnusson, a baked kibble - most extruded kibbles are too greasy for my guys, the baked food suits them better. Adding hot water to the kibble helps bring out the smell, making the food a bit more appetizing. And mush is easier on my ancient almost toothless guy than kibble.  Lady might tolerate a senior diet better.    
If Lady absolutely cannot eat kibble, then a home-made diet is a possibility. But here it is very important to get the nutrition right. Any home-made diet probably needs a vitamin and mineral supplement, and you should ask your vet to analyze any home-made diet to ensure that it is indeed nutritionally sound.   
A very good resource discussing canine diets is the Whole Dog Journal. The magazine analyses commercial dry and wet foods, as well as home made diets and raw feeding - lots of good articles. In light of the melamine scandal of a few years ago, assessing quality and ethics of commercial companies has become a mission with them. This magazine is US based, so some of the commercial diets discussed are not available here.   
The magazine is subscription only, but there is limited free content on their website:       
There are times when I have fed home-made; the diet I followed is here:       
But please note that supplements are required.   
Changing foods can cause stomach upsets for some dogs; for this reason chopping-and-changing, trying different foods often to find something Lady likes, can be sort of self-defeating. As you look for a good food, try to stick with one for a while so that you get an idea of what Lady tolerates.   
----   
Assuming that Lady has been given a clean bill of health, then there is likely a behavioral reason, perhaps a relic of Lady's past. The bread and milk thing suggests that she has been fed this way in the past. (And no, bread and mild not a sound diet. ) However, if she was in a Tierheim for 8 months than surely she was fed on a no-nonsense kibble diet during that time. Have you spoken to the Tierheim to get an idea of her behavior around food there?    
If the food rejection is largely behavioral you need to decide what approach to take. With a healthy dog, I'd probably take a pretty hard line.   
If she is in good health, missing a meal or two won't hurt her - I'd try putting her food down, give her the 'time to eat' command, leave the bowl for ten minutes, then take it up again if uneaten. Ignore begging and pleading looks until next mealtime. Most dogs catch on quickly that nothing else will be on offer, so I'd best tuck in.   
When doing this it is important that you remain absolutely non-reactive. Meals should be a neutral time, not a time when you get upset at her behavior, or a time when you coax her to eat, bringing emotion into the event. (I know this is difficult to do when one is worried about one's pet.)   
Please note - this only appropriate if Lady is in good health. - If she has any health concerns do not do this without first speaking to your vet.   
---   
Another approach might be to do away with meals altogether.  My two younger dogs don't get food in bowls - instead they get their daily ration one piece of kibble at a time, as training rewards throughout the day. (This means I walk around with pockets full of kibble all day, but hey ho...)    
Will Lady accept dry kibble from you, as opposed to eating it in a bowl? Does she like to train? If so, perhaps you could try this. My guys love to work, love training. Feeding as rewards rather than meals has the added benefit of cementing the bond between us, gives the dogs the brain training they so love - and keeps them from getting fat. If I fed meals in addition to training rewards mine would both be barrels.    
A variation on that is to turn mealtime into a game - this is good for play-oriented dogs. I have a treat dispenser that looks like a gumball machine with a lever. I trained my girl to press the lever to get a piece of kibble. Some days I put her part of her  food allowance in the dispenser - she loves the 'self-service' game. You can do the same with a treat ball or cube, or home-made activity box. Another game is search: I hide kibble in toys, containers, etc around the room, give my dog the 'search!' command -  she runs around the room looking for her food.  If Lady is play oriented, doing something similar might be a way to motivate her to eat.    
Be aware, though, that turning meals into a game can back fire with some dogs. Mealtime as playtime might not fit into your schedule every day.  The key is you decide when the game is played.   
You could also feed  Lady in a kong if she likes those - stuff a kong with either kibble mush or your home made diet.    
----   
Do you think Newton's behavior around food might influence Lady in any way? Could interaction between the two over food play a part in Lady's fussiness? I've seen some dogs reluctant to eat in the presence of others, sometimes because of subtle signals the other dog gives off.  On the other hand, I've seen some who get food-obsessive and bolt it down when other dogs are around. Something to think about.   
(I had accidental success curing my MILs fussy-eater cairn when she came to stay with me for a holiday, simply by feeding her in the same room as my piglet of a collie. The cairn was doing her usual diva routine and before I could stop him, my collie scarfed down all her food. The little cairn quickly became a paid up member of the clean plate club after that. Be careful though - you don't want to set up a food jealousy or resource guarding situation.)    
---   
Another thought:  how much food Lady does actually need?  The feeding recommendations on many foods are notoriously over-generous. My healthy dogs get ca. 10g food per kg bodyweight - which works out to a little more than 1/2 the recommended allowance of many foods. If I fed mine the manufacturer's recommended amount, they'd be huge.   
Also, perhaps Lady needs small meals more often - my boy with IBD can only eat a spoonful or two at a time - so he eats 4-6  tiny meals a day. Many senior dogs have digestive issues; feeding little and often seems to help. If you find this is the case a vet visit is likely in order.   
---   
These are just some random thoughts, some may apply, some not.  Start by checking for or ruling out any physical reason why Lady might not want to eat, and then spend some time observing her behavior around food. Perhaps with more specifics we can come up with some more appropriate ideas.     
Good luck - and bon appetite!     
ETA:  Re: adding bullion to Lady's food. While adding something appetizing is often a good idea, I'd stay away from commercial bullion  because of the huge salt content - especially in a senior dog where kidney problems could be a risk. Rather, make your own so that you get the meat smell and flavor but no salt.

Easiest way is to get some quick growing plants - the algae is because of excess nutrients so quick growing plants will compete for this. go for water wisteria - it grows quick and looks ok and isn not hard to grow.

I can only speak from my experiences: I have always called ahead and ask if volunteers are needed. One will likely be asked several questions, sort of like an interview to assess your skills, knowledge, etc. Then one usually meets with a staff member and further questions are asked, often to pair you up with an appropriate dog. One usually is asked to leave one's Ausweis when one takes a dog walking. It's very helpful if one can volunteer with some frequency, as you develop a rapport with the dogs.   
Some rescues have an orientation program that dog walkers need to complete.   
Most Tierheim do not allow minor children to walk the dogs, some will allow a child to accompany an adult, but children are generally not allowed to hold the leash.   
Every Tierheim I know requires that the dogs be walked on-lead only.   
Some Tierheim will ask for a regular-ish commitment, some are happy to accomodate less regular volunteers. Each Tierheim sets it's own policies, so don't take my word for gospel, call and ask.

post:
Well, we all arrived safely to our Zurich apartment (2 parents, 2 babies, and a cat).   
It's funny how the part we were most scared of, i.e., the Zurich airport part, turned out to be the easiest one: We went through the red "goods to declare" lane (I doubt it if they would have noticed that we are traveling with a cat otherwise), were asked to present the FVO permit (apparently, this is the only document one needs), Shirley's microchip was read to verify a cat-permit match, paid 88 CHF, and we were free to go. The whole process lasted less than 5 minutes.   
In contrast, we did have some unexpected difficulties in Tel Aviv airport (from which we took-off): First, we found out that Swiss (the airline) requires that cats will be carried in a soft cage (when traveling with us in the passengers cabin), so we were forced to buy one (US$40) and transfer Shirley from her old cage to the new one. Then, security demanded that we put the soft cage through the x-ray machine (although it was bought in the airport 10 minutes beforehand). We refused to put Shirley herself in the x-ray machine, so they suggested that we take her to a quiet room nearby where I held her in my arms while the security guys scanned her cage.   
I don't want to imagine how she felt throughout this journey. But I'm happy to see that less than 24 hours have passed since our arrival and she is already getting used to her new home (spent the night in our bed; walking on my keyboard while I'm trying to write this post :-)   
Many thanks to all of you for the helpful advice,   
     Yuval

Not another, I want to breed my dog thread.   
Toy breeds are typically fraught to breed, and many do not birth naturally, causing a great deal of stress all round. I'm especially concerned that the OP seems more concerned with the length of the studs coat than if it's properly scored (or her bitch for that matter). No responsible person would breed without ensuring they have homes for, or will keep any pup's, and that's before conversations about health, facilities etc are even entered into. A litter of pups is noisy, messy, stressful, expensive and bloody hard work, and should never be entered into lightly... regardless of how long the coat is.

Here's a little more to the story (and don't worry, no dogs were harmed). This took place in early June of 1991. After the fighting was over in Kuwait, my unit had to wait it's turn to fly back to the United States. Because we were one of the last units to arrive (Christmas day, 1990) we wound up sitting in the desert outside the city of Al Jahra. By June, the area was declared safe and Kuwaiti citizens were just starting to return to the area.   
With absolutely nothing to do besides wait, we took to getting ourselves back into good physical condition. My buddy Tom and I decided to go for a 3 mile run, and because it was extremely hot and the fighting was over for months, we decided to not bring our rifles with us. When we were about a mile out of our camp, I saw the dog pack. Being a dog lover, I thought "Oh how cute. a bunch of puppies!". The dogs looked at us and thought "Oh how cute. Lunch has arrived".   
The dogs ran towards us and it didn't take long to figure out that they were not looking to have their ears scratched or bellies rubbed. They quickly surrounded us and began their attempts to separate us. We stood back to back and started looking for some kind of weapon for protection. When we tried kicking or punching, the dogs snapped at us. Although they were not big, they made up for it with speed. If a dog doesn't want you to touch him, they can easily jump out of the way and take a bite out of your hand.   
We were in open desert with absolutely nothing around us. We kicked in the sand for rocks and the best we could come up with were small pebbles. Nothing that could hurt a dog, but they didn't know that. Luckily, the dogs had had a few rocks thrown at them before, so they would back off if you looked as though you might throw one. Actually throwing the pebble was a mistake because they knew we were then defenseless.   
So we held our pebbles above our heads and started our way back towards base camp. We had to move slowly or the dogs would lunge at us more boldly. We also had to constantly turn in a circle. If we ignored any angle for too long, the dogs covering that area would move in on us. After about 30 minutes, which felt like hours under the hot sun and the bad situation, a Humvee (American military vehicle) saw us and drove up. The driver got out and fired a few shots into the air. The dogs took off running farther into the desert. The driver got back into his Humvee without so much as saying hello and drove off (a ride back to our base camp would have been the polite thing to offer). Tom and I sprinted the remaining half mile back to base camp where we took our fair share of ribbing for being scared of a bunch of mutts. We never left base camp again without our rifles or in large groups.   
The fact that these dogs could survive out there was absolutely amazing. I have no idea how they were staying hydrated, and what they were eating for food was a pretty grim prospect. I remember a few of the dogs looking as though they were apologetic or unsure if they were doing the right thing. Others looked quite savage as though they never knew about the traditional bond between man and dog. We were just prey to them. The alpha dog of the pack had a real intelligence to his eyes. He looked like a smaller version of an Australian Dingo and was maybe 15 kilograms. From time to time some of the dogs would start backing away like they had doubts about the venture, and the alpha would then bark at us even more fiercely, which would rally the other dogs back into the hunt. We focused our threats of thrown pebbles towards him because all of the other dogs would jump back when he jumped back, and when he moved forward, they all joined in.   
Looking back on this it seems very interesting. At the time I was genuinely in fear for my life. They may not have been big, but with so many attacking at once, I am quite sure they could have killed us.

post:
To do it right, bringing a new dog into a family requires planning and preparation - some things to think about :     
1. English Bull Dogs and Pugs are two very different breeds. Please research both breeds, and determine if either is appropriate for your lifestyle - both here, and in India.   
2.  Please research 'Brachycephalic dogs/ flight risk'.    
3. Please think about the stress of a flight on a puppy - most airlines have a minimum age limit before they allow a dog to fly.  In any event, please think about whether you would have time to properly acclimate him to his travel crate before flying.   
4. Please research importation requirements for dogs into India.   
5. Please consider waiting until you are settled in India - moving countries is always a very hectic time, lots of stress and rushing around. Adding a new dog to the mix would complicate things greatly - for you, and more importantly, make it very difficult on the dog. Why not wait until you have more time free to introduce a dog to your family, to train him, to properly socialize him - then look for a reputable breeder in India.      
Wishing you and your future dog all the best.     
ETA - There's also the SKN to consider; if you are a first time dog owner, still resident in Switzerland, you would be required to take the theory part of the Sachkundenachweis before you purchased a dog - a breeder /Tierheim is not supposed to allow you to take a dog home without proof that you have completed the course. Again, would you have time to do the course before leaving?

The Swiss authorities seem not to care about temporary imports. I've spent hours this past week researching Swiss and UK law (Defra [the UK authority] only knew that prior Swiss rules were withdrawn, and had no notion of what documents are now needed for parrots). But as far as I can tell, so long as I have a CITES certificate (I applied for it today), that's all I need:    
Our parrot and our cat get along famously, and they will stay with us and our daughter in Switzerland for the next six months or so while our London place is renovated.   
I suppose if we are denounced we'll have to borrow or rent a companion for our Figaro.

If you think it is the female, it most likely due to the surgery.  Spaying females can be a pretty in depth procedure, and it is not uncommon that there are complications.  Seems like she is finding soft, comfortable places to pee.  That, to me, indicates something is wrong.  It might actually be uncomfortable for her to go in the litter box. 
Two things to try: 
1.  Separate her somewhere in the house where she will be comfortable with her own litter box.  If the peeing in the rest of the house stops, then you know it is her.  If you don't find pee in her box, then you know something is wrong.  Monitor her behavior because any changes can be symptoms of something else.   
2.  Take her back to the vet and have her checked out.  You can *never* be too cautious in these situations.     
Good luck, and keep us posted...  :]

Perhaps try to mix dry food with the tuna?     
I read before that somebody suggested only offering dry food (or even a wet food in this case - anything but tuna) for up to 3 days at a time.  If there is no medical issue, and just stubbornness, then eventually they will eat if hungry enough.  If after 3 days he doesn't touch it, then offer tuna to feed him, then try again.  But, I would suggest talking to somebody more professional about this before starting.     
Lame question - but have you offered tuna flavored wet/dry food? I sometimes take the water from the tuna fish can and dump it over the cats' dry food.  They think it's a treat.

I just brought my cat from Canada. He was allowed in with his tattoo, no microchip required until next year. I got the info straight from the Swiss authorities and brought along her email confirming his tattoo was acceptable. The email really helped at customs because they started to shake their heads when I said he wasn't micro chipped. As soon as they read it they just wanted their 88 CHF for entry.   
I was really worried about how he would do being stuffed in a carrier under my seat but he took it all in stride and was very calm through the whole flight from beginning to end. The staff were great, the agent even came on board just before we left to move a girl who was seated in the middle seat beside me so that I could have the extra room for my cat during the flight.   
Good luck

This may seem obvious but assume you have checked with the SPA in Nyon. Usually missing pets find their way there if someone cannot find the owner (ie. new to area and no identifying collar). Also, you can post a flyer/poster there as well.    
SPA Nyon  
022 361 61 15        
Also, I live in a neighboring village of Grens and have not seen the posters. May be worth driving to all neighboring villages and placing a poster in the center of the village. After a period of time, cats can travel some distances.   
Also, since you live so close to Signy shopping center, worth placing a poster there on the board as well.   
Another possiblity is placing an add in the local paper, La Cote, do it for the Thursday 'tout menage' edition, and you will get greater reader coverage.   
Edited to add:  Yet another possibility is to place a poster in the inter-communal dechetterie that is a stones throw from Grens, and gets all the visits of the neighboring communes.  It is on the border of Grens, Signy, Borex.  If you haven't visited yet, good to go and the farmers running it are very nice.

Go for a long-hair Chihuahua... they only shed twice a year and your daughter will love grooming it and doing "princess" things with it.   
Also, they are the longest living toy breed with very few genetic problems- your girl will grow-up with it and you will have few worries. Their life span is approximately 15-17 years.   
I've two short-hairs (there is a dog en plus each month in the vacuum bag, because they constantly shed) and I find them the neatest dogs, 'cause they are like cats... but that need to be walked (good for calorie burning).

post: Hey! Does that make me the... wait for it... the leader of the pack?

Actually by law, if you find a "runaway pet" you are obliged to feed it and give it shelter until the owner has been found. This can also be achieved by taking the pet to the Tierschutz or calling the Tierambulanz.   
Art 720 of the Civil Code states that whoever find a lost pet must inform the owner or, if that is not possible, inform the authorities. Article 721 states that such "things" must be stored/kept in an appropriate manner. This has been interpreted to mean that pets in such a situation must be given food and shelter.   
I think Mrs. D was more angry at people encouraging you to "shoo" the problem away rather than carrying on what you were doing which was quite obviously looking out for the cat's interests. And, should an owner berate you for feeding the cat, then I think you have enough arguments to quieten them down.   
A) You were doing your civic duty 
B) Given the cat had no name tag, how could you possibly know who to call

Hi Yuna   
First, you need to decide on the airline, they might not even fly your pets, so this you should know first.   
Second, decide how would you like to fly you pets, there are normally 2 options, depending on the airline. 1 is pets fly with you and will be put under your seat. 2 is they will be put with the rest of the suitcases. The costs are fairly different.   
After you decided which airline, you can contact them for further details regarding costs and requirement of the cage. The cage also must meet the ITAT requirements.   
You should also check the local airport and company with connect with your airline (the courtry you are moving to) for any extra fees for landing your pet.    
Since you are leaving from Switzerland, i would suggest you to take Swiss airline, direct flight is the best for your pets since they will be extremely stressful, they will take a couple days or weeks to recover after the move depending on your cats.   
Dont forget to check on the govn. website (the place you gonna be) to make sure you have fulfil all the requirements such as health certificate, rabies etc. If you need to get your pets rabies injection, they wil not be allowed to fly for first 30 days after they are injected.   
Good luck.

Hi everyone   
My girlfriend recently got a dog - a mini Schauzer - and I am really enjoying running with it and getting it fit.  I have heard that the going rate for dog walking in Zurich is 30CHF per hour and was thinking for that rate I could surely do something much better and run and play with the dog to increase its fitness.   
I just wanted to guage interest if anyone out there has an active breed dog that is missing the necessary exercise and hence is overweight or engaging in destructive behaviour in the apartment.  If so I could get a couple of dogs together and go running with them, or swimming in the lake with them, play frisbee, catch etc.  Combined with a good diet your dog could be fit in a month or two if it isn't already.   
I wouldn't be interested in working with aggressive dogs and the dog would need to be sociable with other dogs so i can take a couple of them together.  I work full time so it would need to be in the weekday evenings after 6.30pm.  I could come and collect from you and the areas of interest are Zurich (where I work) or Zug/Cham (where I am living).   
If someone wants to track the progress of their dogs running then I can easily provide a map via my GPS running watch of where they went and you can see the average speed etc etc.     
If people are interested please let me know and you can PM me if necessary.  Ideally I would like at least 2 dogs that I can take at the same time to get the idea off the ground.  Based on level of interest etc I can decide whether to go ahead and rates etc.   
Cheers 
P

Thank you so very kindly for the time and the info .. I'll certainly attempt the links you have given me and be on the lookout.  If not we could always start something that's not around eh?   Enjoy the lovely weekend!

I was sleeping and my then young cat wanted me to wake up, so he did his usual "jumping up and down on the boss' head" routine. By coincidence, he threw my reading glasses on the floor, which I had parked on my bedside table. Of course, I picked them up and told the cat to never ever ever do this again. And I can be grumpy as hell early in the morning.   
What he learned from this was: Throw the glasses down is the quickest way to wake the boss up. Who cares, that he isn't happy about his glasses being thrown on the floor, after boss gets up, first thing is food for the little zoo anyway. We're hungry, therefore glasses must fly. Howgh!   
Then he kept on thinking further like: What else could we throw down from somewhere and what's going to happen then? How about this nice video-camera there on the shelf, could be fun...    
When I figured out, why he threw everything down from everywhere, it was clear, that he was basically playing fetch with me   Took me quite a while to reverse this behaviour.   
Now, he is allowed to throw empty pet-bottles to the floor and then he gets the caps to play with. it's much cheaper, than if he throws cameras and I take them to the repair shop...

Hi Meloncollie   
Thank you for your fantastic and invaluable post.   
I think it is prey drive and territory that are the main issues here.   
Yes the owner got bitten when she intervened.  I know we're not supposed to, but if I had a little dog and a big dog attacked, I would probably do the same thing!  Heart over head.   
Holly seems to have a fixation with small white animals.  We have been walking her on the lead (with a halter - will get basket type muzzle) and we have noticed she whines and tugs when she sees small white animals (whether they be dogs, cats, rabbits).  There is no aggression toward people - just small white furry things ...    
We've been exercising in the backyard under constant supervision.  Neither of the dogs are allowed out without supervision.  Thanks for suggesting this because it just reinforced my own decision on it.     
We will try all your suggestions to see what we can do and get on with the professional training.  If the worst comes to the worst and it has to be a management option, then management it is.

I have to agree with you, I think the face-to-face confrontation level here is quite low but the behind-your-back SLAP in the face quite high. You mind your own business, think you are doing the right thing and then  , the owner or landlord abruptly sends you warning letters. Luckily, it hasn't happened to me yet, but many a friend (and foe) have had these kind of issues.   
Hopefully, instead of indirectly sending me a message of being unhappy about my cat, they will come by and knock on the door. I'd rather not get the ol "Excuse me, may I have a cup of sugar? And oh by the way, I poisoned your cat this morning."   Talk about trying to avoid confrontation and communication.   
You have to DRAG your cat outside?! I have to fight my little one tooth and nail to keep her INSIDE. And let me tell you, she has sharp little teeth.

post:
I attended my first theoric lesson yesterday evening with two work colleagues. It was long, almost 4    hours but i didnt notice the time pass by.    
We were surrounded by dogs that were staying at the dog hotel. All dogs were sleeping quietly through the class. No conflicts whatsoever. That alone, made me pay more attention to what she had to say.   
The Natural Dogmanship method is brill. It all makes sense. But i have to carry on many adjustments to our daily life with our dog, which is good as long as it makes her feel safer and stable.    
Attending to these lessons with an open mind really gives you knowledge about your dog and your dog's needs from a completely different perspective.  I am very pleased so far.    
We have the first practical lesson next monday but i have tried some of the stuff she told us and the result is quite amazing!    
Sadly, the books and information about this method is nowhere to be found in english but if someone is interested in reading a bit more, and are still looking for a trainer, do read and i can give you the contact info of this place.

post:
As you are in ZÃ¼rich, here is a list of Tierheime in the canton:       
Tierheim PfÃ¶tli has a good reputation.   
A list of Tierheime in other cantons can also be found on the Tierschutz site. Don't let geography be a deciding factor; Switzerland is a small place, and traveling the length and breadth of the country to adopt a dog who tugs at one's heartstrings is frequently done.     
Be aware that some shelters require a handover fee, to aid in the (sometimes significant) costs the rescue incurs in taking care of your pet.   
----   
(Volunteer hat on...)   
Is there really no way that you can keep your dog?    
(You don't need to answer that here -  but I hope that you have looked into all possibilities to try to keep him. After all, when we take on a pet it is with the understanding that we have made a life-long commitment.)   
---   
If you   give up your pet, please do all that you can to help him find a good forever home. It will take work on your part to find a good Tierheim, and there is a chance that it may take time before a rescue place is available. .    
Giving the rescue as much information as possible about your dog's good -  and perhaps difficult - points is important. Absolute honesty will help your dog find the right people this time around.    
And please if you are giving the dog up through no fault of his own, make that very clear to the rescue. Again, this will help considerably to finding him a new home.    
Give the rescue as much information as possible about his health, give them copies of his vaccination records, a summary of the training he has had to date - as well as the training that is missing. Can he live with children, and if so, what ages? Can he live with other dogs? If so, are there any concerns over living with a dog of the same sex? Can he live with cats? Can he live with small furries? Can he live with livestock?    
If he/she is not yet spayed/neutered please have that done before you give your dog up - it will save the rescue much needed funds, and is the right thing to do.   
Wishing your dog all the best - may he soon find a family who will truly commit to giving him the forever home he deserves.

post:
I think some of ya'll missed my point and missed the point of the article.   
It isn't about being "fit" as much as being healthier in general. Having someone there to help motivate you and give you encouragement without the judgment entailed in human friendships can go a long way to helping someone overcome issues they may be having.   
Your dog isn't going to wonder why you're walking woozy if you're dizzy, they're not going to wonder about your limp or even if you felt like going out without a shower (depressed, hungover or even simply lazy)... they just want to go out and enjoy the walk.

Anybody interested in house/pet sitting for 6 weeks from late June to early August in Engelberg? We have two friendly Australian Shepherds (age 11 and 15). The younger one likes to go on hikes but the older one can only handle short, level walks. The house has a small lawn that needs to be mowed once every couple of weeks (20 minutes max).   
The house is located on the edge of the main town (5 minute walk to the Dorfstrasse). Engelberg is very nice in the summer with endless hiking possibilities, decent mountain biking, tennis, golf, swimming, ice rink, etc.,...   
Ideally this would be for a retired/unemployed individual/couple who would be around town most of the time and not leaving the dogs unattended for hours on end. Daytrips are not an issue as there is a fenced in yard but we would prefer that they not be left alone on a daily basis. It would also be good for a family with some young kids who want to enjoy the mountains for a few weeks (we have 3 young kids (2, 4 and 6) and the dogs are great with them).    
We would be willing to pay a nominal fee for this service but we don't want somebody who is just looking for a job. We want someone that likes dogs and likes to be in the mountains primarily and has some spare time to enjoy them.   
Send me a pm if you are interested or want some more details. Thanks.

I attended this dog school with my dog as part of the BVET requirements here when he was much younger:       
The school is based in Albisgutli compared to others which are quite far out.    
The trainers there are also available for individual training. I rate Carolina Jaroch really highly. I am sure she does private lessons if the timing is right, but she can be quite hard to reach on the phone. She speaks decent English if needed.    
Good luck and tell her that Oskar's mum sent you

I did the course at the end of last year, despite having had a long experience with dogs. There was nothing on the course which was new for me, other than information about the Swiss regulations. I'll be doing the 'praxis' course soon. The course trainer knew I knew this too, but we went through the motions.   
Neither of these courses come cheap, but I think these price and time barriers are intended to put off anyone who is only casually interested in looking after a dog, which is a good idea in my mind, since owning a dog is time-intensive and costly. If it reduces the number of abandoned dogs, then I'm all for it.   
Other countries (notably the UK) are bringing in identical rules.

post:
I live in one of the  small towns just south of Bern. We registered our dog within 10 days at the gemeinde, and then visited the vet afterward. We didn't need to show insurance or registration in ANIS to register and pay tax (my tax is CHF80 per year), but we did all of this  in August 2007, and things may have changed with the Federal Dog Control stuff.    
It depends on where you live, of course, but our gemeinde is just one building, so we did one thing on one floor and went upstairs for the animal stuff. If you live in Bern itself, it might be a bit more complicated.
We swing by the vet for every little thing cause I'm pretty paranoid (have very little cat experience, and being human, little frame of reference). Costs a fortune, but better safe than sorry.

Yes, my Bonny is pretty much like Simon's Cat... if she can tell I'm waking up, she'll start attacking my feet, especially if they're out of the covers.    
Also, she brings her toys to our bed as if we'll play with her or maybe to show them off as if she's killed them... we wake up with all sorts of cat toys at the foot of the bed (   ), including her newest favorite - q-tips (aka cotton swabs) - some of which she fished out of the bathroom trash.     (I've taken now to giving her fresh ones from the cabinet to keep her from dragging used ones around the house - and into my bed.)

You can email 
Gabriela Capraro <info@hundeschule-capraro.ch>   
She runs courses for gun dog and search exercises as well as the usual. She speaks good English too (if you don't speak a lot of German). Her training venue is about 15 minutes' drive from Zug town.       
Talk to her; she's very approachable and professional.

I was told by a employee working in a shampoo production, the shampoo for dogs is basicly the same and does not differ from those for humans. It is probably only bad if you use a strong parfumed shampoo on dogs because of their sensible nose. 
You can`t go wrong with baby shampoo.   
But I would be carful washing the dog because of dandruf, it could be you make it worse because of degreasing the oily skin or even the washings did cause that. 
As long he did not play in mud I would just brush the dog .

Changing pads are waterproof, and when I say 'water'... Basically, you just have to roll them and throw them away, no need to mop the floor.    
The problem with newspapers is also that on linoleum the wet ink tend to 'print' the lino, and it's very difficult to get rid of it.   
The babies' pads cost 10.-/10, so the Casino brand is cheaper. But they are all much cheaper than the 'doggie kind' anyway.   
Casino is a French brand of supermarkets, but we have one in the centre of Lausanne. No idea about Zurich though. Perhaps they have that kind of items in Lidl? Anyway, it would be cheaper than a pharmacy.

post:
LOL.... mopp been there. MG had all three dogs for a walk in France last summer, as she approached a garden at the end of the chemin, the dog who sometimes walked wth us appeared. MG didn't notice it, but the three of ours did.... apparently she 'waterskied' on the gravel for about 10 meters, but couldn't make the turn into their garden and hit the deck. To be unceremoniously dragged for a little while before releasing the leads.... much to the bewilderment of the French family who were sitting having a relaxing rose  .    
She appeared at the house about 2 hours after she set off, slightly grazed, with 3 soaking dogs as our three, plus their dog and 2 kids had been playing in the their pool, but feeling no pain as the French folk though it was so funny they got her sozzled with shouts of a la Benny Hill

I left my cat behind as I now live in a second floor apartment. He loved to be out roaming  and I knew I just couldn't lock him in going from a free spirit to an indoor cat at 12 years old.    
I still have the guilts but I get updates on his new family, he is loved and has settled very well, still with a nice catflap into a very large garden. So this helps me to deal with the emotions!   
I would say leave him where he is, the slight change will suit him far better.    
Good luck making your decision, I know how hard it is.    
Gal x

post:
And, if you wish to look further afield, here is the Tierschutz Switzerland-wide database of homeless animals:       
I will always advise those looking for a canine companion to consider rescue first - so many wonderful dogs looking for homes, the need is so great. Most dogs end up in rescue through no fault of their own. You will find all manner of dogs in rescue, from puppies to (already trained   ) adults to seniors - from pure breeds to delightful one of a kind mixes. All my guys are rescues - and I thank doG every day that I have been given the privilege of sharing my life with them.     
However, if you feel that rescue is not the route for you, then please only go to a reputable breeder. NEVER buy a dog from a pet shop - chances are those poor puppies on display in a shop window, - deprived of the opportunities for socialization and learning so critical at that age - came from a puppy mill (or the more accurate, less fluffeh term: battery farmed dogs   ). No breeder of any worth or ethics would ever consider allowing a puppy to be sold via a pet store.    
(In fact I don't think it's even legal to sell puppies in pet stores in Switzerland... someone please correct me if I'm wrong.)   
A good breeder will not sell you a puppy via the internet shipped to your door, nor will a good breeder meet you at some highway rest stop to dump off a puppy. Again, these are all signs of dodgy battery farmers.   
Dodgy breeders - whether battery farmers or clueless BYBs - don't do health or temperament checks of the parents, such folk care little for the genetic health of the line - meaning the cute puppy you buy may be seriously ill. Battery farmers often breed in appallingly cruel conditions - the dogs are treated as little more than machines, and dumped or killed once no longer profitable.  It is filthy, vile trade - please do not support it.   
A good breeder will require you to meet him far in advance of bringing a pup home - many even have waiting lists well in advance of conception. A good breeder will grill you carefully to determine if you can indeed provide a good home for one of his dogs. (A good rescue will make you jump through the same hoops.) A good breeder only breeds dogs who are genetically and temperamentally healthy, socializes the pups in a nurturing environment - giving your puppy the best start in life.   
The BVet has a good brochure on the subject: "Augen Auf beim Hundekauf".       
To find a reputable breeder, see the SKG (the Swiss Kennel Club) website, under ZÃ¼chtertafel:       
But even before you take that step, please research the different dog breeds. Think about breed characteristics, and think hard about your lifestyle and what you can offer the dog. Look for a breed whose needs match your lifestyle.   
And then - under the new Animal Welfare Law, if you are a first time owner you will need to take the theory class of the Sachkundenachweis   you purchase your pup.   
And, again by law, within the first 12 months of ownership, you and your dog will need to complete the practical course.   
See:       
OK - hopping off my soap box now.    
Wishing you and your future four-legged friend all the very best.     
ETA - Prices:   
Rescues ask for an adoption fee; this varies. My guys' adoption fees ranged from CHF 400 to â¬800.   
A puppy from a good breeder will be expensive - think thousands.     
ETA II:   
Fahad, forgive me for jumping back on my soapbox, but in your other post you mention that you are here on a gap year, afterwards you will be moving on to complete your studies. Will you be able to bring your dog with you when you move? Bear in mind that when you take on a dog you make a commitment for the  next 10-15 years. OK - lecture over.    
.
Never do an ultimatum you are not ready to carry on with! If you do, make sure you are ready for the consequences...

post:
That's a BAD idea. Goldfish should never released in the wild because they badly mess with local ecosystems. They turn into pests.   
And even if you find a public pond with goldfish in it already (in a park for example) it is a bad idea to drop yours in it, because yours may be carrying infectious diseases (ichtio is fairly common in aquarium fish, and often is latent) that would spread and eventually kill all the other goldies (and other fish) in the pond.   
Besides I think in Switzerland you can be fined if you're caught releasing your goldfish in a pond. They have introduced some new strict rules about pets a few months ago, some of which specific for goldies (even dropping a "dead" goldie in the toilet is now forbidden).

I have plenty of experience with this situation, as all my life we have added kittens to my home. And you are right, your cat is probably very lonely being alone during the day, and I did the same thing for my cat about two years ago. I didn't necessarily want another cat but knew it was better for my love (who was definitely lonely).    
A few simple guidelines, and there should be no problem with the integration. 
1. It doesn't matter the sex of the first cat or the second for that matter. I prefer males, so I never get a female (and have never had a problem). What matters is the AGE of the cat. If you want things to really go off without a hitch, you have to get a kitten and preferably a young one at that (no older than 12 weeks in my opinion). There is a dominance issue that has to be worked out naturally; so for your cat, he considers your house to be his territory and he thus has to feel like he is in control of the situation (even though he really isn't) when a stranger (ie-the kitten) arrives. So make sure to let this play out. There will be hissing and growling, but it will work itself out for sure.   
2. If/when you get the kitten, make sure to keep them separated from each other for at least a week. Normally, I acclimate the kitten in the bathroom b/c it is the perfect location for controlling messes while litter training as well. You can do occasional 'supervised' visits where you introduce them to each other with you around, and as time goes by (and dependent on your cat's reaction), you can make these more frequent until separation is no longer necessary.    
The only other thing I can say is to make sure that the new kitten has a clean bill of heath from the vet just so that no diseases are spread. This can be a problem.   
Otherwise, I hope you enjoy your new kitten (and your cat does too)!    
Julie :]

post:
Amen to that!     
Hope your doglet is feeling a bit better today.   
Not knowing all the relevant details I'm hesitant to second-guess your vet... But as a general rule:   
If you are uneasy with the approach your vet has taken, speak to her - ask her why A and not B. She should have given you a full explanation and discussed the whys and wherefores of her treatment plan with you before proceeding.   
There can be many ways to treat a given condition - one is not necessarily right and the other wrong - rather, the question is often what is most appropriate for an individual in a given situation. I expect my vet to discuss available options and outcomes, and together we decide which approach is best for my mutt.    
I firmly believe that an owner has to be respected as an equal partner in all decisions concerning the treatment of our animals. (It took me a couple of tries before finding a vet whose ideas meshed with my own.   )   
I've run into a few vets (and doctors   ) who've shown a somewhat patronizing attitude towards owners/patients - who perhaps don't give the layman credit for the general knowledge that comes with being an experienced owner. Or perhaps some owners in your vet's practice may not feel comfortable doing their own first aid or after care, hence the request to have you bring your dog in so often?  But - again bearing in mind that I don't know the details of your dog's condition and so can only speak in generalities -  I'd ask point-blank why the vet feels the need for follow up visits so often.  If an owner feels competent to do the after care, my vet often prefers him or her to do so, as the animal is far less stressed at home. And keeping the stress levels down aids recovery.   
Hopefully your vet will address your concerns to your satisfaction.   
Oldhand has hit the nail on the head - listen to your gut instinct. Both in treating your dog now, and in assessing any owner/vet relationship.     
Hope your guy's toe heals quickly, and that the recovery period isn't too boring for him   - or stressful for you.

From my experience in the pet industry Demodex can be quite common in juvenile dogs and especially those prone to skin problems (i.e. staffies, weimaraners, shar peis, etc) and the vet we were working with used an Ivermectin shot that generally got them through it quite quickly. 
Ivermectin is also used by the guinea pig association of WA and the rabbit society to get rid of mites quickly (in the part of Oz I come from mites are a big problem). 
Perhaps discuss this option with your vet? Good luck!

post: Same here.  When I have gone walking on roads which have had salt on them, I rinse my Jack Russell's puppy's paws with warm water when I get home...

We went through something similar several years back, my sympathies to you for being put in this position.    
I think it was said best above - you'll know when it is time. We adopted two kittens who had been quite sick and recovered - but one hadn't really (the original disease mutated) and a couple of days after we brought them home he began to quickly decline. It turned out he had the wet version of  , which is a swift killer. His sister that we adopted was fine, as was their sister we'd left at the shelter (or so we thought). A week or so after our boy had to be put down, we brought home his sister. A month or so later, she ended up with the dry version of that horrible disease, she was constantly low-grade ill, sometimes quite ill. We knew when it was time for her, she told us, and we put her down on Christmas day 2003.    
Your other kitty will also suffer from the loss of your kitten, so don't forget extra love, treats and other special things for it. Our remaining one went into a deep kitty depression for a couple of months, constantly looking for her sister and moping.    
Your little boy seems to have a great handle on this. I hope all can go as smoothly as possible for you.

post:
Although I probably should have put this under the Family Matters section, I'm posting here because this applies specifically to pet owners.   
We are a year away from being eligible to apply for Swiss citizenship, but among the things stopping me: I am concerned that I might not be able to ensure that my dogs are adequately cared for after my death if my will had to follow Swiss inheritance law.    
As an Auslander, I've claimed Heimatrecht and set up a trust in my will that ensures my dogs are provided for financially for the rest of their lives - the balance then goes to the rescue group who will care for them. But if I understand it correctly, if I were a Swiss citizen setting up such a trust  (which means the bulk of the estate goes outside the family, and some of the folks who would be obligatory heirs get zip) is not allowed.   
The family members who would be obligatory heirs under Swiss law are not really animal lovers; it worries me greatly that my taking Swiss citizenship could mean that the mutts would essentially be left to their goodwill. Volunteering with a rescue, I've seen it all too often: The family promise Mum that they will look after her beloved four footed friend - but before Mum is even in the ground poor Fido is abandoned without so much as a backward glance.   
So a question for pet-owning Swiss citizens: How do you ensure your animals are provided for after your death, given the restrictions of Swiss inheritance law?    
All info and advice is much appreciated.   
(I know that there are threads about wills as Auslanders, but this is applies specifically to writing a will as a pet owning Swiss citizen, which I don't think has been covered - please forgive me if I've missed something discussing this aspect.)
thread: Providing For Pets Under Swiss Inheritance Law

post:
Are you asking me?  
My dog traveled in the cabin with me. She traveled under the seat in front of me. Well, except on the way back where she actually stayed under the seat of the three year old behind me as his feet didn't touch the ground!    
I made the reservation at the time of booking the flight as there are only 2 dogs allowed per flight. So I had to check that the flight I wanted to take had room for the dog. She was considered excess baggage & I paid per kilo. I can't remember how much I paid, though. It's on the Swiss website.  I only every fly Swiss. I should have mentioned that so I don't know about other airlines & she only ever flies in the cabin with me. I never put her in the hold. You must check the regulations per airline as they vary. They also vary per destination (i.e. No dogs in the cabin to UK and no dogs at all on EasyJet).   
She slept the whole way and didn't make a sound. She seemed quite Ok and was bright & happy when she arrived. Much happier & brighter than I was! The flight was 8 hours to & 7 hr back.    
Yes, dog are generally banned from restaurants except outside cafe's usually allow them.  Since she stays in her bag, I did bring her to a couple of restaurants and just didn't mention it... No one ever notices her. (Yes, I know I shouldn't do this.... ) When they did notice her they all wanted to see her out of the bag. After all these regs are not made by the restaurant, but by the law.   
Recommendations: the travel case can not exceed a certain size (this will be given by the airline). The problem with this is that they don't tell you which direction measurements must be. Thus the bag I took was under the size limit, but didn't fit under certain seats & I had to change seats to have a seat without legs or other metal peices in the way.  You can't really avoid this as they don't know which seats have legs or whatever under them... Also, your dog should be used to staying in the case/bag. My dog is quite used to this so she doesn't get upset when she's closed in the bag. They do not let you take the dog out of the bag & it really isn't safe for the dog to be out anyway.    
If you have more questions don't hesitate to ask.

Our pets were all in the cargo hold of the plane from Tokyo and the Captain came to talk to us about the temperature in the cargo hold as he wanted to be sure it was right for the parrot as well as the dogs.   They arrived here perfectly fine. It is better for the pets that the hold is dark as the pets sleep. They don't hear humans talking, smell food being served, etc.   
I don't know what "horror stories" you are referring to. I have worked with many pet shippers over the years and not once has this been my experience.   
Many animals travel better in the cargo hold than in the cabin as they don't have nervous owner fussing over them, plus in the cargo hold they can have a larger, sturdier and roomier kennel fitted with a water bottle, which is essential for a long flight to avoid dehydration. How does one affix a water bottle to a carry bag? The extra space in first class doesn't change anything from my perspective.   
I once sat next to a passenger with a dog that whined most of the flight. It was awful.   In first class, if your dog does anything but sleep, you are going to annoy others who opted to be in first class for a reason.    
If you are travelling with your dog, you don't need to use the services of a pet shipper. My pet shipper always recommends pets travel with the owner (though not necessarily in the cabin). This keeps the costs down.

If you've been extremely consistent about not letting the dog on to the sofa whilst you are at home, chances are, he is doing that because that spot on the sofa is the most comfortable - even more so than his blanket / bed.    
The crate is a fantastic idea, as long as its not for too long periods. And its never too late to crate train the dog.    
However, another possible solution is to purchase large plastic sheets that the painters used for protecting furniture / floors during a job, and put it over your sofa when you are out. Unsightly at first but its not comfortable for dogs (feel and sound wise). He will in time, find no more joy in jumping on the sofa for a snooze.

Check out the service provider thoroughly; test safety measures in place, quality of care, attention to individual needs, ability (and willingness) to follow owner's instructions, understand the provider's view on animal care, visit unannounced wherever possible, check references carefully, etc. Discuss the 'what ifs'.    
And be aware that not everyone offering pet care services is qualified to do so, or takes the responsibility seriously - or is even a pet lover.    
Unfortunately.

post:
As you mentioned puppies rather than adult dogs - I just to want to emphasize this from the BVet link given by temiatwork:   
In the case of puppies too young to have completed the vaccination course and eligibility period:   
"Animals aged less than three months may only be imported into Switzerland from the EU unvacci-  
nated if they are accompanied by and dependent upon their mothers or if a veterinary certificate can be  
provided showing that they have been kept at the place where they were born since birth and have  
never come into contact with wild animals which could have been exposed to an infection with rabies. "   
If the dog you are importing is fully vaccinated according to the BVet requirements, this of course does not apply.   
Also, please bear in mind that under the new Tierschutzgesetz you are required to complete the theory course   acquiring a dog if you are a first time dog owner. So, if that applies to you, best to get that out of the way well in advance of bringing your puppy home.   
And, don't forget the practical course requirement - you and your puppy have to complete that within the first year of ownership.   
Wishing you and your new pup all the best.

I'm so very, very sorry.   
It is never easy to come to terms with the loss of a beloved pet - but when such a tragedy occurs out of the blue you will of course be in shock.   
Grief hits us all differently, the ways we need to work our way through the pain differs as well.  Once when I found myself unable to cope with the loss of a very special dog (I was in Switzerland, with no one to talk to in my own language)  I turned to the Blue Cross Pet Bereavement Helpline in the UK:       
The counselors at the Blue Cross were a great help to me - perhaps you might find them helpful, too.   
---   
I hesitate to say this, as now is probably not the time - but when you feel able to cope perhaps there should be a follow-up discussion with the sitter. (Is the sitter a professional, registered with the BVet? Is she insured for her commercial activity? How did your contract deal with safety and responsibility issues?) 
---   
For now, please concentrate on yourself and your family - and cherish the memories of the time you had with your dog.   
I'm truly sorry, and wish you and your family strength to see you through this difficult time.

Adoption is a great route to go if you dont have a preference for any breeds. I am so glad that a dog will be able to find a new home with you and your family.    
Now will also be a great time to start looking for where you can start taking the legally required BVET courses. If you are a first time dog owner, since Sept 2008, its obligatory for all first time owners to take a theory course before you acquire the dog.   
Once you get your dog, you'll have to take it on a compulsory 5 sessions course on basic obedience and the different but common situations that your dog will be exposed to (trams, approaching dogs /strangers etc).        
Keep us posted!

post:
Mmm, spaying or castrating your dog is an individual decision. I've heard not nice comments from other people with regards to my recent decision to neuter my dog but I dont really give a rat's bottom.    
There are advantages behavioural and health wise for having your dog neutered but leaving them entire doesnt mean that they will definitely suffer health problems - hence my point about it being an individual decision. I dont think less of people who dont.    
But yes, I neutered my dog mainly because I want to prevent future health problems in that respect. Its a case of rather-be-safe-than-sorry -- much to my husband's dismay and protests.    
Afterall, I dont have any plans to breed him etc. With regards to behaviour, I see not much of a change. Still playful and cheeky,  but he was never aggressive or territorial to begin with..    
People also tend to neuter their dogs to calm them down but mine's still as boisterious as ever (though nothing a good run or long walk wont fix).  
I have to say though, he has since decrease his markings outside and stopped humping my husband and his bed.

We've just imported our 2 dogs from the uk.  They arrived yesterday.  If your animals are to go over the borders, out of Switzerland, say if you go on holiday, then your  animals will need the rabies vacc to be up to date.  My uk  vet told me that we musn't let this lapse even by one day, because then you'll have to go through the whole rigmorole of vaccine + blood test once again.  However, if you remember to do the booster before the 3 years is up then no blood test is required.   
I got varying advice regarding importing/exporting pets.  The official line is that if they fly directly into Switzerland they do not need anything as Switzerland is Rabies free.  However, I was then told that no customs vet would allow a dog out of the airport without full load of vaccinations.   
The best advice I got was from B-vet on Melancollie's recommendations.  They reply promptly to all your questions and in English.  They are very very clear.   
The English (Defra) however, is another matter; tardy replies and then the most I got out of them was "we don't know"!!!   
Good luck.  My boys are now happy to be here.   
Sx

Neil,   
There are a lot of people offering casual pet sitting services - some good, some not. Demand is very high during the school holidays, so I would think that there is opportunity for you. If that is the kind of service you are considering offering, think about what you can do to stand out from the crowd.    
In contrast, there are very few people offering professional in-home sitting, as the person I finally found does. As she is fully booked months in advance, I assume that there is indeed demand for more of this kind of service.   
If you study the Animal Protection Law of 1 Sept 2008, and if you keep your eyes on the proceedings going on in the WBK and their proposal working it's way through the federal legislative process, you'll see that being the person in charge of a dog has become rather complex.  (Offering cat care services is far less complex, as I understand it - but I am not a cat owner, so am probably not au fait... ) Speak to the Bvet, speak to an insurer, speak to the Gemeinde and cantonal tax authorities about requirements.   
A few random thoughts and rhetorical questions, from my perspective as a customer (dog owner):    
First,  think about how you will structure the business. For my part, I want the sitter to be legally self employed. I wish to be a customer, not an employer - and do not want to be put in a position where I could be construed to be an employer with an employer's liabilities. If a sitter is working illegally he/she could be putting the customer at risk, in addition to running afoul of employent law one's self.    
In addition to properly registering with the tax authorities, some dog sitters need to comply with Bvet regulations under the new Tierschutzgesetz. The owner's insurer might refuse to cover damages if the sitter is not fully compliant, leaving the customer very much in the lurch.  (Think of the recent incident in Schaffhausen...)   
Pet sitting is not a casual job - it's a big responsibility. If I have booked the sitter, I expect the sitter to fulfill that commitment. Most customers cannot easily change plans, re-schedule flights, etc - which means a sitter should have back-up, in agreement with the client, in case of emergencies on his/her part.    
As mentioned, I use an in-home service - my sitter moves into my home in my absence, living there 24/7 to care for my dogs. During the time I've booked, caring for my mutts is not something the sitter does for a few hours on the side - it's a full time job. Even if you take the pet into your home, the commitment is the same - would your family be able to cope with that? Do you have children or pets of your own? If so, how would the business impact them - and would your children/ own pets/ home commitments limit the kind the pets you could care for?   
I expect demonstrable experience or qualifications. I need a sitter who is conversant in behavioral theory, whose philosophy and methods mesh with mine. I would quiz a sitter thoroughly on how he/she would handle a variety of situations, and I would set up a test period to evaluate the sitter's skills. Think about how you could convince a prospective customer that you are the right person to care for his/her pets. And, what would you do if a customer's ideas differed from yours - think about who you want your customers to be.   
I expect a sitter to be fully conversant in local, cantonal and federal animal welfare and control laws. And of course, I expect a sitter to comply with those laws. For instance, I see you are in canton ZH - be aware that new dog control legislation is in the pipeline following the cantonal vote last November.   
I expect a sitter to be able to deal with veterinary emergencies - which means knowing basic first aid, having a good enough command of the local language to get through the answering service gatekeepers to get the dogs timely veterinary care or to speak to the clinic staff, and having a car to transport the animal to the emergency clinic if needed.  A sitter needs to draw up a detailed agreement with the client as to how emergencies are handled.    
Are you willing/able/qualified to deal with special medical needs, such as dispensing meds, handling pets with limited mobility, diabetes, epilepsy, etc? Could you care for an incontinent pet? Could you handle pets with behavioral challenges? And if so, think about the liability issues surrounding taking on such responsibilities.    
If you choose to take pets into your home rather than watching them in the customer's home, do you have permission from the landlord to do so if you rent? Do you have permission from the neighbors if necessary? Think about noise and neighborhood tolerance levels.   
And if you take pets into your home, is your home safe for animals? Stairs? Hazzards? Is your garden securely fenced in? These are issues to discuss with your insurer.   
I am admittedly a demanding customer   , as I have dogs who are a bit of a challenge. My sitter offers me peace of mind, knowing my mutts are in safe hands. For that I - and many dog owner in similar situations - are willing to pay a small fortune.    
The right  person, with the right business model, can indeed do well with this gig.    
Wishing you well as you explore this venture...
