Hi abzurich,   
I'd keep a close eye on him until you can get it checked out.   
If it's asthma then the breathing can go into spasm which would need  medical attention because it can deteriorate. If you find he's having to keep his mouth open with tongue out then get him in quick.   
MY cat had asthma and a number of treatments were tried as suggested by our vet:   
1. asthma inhaler as used by babies - absolute waste of time an money and distressing for the cat 
2. pills to be taken daily - did not work  
3. steroid injection - once every 6-8 weeks   
The injections worked best, but was told they may have side affects - she was alot happier on those than the other treatments.   
Still a happy cat, but sadly in the uk while i'm here ......meow

This Labi was socialised from puphood to be gentle and friendly with children. She didn't really have a choice as all the neighbourhood tots wanted to touch her and play with her but most of them knew to ask first, "May I touch your dog?" Some dog-loving fathers even brought their barely-walking babies to pet the pup. The Lab is extra gentle with very small children (indeed it's in their genes to be easy with children).   
So, as per the OP's question, if a dog is not socialised from young to be comfy with children, would more frequent exposure to gentle and not-so-loud children help?   
Another question: Is it OK if a stranger asks to touch the pup but he/she rough-houses with it and makes it too excited? I didn't mind strangers petting her or playing gently with her but thought the rough-housing wasn't good for the dog and with my bad German I could only say, "Nicht so schnell, bitte!"

post:
I used Continental to send Lily from the US to Switzerland two years ago, and found them to be very helpful. What I'm wondering is whether or not the regulations are different when you leave Switzerland versus when you enter. It seems that the regulations might require that you use a shipper when you leave. Seems to be a bit of racket - animal shippers needing business. Or perhaps there have been too many problems.    
Continental ships pets as expedited cargo and the price is based on the weight of the pet and crate. (For example, 65lbs of dog and crate were $800, over 70lbs, $1000. Continental was very good in providing me information about the size of the crate required (enormous), and we really had no problems, despite entering Switzerland with slightly wrong paperwork. But again, this was coming from the US to Switzerland 2 years ago.    
I would call Continental in the United States - the pet safe program number is  +1 832.235.1541         
One other option - KLM, the Dutch airlines has an "Animal Hotel" in Schipol Airport (Amsterdam) and I know that lots of animals are shipped out of A'dam. You might check with them. Air France and KLM are part of the same company (and I think Continental code shares with them), so it may or may not be helpful.    
Edited to add... I just checked here   
and it looks like KLM will only work with a shipper, and obviously AF will only work with one as well. Still not sure about Continental   
This is good to know, if we decide to go back to the US for any lenght of time, we'll have to take Lily and I'll need to plan this, I guess.    
Good luck.

Caroline,   
My Hooligan is an ultra high energy dog - in hindsight, one of the mistakes I made in the beginning was focusing on physical exercise to calm her down. She is extremely fit and can go all day long - but we reached a point where her stamina was such that she needed ever increasing amounts of exercise, she became almost an adrenaline junkie. I could not tire her out physically; I don't live on a farm where she could run free all day, nor do I have a herd of sheep for her to control. I soon realized I needed other ways to engage and stimulate her: brain-training does just that.   
I've found that interactive games where my dogs and I work together to be the most fun, and are best mental work out for my guys. Most of the things we do are simple games easily incorporated into my daily household routine.   
I use a lot of clicker training - which is really just form of operant conditioning. First, here is a good site explaining the basics:       
I use this method to teach my dogs something new, something they might not instinctively understand. And then I try to turn training into a game.    
For instance, my house often ends up littered with dog toys; you can't move without stepping on a squeeky. So when it's time to clean up, I call the the dogs in to play the pick-up game. On my command, the dogs search the room for toys - when one of my guys finds one, he/she picks it up and puts it into the toy box - and gets a reward. On to the next toy... and the next...    
I do the same when gardening - the dogs bring me my gloves, a trowel, put the plastic pots in a pile for recycling, etc.    
My friend taught her amazing lab to sort laundry using clicker training. I haven't gone that far, as I expect my opportunistic sock thief would have a field day - and we would end up barefoot.    
You can use the basic idea to teach your dog anything - the point is to involve your dog in your mundane household activities. Ask yourself, what part of this task could my dog do? Turn a chore into a game - the dog loves being with you, figuring out what you want and how to do it, getting praise from you. The dog enjoys the game, and the activity reinforces your bond - and the mental exercise really does tire the dog out.   
There are lots of videos on YouTube demonstrating clicker basics, as well as how to teach games/tricks.   
Teaching 'search' has been very handy - I can use this in so many ways, from traditional dog activities like scenting a course, to playing 'find it' games around the house.   
We also play with puzzle toys, where the dog has to figure out how to make something work in order to get a reward. Nina Ottoson makes a fantastic line of dog toys, really brilliant stuff, top quality - and very expensive. As an easier-on-the-budget alternative, I make most of our toys. My husband is into woodworking, so he has done some variations on the Dogbrick - but most of our toys are made of cardboard boxes, plastic bottles, packaging materials - things you have lying around the house. I really like the Spass Mit Hund website - it's packed with great ideas:       
The authors have also written a book, available in English translation "Playtime For Your Dog'.   
Targeting games are another good mental work out - I use targeting a lot with my deaf dog who needs visual rather than auditory (clicker) cues. One game he loves: I give him an array of cards, some round shaped, some square, some star shaped, etc. He has to touch each one differently - star with right paw, round with nose, square with left paw, etc. I'm working on doing this with color variations as well. Targeting can be used for practical applications - a high five and 'gib pfotli' games, for example, are how I desensitized him to give me his paw so I can clip his nails.    
You can also make basic obedience training into a game around the house. My dogs tend to follow me around - usually underfoot, tripping me up.   So taking that natural instinct, I've taught them to off-lead heel - up the stairs, into the kitchen, through doorways, etc. My morning coffee break is a good opportunity to teach a down-stay; our goal is to be able to hold a down for the time it takes me to finish my cuppa.   
Team Training teaches the dog a sequence of steps - turns, weaves, etc., kind of like dog dancing.  The point is that the dog learns to focus on me while doing something that requires concentration. Now, I have no interest in turning my dog into a circus performer - but it's a fun way to teach close-in work. A bit of serendipity - I've found this a very useful distraction/re-focus technique with my reactive dog.   
Yes, my young to middle aged dogs do need a lot of physical exercise - they are herding dogs after all. But I've found that their brains need as much - if not more - exercise as their bodies do - it's all about balance. We play brain-training type games randomly throughout the day, for short periods - a few minutes at a time really is enough. After a good mental work out, my guys usually toddle off to their beds for a nice long nap.  And peace reigns throughout the house.    
I'd encourage you to find a training class or group you could join regularly for socialization as much as for training. The group I go to not only gives me support and encouragement, new ideas and techniques, but through the group the dogs and I have found some good friends.   
All the best to you and your dog.

post:
I am sure you must be relieved. From time to time one of our dogs will limp and it has always been a case where she just sprained something (usually a result of playing football in the garden ). She does have a problem with the patella popping out. Now I wait before rushing to the vet to see if it improves. If the dog does not appear to be in pain, I prefer to wait and see if she gets better.    
If the vet gives something for pain, it should be because the pain is severe and not just a dull pain as otherwise after the pain meds the dog will want to put weight on the affected area, which is not always the best idea. One time she seemed to have done something to her toe....we have no idea how, but she was limping so badly but it was just really painful for her to put weight on that side all because of one toe.    
Another occasion I remember one of the other dogs limping and when I check under her paw and between the toes I found that she had managed to get a wood splinter stuck in her paw. So do check that there is no foreign body there. Sometimes this tickles and the dog will pull her paw away but this is not the same as if she winces when you handle her paw or toes.

Hello,   
Be careful when introducing the new rat! Even though rats are highly sociable creatures, it might be difficult for an ageing rat to accept a newcomer! And traumatising incidents of decapitated or severely injured youngsters are not rare... Could be very shocking for your poor daughter to discover such a scene in the cage!   
It's for you to consider, but if your rat is already old, it might be wiser to compensate the loss of her playmate by tons of attention and cuddles.   
Anyway, all my thoughts go to your poor daughter. I lost two rats due to old age, and it was very difficult. We get so attached to those furry clever things...

Dear Summerrain,   
thanks for your link. I went through it. However, it seems that such a condition is caused by a single worm under the skin especially in the face/neck region while this kitten had hundreds coming out simultaneously from within the skin of his hips. They were not more than 1mm in length each and had a creammy white colour. They were also coming out from within the ears and some also from his mouth. There was no reddening or blood coming out of the kitten's skin/ears or mouth but from how he was opening his mouth and how lethargic he was compared to his siblings, I think they caused quite a lot of discomfort      
The thing I thought most plausible is that the mother cat has something wrong (maybe a worm laying eggs in her which attck the unborn babies) or I don't know what to think. I mean, how could a fly deposit eggs in a newborn kitty and they hatch and get out of the skin by the next day?    
Thanks again for your post, it is always useful to learn about such things.

That's really sad, poor kitty    
From what I've read, problems like that are caused by long term neglect of the teeth, or it could be a symptom of a virus. Feline calicivirus , FIV & FeLV could be the problem, especially if the cat is young, goes outside and has never been vaccinated. If you are bringing the cat into your house and you have cats, please don't let it get near yours - contain it and give the room a good scrub and wash your clothes before letting your cat in or picking him up. Our cat picked up a virus from our clothes, our vet said they are easily transmitted.   
Also from what I've read it is hard to treat, but can be managed with antibiotics, steroids and continues care of the teeth. Our vet only charged us 120 CHF to clean our cats teeth, I thought that was pretty cheap compared to Canada, but it seems like this woman might not have the money to do so...or she just doesn't care.   
To get the cat to eat you can give it some wet food, best to warm it up a bit to make it more appealing.   
If your vet would be willing to help as a charity case, I'd be willing to donate some money to get this kitty some help....I also hate seeing animals suffer.

post:
Now granted I'm not sure how much of this is taken care of by the animal shippers but the official rules we were given last year for bringing a dog here  in order to skip quarantine were:   
First the dog has to have a microchip that is readable by European scanners - the typical US microchips are on a different frequency so you need to go somewhere like Petsmart which will put both in.   
Rabies Vaccine less then 1 year old - and the vaccine has to be verified by:      (its the only lab in the US that does this - your local US vet will draw the samples and send it to them - I think it took us something like 6 weeks to get the results back)   
Then you have to have a vet fill out papers, followed by your state's USDA vet signing off and stamping that everything is in order and meets export rules.       
Then your dog will get to Switzerland and no one will even bother looking at all the papers you absolutely HAD to have to bring the dog here (but of course you have to have them if you actually do get asked).  I think that was everything anyway.  Good luck

As most has been covered I would just like to add that medical emergencies do cost alot here.   
Rencently one of mine* had "hemorrhaging gastritis" and was thankfully saved. The bill came to 849 chf.        *Some of you might remember the "Lulu has gas" thread. It was Lulu who became ill. Btw, she doesn't seem to fart as much anymore.

When we were in Japan the veterinarians there seemed to handle most things in a simpler manner than here. When one of our dogs needed an Xray here and the vet said she would have to anaesthetise her, I was confused and said that would not be necessary. She tried it without and it was fine. One of our dogs is prone to lipomas, and as soon as we would find one, the vet in Japan removed it without cutting or sutures. Here it requires an operation (she continues to get them - it's a condition common to Bassets.)   
I have made an appointment today for our dog to see our "regular veterinarian" and will take it from here.  I have known him for years. We consulted with him from Japan and I trust him.     
I have referred many people to this clinic as communication in English is no problem. 
Will keep you posted.
I think this would be very helpful and a real asset to this new forum area! No doubt melloncolie and Mrs Doolittle have a good idea already about which questions are popular

I'm not in ZÃ¼rich, but if you are up for a trip into the wilds of SZ (Wollerau, just over the cantonal line), I highly recommend:       
Two of my mutts attend classes here - my youngster attended the basics course and has been in   (literally, family dog) classes regularly since then. The trainer is absolutely brilliant with my little whirlwind. And, she deals brilliantly with my... err... foibles, which is what training is really all about. Training classes teach the owner - and you in turn work with your dog.   
I very much like Frau Schuler-Ponte's philosophy of training - she takes a positive, rewards-based approach founded on a solid understanding of canine behavior and common sense.   focuses on socialization and on-going training - for you the owner, and for your dog. The classes are small, 4-6 dogs/owners, and the atmosphere is relaxed.    
My recent addition is deaf; he and I are now doing one-to one training sessions with Frau Odermatt, who handles the senior and handicapped classes. The classes are fun for my doglet, and have been a huge help to me, giving me the confidence I need to work with my new guy.    
HTM, special sessions covering specific or advanced topics and  , (training walks) are offered one to one or in a small group. The school is also affiliated with an Agility club.   
Prices are reasonable. German only, I'm afraid.  Although my High German is far from perfect and my Swiss-German downright awful, I haven't had (much) trouble communicating.    
----   
Two other good schools (again SZ but not too far out of ZH), largely Agility and Obedience focused:           
----   
The SKG website publishes a list of training courses/clubs from it's members: (I don't have personal experience with these.)       
(Click on 'Erziehungskurse' - listed by canton.)   
Or take a look through the Certodog site for an instructor:       
--   
Or, try googling 'Hundeschule' or Hunderziehungskurs'.   
There are lots of good courses out there - if you are looking within a certain area, let me know where and I can ask around for recommendations. Also, ask your vet, ask other dog owners you see out on walks - personal experience is always best.   
The important thing in choosing a class is to understand the instructor's training philosophy and methods - his/her ideas about training should mesh with yours, and should suit your dog's needs. Sadly, there are still some old school trainers around who use fear/punishment techniques - do avoid these. Your best bet is to speak at length with the trainer about his/her ideas, about your dog, and about your goals. Then audit a few classes (without your dog) to ensure that the atmosphere is right for you. Good trainers are happy to have a prospective client do this.

Are the submitted forms processed on a first-come first-served basis?   
Cheers, 
Nick

The whole thing about a CITES certificate is convincing the people that issue the certificate that you acquired the bird legally and that you (or the person you acquired it from) didn't catch the bird in the wilds. The veterinarian in Japan showed me how you can induce vomiting with salt water. The dog won't drink it willingly, so you have to force it down. It's really nasty and difficult to do alone.    
Vomiting will not help in some situations, in fact, vomiting could do more harm. Certain poisons, for example, can burn the esophagus or mouth again on the way up. But in our case it was necessary as the dog ate pebbles from the garden (that's what the xray revealed).   We realised it quickly enough that vomiting was the solution. If hours had lapsed, vomiting would have no effect as the material would already be in the small intestine.    
Fortunately she never did that again.   
I would be extremely careful about inducing vomiting without consulting with a vet first.
thread: What meds to keep on hand?

post:
Although I usually use the combi vaccine, I switched  my guys to the nasal drops a few days ago...   
Apparently there is a lot of kennel cough going around at the moment; my vet said he has seen a significant increase in cases this year.    
There's a good chance that one of mine has been exposed, and if so, that would mean that she could give it to the rest of the crew. So, the vet recommended that we play it safe and re-vaccinate with the nasal drops. (It had been 10 months since she had the combi jab.) I'm keeping all my guys at home for the next two weeks (the incubation period is is usually 5-7 days, but can be from 2-14), just to be safe. And now we wait...   
For all dog owners: If you regularly meet up with a lot of dogs (training classes, sports club, or just come into contact with a number of dogs on your daily walks) or simply frequent areas where dogs congregate, you should discuss the various protection options with your vet, and make a decision with his guidance.   
KC is very contagious; if you think your dog may have been exposed, please keep him/her on lead during the incubation period, and away from other dogs. If he/she has been diagnosed with KC (or any contagious disease), it's the law in many Gemeinden that the dog must be kept on lead until given the all clear from your vet.

Mrs Doolittle has already pretty much said it all... the only thing there is is that you are not allowed to be distracted by something while driving be that a Navi, Mobile Phone or... D O G. So,if your dog is secure somewhere and not with his paws on the steering wheel or distracting you otherwise you'll be ok... For now, but I suspect sooner or later there will be a new law.   
(Disclaimer: This could already be the case in a different Kanton to Zurich.)

A dog off a leash is not a threat, just what you perceive to be, and that is not necessarily the reality of the situation. At the moment there is a program running in our local schools called "Prevent a Bite." I can assure you that kicking a dog will get you into more trouble than standing perfectly still.

I recently bought crates. I posted an ad here and there is info under that thread where others shared their collective wisdom.     
This is what I ended up buying for our 3 dogs..one double cage and one single cage. I had a lot of trouble finding what I wanted but it was worth the effort. Dogs are very happy. The cages fold when not in use though most of the time I just leave them in the car. We have one small cage from the same manufacturer which we keep as a spare for the other cars when we just take one dog with us. What I really like is that all the cages come with two doors, one on the long side and one on the short side. 
Our dogs are not used to cages in the car as before we used these great dog carriers from Japan which were very handy and the dogs liked them because they were open, but the dog can't jump out as there are straps to attach to their collar. I posted a photo of one below. It is a great idea if you rarely take your dog in the car. Also, it is very easy to get a dog in and out of which is necessary if a dog is ill or injured and getting them in a cage is next to impossible.    
As for safety, I see an awful lot of dogs in cars with no cage or carrier of any kind and I think this has got to be a distraction for the driver. There is no law that covers how a dog must travel in a car but I think anything that confines your dog and makes him or her more comfortable is better than nothing at all. I have seen seats covered and the dog's collar attached to a harness, as in the last photo. We have one of those as well though I don't use it at all.   
Our dogs weigh just under 20 kg. For air travel we had a kennel similar to a vari kennel. We sold them all. For the car I find them too closed in. Our dogs like to see out.

Burning the mid-night on this informative post meloncollie!   
I'm not a big fan of leads attached to collars, I prefer show/slip leads.I find them easier to use and provide more control of my dogs...well 2 of them anyway.   
We have 3 labs and 2 responded well to a being on a short slip/show lead high on the neck from early on, and now unless the big boy is desperate for a wee (and that's my fault for leaving to long a gap between walks) they are a piece of cake.    
This techqnique failed miserably with the 3rd, and simply resulted in my shoulder being yanked. Also tried the food reward which is normally a banker for a lab....not this time though. So we switched him to a harness.....bingo, the odd 'I'm a 2 year old trying my luck' tug, but other than that great.   
I guess what I'm saying is that what has been mentioned in the other posts is all good, but is it good for you dog? Good clear control from you is the most important thing, try one method if it works great, if not move on to the next, but don't loose patience, don't use a choker chain and don't over correct.

There is also a place in Letzi and one in Oberaegeri that offer "pension". The place in Oberaegeri offers "full service" for 1600 I think and otherwise its 1080.   
Julia (who is thinking of buying a horse...)

I had my two cats micro-chipped with Home Again last month - we arrived in Zurich a week ago.  Unfortunately the vet used the old chips that aren't European standard.  What we did do - that other people in a similar situation might find helpful - is borrow a digital scanner to take with us.  The bvet website states non-standard chips are okay if you carry your own scanner.   
There is an organization called Digital Angel that will ship you a scanner free of charge anywhere in the US that you can take with you when you travel.  I just called them and they got it to me within a few days. (800) 328-0118.  You just have to mail the scanner back to them within 30 days.  They take a credit card number in case you don't return it.   
After all that, no one at the airport (on either end) ever asked for any documentation for the cats (we travelled with them in cabin).  Better safe than sorry though.
Qualipet carries it.  There are many locations around the canton including Sihlcity and Dietlikon.

Hi Alanbrito,   
hope you dont mind my thoughts/feedback: after reading your situation, I wanted to just add that whatever decision you take regarding the housing of your dog, it would be a good idea to bring your dog to the place she will be staying,  . If it is a private home, that will of course be better, but you would want to show her that you are "coming back for her" by leaving her there for 30 minutes. Be sure you actually leave, and dont hide round the corner and come back, as she will be on to you. she will understand that this is a temporary place, and wonÂ´t be traumatized when the longer period begins because she will remember her first experience there. It is better on her stress (therefore appetite, play, sleep, etc) to let her go through the fear of abandonment for a few hours in the first visit, than for the longer period.   
 Good luck!

I have very definite ideas as to the best way to care for my own dogs, as do most owners. Some dog owners may agree with me, some might not - I won't get into a debate here between owners, as we presumably know our own dogs' individual characters - and thus their individual needs.    
(Although I'd encourage all dog owners to review the new Tierschutzgesetz , with particular attention to the article on dog ownership and a dog's need for daily social contact...)   
So pax, y'all.    
BUT - anyone offering dog sitting   should be around to interact with the dog most of the day. Afterall, that's why one pays a sitter.  In most cases it would be inappropriate for someone to set him/herself up as a sitter and leave the dog 10 hours.    
Remember, folks - under the new Tierschutzgesetz (discussed in the Federal Dog Control thread...   , the discussion of the latest law starts with post 164) dog sitters  - preliminary definition is anyone who receives money or other compensation, although this is still under discussion - will now be required to complete a course or a series of courses and to adhere to good animal welfare practices. (Again, details for several aspects of the new law are not yet finalized.)   
SO - if you are a dog sitter, or if you use a dog sitter, be aware that the rules are set to change. So keep an eye on the BVet website for details.

The SVPA (SociÃ©tÃ© vaudoise de protection des animaux) is situated by Chalet-Ã -Gobet, direction Moudon. Ã  12h. et de 13h.30 Ã  17h, du lundi au samedi compris. "   
N.B. You will have to pay for your dog; the amount covers the expenses for the vet, vaccinations, food etc). I think it is between 100.- and 200.- CHF   
Another way is to look in free adds websites (  or scout 24 or anibis or zannonces) or to put an add. But anyone can give or sell any dog. Difficult to know if there is a problem, if the dod has been mistreated etc...

I moved to Walchwil (in Canton Zug) in August 2007 and am delighted at the number of amazing walks in and around the area which are dog friendly. All the walks seem to have doggy bins available and I often come accross other dogs which are being walked off leash. As people have mentioned before one has to be a responsible dog owner as farmers do not take kindly to there livestock being harrassed and in hunting season I tend to stay away from the woods (in Zug I believe hunting days are Monday Wednesday and Saturday). I have a very energetic weimeraner and she loves it here - we walk extensively in the Zugerberg and there are many quieter routes you can find when there are lots of people around. I invariably walk on my own on some very remote paths and always feel safe. The Swiss are generally very friendly and I make sure that if someone is walking without a dog I call mine back so she doesn't bother people who may not like dogs. There are also many beautiful walks that you can drive to - I often go to the Hunenburg river which is a very popular dog walking spot. There really are loads of appropriate places to let you dog off the leash and have a great time - I love it here.

Oh well I know the feeling... my scamp managed to stage an escape out of the garden and ran into the road... boy I thought my heart would stop!   
The best thing I can suggest is making friends with someone in your neighbourhood who owns a doggy too... I am a crazy dog mum and I'm proud to admit it   so I'm really fussy about who gets to take me dog unsupervised by me.    
As a kid, one of my holiday jobs was taking dogs for a walk for friends of the family, so perhaps you could find a responsible kid? Try posting something up or I think under the jobs section there are already some adverts for that.   
If I lived near you I'd offer to help but...   
My dog is small but boy she thinks shes a big one!

The   (courtesy of Google) starts off:   I am not too surprised that the center, according to the TDG, "... sees few dogs, and is not yet profitable".

I visited once to check out the kennels and assess their service.   
*** Disclaimer ****   
This was 7 or 8 years ago.   
I do have an ever so slight tendency to be just the tiniest bit OTT when it comes to my mutts.        
*****   
Their set up, while fine for many dogs, would not have been appropriate for my mad-as-a-box-of-frogs psycho-collie.    
When we visited we first had a chat with someone there (Not the owner, IIRC - I'm not sure who I spoke with...) to discuss my dogs, their needs, their characters and behavior, any problems/issues etc.,  as well as my expectations. I was quite frank about my collie;  the terrors of his past still haunted him, and he needed careful handling. The person I spoke to seemed rather dismissive of my concerns - and that left me feeling uncomfortable.    
In the end, I decided it was not the right solution for my dogs.    
But you really should go and check out the place yourself, talk to the people in charge, talk to the staff, and see if you think it will meet your own dog's needs. I remember once comparing notes with another dog owner who used them, and this person was quite happy.    
---- 
Instead of kennels, I have a dog sitter who moves into our house to care for my dogs while we are away. I've known her for many years now, and she always does a wonderful job with my collection of misfit mutts.   
If you are looking for that kind of solution, I can pass along the contact details.

Thanks for all that information, I was surprised to hear that they have to be pedigree to compete! In Finland X-breeds are very common in Agility and do very well Both our dogs are registered so hopefully we won't have a problem in CH.  Haku is the competitive side to disaster rescue, was initially started as a training exercise for the rescue dogs to teach them to search in a grid pattern rather than relying on following a scent, it is now a competition sport in it's own right, I would have liked to have got involved in the rescue side of things, but a high level of Finnish is required.  We donât do competitive obedience, But Hundehalterbrevet sounds like a combination of the BH and Character tests we do, BH is a test required to be passed by all competing dogs to ensure they are under at least a basic level of control, and include tasks such as being left in stay, walking past other dogs and behavior in traffic, The character test is just that, and is generally taken by dogs who will be used for breeding to ensure they are not too timid, aggressive or have other major character flaws. We will be living in the Lausanne area, and have already tracked down 1 agility club between there and Geneva. We had already found the bearded collie pages, and they seem to have some good activities

thread: failed to adopt a dog today

post:
At present, dog laws vary by canton -The proposed federal law has not yet been passed. Whether it will be enacted in the future, or what the final form will be, is anyone's guess.     
Where are you moving to? For info on each canton's current regulations, see:       
In any case, I believe your Bostons should have no problems. It's the poor 'bull' terriers who have been (unfairly   ) singled out.   
One thing you should consider - have your dogs flown before? Some airlines have special conditions for flying the brachycephalic breeds - you'll want to look into that.   
As for how easy it is to rent... kind of a roll of the dice.    As your dogs are small you are in an easier position than we were. Are you under much of a time constraint with the move?    
With our mutts, temporary housing was not really viable, so I made a trip over to find the house first. The house I chose wasn't going to be ready for another 3 months, so the dogs and I stayed in the US for that time, husband moved into a short term serviced appartment, and we joined him in CH once we had the keys to the house.   
When I was house hunting I was told housing would be a huge problem, but  in hindsight I have come to believe that was simply the relocation agent trying to scare us and squeeze a higher rent/commission out of us. (So stay away from the evil corporate relocation people!    )  Just stress to any potential landlord how well behaved and friendly and quiet your dogs are.     
(You may have to pay a higher deposit - we did - but again, I think that was just our slimeball agent. Our Swiss neighbors, who had dogs and rented from the same landlord, did not have to put down more than the usual deposit.)   
We settled for an old home in a town outside the city, with a large private garden. The house was small, nothing special, rather run-down, and far too expensive for what it was. But it had adequate secure space for the dogs to run and play, located in a dog-friendly neighborhood, with lots of great walks in the area - which was all I really cared about.    
Make sure you have express permission to keep all four of your dogs written into  the lease - this is very important. And, if there is anything else you need to arrange with the landlord - fencing, etc., make sure you have an agreement in writing.   
You will want to consider taking out insurance against any damage the dogs might do to the rental property - as we found out to our cost, this was NOT included in the standard    (private liability) insurance package offered by Winterthur.  We should have taken out a separate damage policy for that.  So make sure your insurer understands your needs.    
(And, stay away from the awful Swiss parquet flooring if you can! Doesn't stand up to the pitter-patter of canine feet, and is very expensive to replace if your landlord insists on it.)   
Good luck with your move.

No longer are you searching for a religious vet

Dr. M. Moser

4123 Allschwil

They're located in Allschwil, but if you don't have a car it is just steps away from the last tram stop on the number 6.

Rachcalde,   
Did you speak to the cantonal Tierarzt or the Staffy club for confirmation of what is required to bring your staffy in or to keep her in Basel? Please do, so that you get the official word. If I understand the Tier Im Recht synopsis correctly, you can bring her into Switzerland, but Basel 'may' place restrictions on how she is handled in public.    
(If language is a barrier, have your husband's HR people contact the cantonal Tierarzt.)   
Also, do look into living in other cantons.    
I certainly understand your feelings, however - my dogs' welfare is the first consideration in any decision to relocate (or not)... I moved to Switzerland because we could not bring my dogs into the UK pre-PETS.
